from ἐπί and ὀνομάζω; to name further, i.e. denominate:--call.
from ἐπί and a derivative of ὀπτάνομαι; to inspect, i.e. watch:--behold.
from ἐπί and a presumed derivative of ὀπτάνομαι; a looker-on:--eye-witness.
from ἔπω; a word:--X say.
from ἐπί and οὐρανός; above the sky:--celestial, (in) heaven(-ly), high.
a primary number; seven:--seven.
adverb from ἑπτά; seven times:--seven times.
from ἑπτάκις and χίλιοι; seven times a thousand:--seven thousand.

a primary verb (used only in the definite past tense, the others being borrowed from ἐρέω, ῥέω, and φημί); to speak or say (by word or writing):--answer, bid, bring word, call, command, grant, say (on), speak, tell. Compare λέγω.
from  (to love); beloved; Erastus, a Christian:--Erastus.
middle voice from ἔργον; to toil (as a task, occupation, etc.), (by implication) effect, be engaged in or with, etc.:--commit, do, labor for, minister about, trade (by), work.
from ἐργάτης; occupation; by implication, profit, pains:--craft, diligence, gain, work.
from ἔργον; a toiler; figuratively, a teacher:--labourer, worker(-men).
from a primary (but obsolete)  (to work); toil (as an effort or occupation); by implication, an act:--deed, doing, labour, work.
from a presumed prolonged form of ἔρις; to stimulate (especially to anger):--provoke.
of obscure affinity; to prop, i.e. (reflexively) get fast:--stick fast.
of uncertain affinity; to belch, i.e. (figuratively) to speak out:--utter.
apparently from ἐρέω (through the idea of inquiry); to seek, i.e. (figuratively) to investigate:--search.
probably a fuller form of ῥέω; an alternate for ἔπω in certain tenses; to utter, i.e. speak or say:--call, say, speak (of), tell.
from ἔρημος; solitude (concretely):--desert, wilderness.
of uncertain affinity; lonesome, i.e. (by implication) waste (usually as a noun, χώρα being implied):--desert, desolate, solitary, wilderness.
from ἔρημος; to lay waste (literally or figuratively):--(bring to, make) desolate(-ion), come to nought.
from ἐρημόω; despoliation:--desolation.
from ἔρις; to wrangle:--strive.
perhaps as the same as ἐρεθίζω; properly, intrigue, i.e. (by implication) faction:--contention(-ious), strife.
of obscure affinity; wool:--wool.
of uncertain affinity; a quarrel, i.e. (by implication) wrangling:--contention, debate, strife, variance.
from ἔριφος; a kidling, i.e. (genitive case) goat (symbolically, wicked person):--goat.
perhaps from the same as ἔριον (through the idea of hairiness); a kid or (genitive case) goat:--goat, kid.
probably from Ἑρμῆς; Hermas, a Christian:--Hermas.
from the same as ἑρμηνεύω; translation:--interpretation.
from a presumed derivative of Ἑρμῆς (as the god of language); to translate:--interpret.
perhaps from ἐρέω; Hermes, the name of the messenger of the Greek deities; also of a Christian:--Hermes, Mercury.
from Ἑρμῆς and γίνομαι; born of Hermes; Hermogenes, an apostate Christian:--Hermogenes.
neuter of a derivative of  (to creep); a reptile, i.e. (by Hebraism (compare רֶמֶשׂ)) a small animal:--creeping thing, serpent.
of uncertain affinity; red, i.e. (with θάλασσα) the Red Sea:--red.

middle voice of a primary verb  (used only in the present and imperfect tenses, the others being  supplied by a kindred (middle voice)               ,    or (active)        ,        which do not otherwise occur); to come or go (in a great variety of applications, literally and  figuratively):--accompany, appear, bring, come, enter, fall out, go, grow, X light, X next, pass, resort, be set.
apparently from ἐρέω (compare ἐρευνάω); to interrogate; by implication, to request:--ask, beseech, desire, intreat, pray. Compare πυνθάνομαι.
from  (to clothe); dress:--apparel, clothing, raiment, robe.
from a derivative of ἐσθής; clothing (concretely):--government.
strengthened for a primary  (to eat); used only in certain tenses, the rest being supplied by φάγω; to eat (usually literal):--devour, eat, live.
of Hebrew origin (probably for אֶלְיְהוֹעֵינַי); Esli, an Israelite:--Esli.
first person plural indicative of εἰμί; we are:--are, be, have our being, X have hope, + (the gospel) was (preached unto) us.
future of εἰμί; will be:--shall (should) be (have), (shall) come (to pass), X may have, X fall, what would follow, X live long, X sojourn.
from εἰς and a presumed derivative of ὀπτάνομαι; a mirror (for looking into):--glass. Compare κατοπτρίζομαι.
feminine of an adjective hesperos (evening); the eve (ὥρα being implied):--evening(-tide).
of Hebrew origin (חֶצְרוֹן); Esrom (i.e. Chetsron), an Israelite:--Esrom.
second person plural present indicative of εἰμί; ye are:--be, have been, belong.

third person singular present indicative of εἰμί; he (she or it) is; also (with neuter plural) they are:--are, be(-long), call, X can(-not), come, consisteth, X dure for a while, + follow, X have, (that) is (to say), make, meaneth, X must needs, + profit, + remaineth, + wrestle.
second person singular present imperative of εἰμί; be thou;  also    , third person of the same; let them be:--be.
a superlative probably from ἔχω (in the sense of contiguity); farthest, final (of place or time):--ends of, last, latter end, lowest, uttermost.
adverb from ἔσχατος; finally, i.e. (with ἔχω) at the extremity of life:--point of death.
from εἰς; inside (as preposition or adjective):-- (with-)in(-ner, -to, -ward).
from ἔσω; from inside; also used as equivalent to ἔσω (inside):--inward(-ly), (from) within, without.
comparative of ἔσω; interior:--inner, within.
from  (a clansman); a comrade:--fellow, friend.
from ἕτερος and γλῶσσα; other- tongued, i.e. a foreigner:--man of other tongue.
from ἕτερος and διδάσκαλος; to instruct differently:--teach other doctrine(-wise).
from a compound of ἕτερος and ζυγός; to yoke up differently, i.e. (figuratively) to associate discordantly:--unequally yoke together with.
of uncertain affinity; (an-, the) other or different:--altered, else, next (day), one, (an-)other, some, strange.
adverb from ἕτερος; differently:--otherwise.
perhaps akin to ἔτος; "yet," still (of time or degree):--after that, also, ever, (any) further, (t-)henceforth (more), hereafter, (any) longer, (any) more(-one), now, still, yet.
from ἕτοιμος; to prepare:--prepare, provide, make ready. Compare κατασκευάζω.
from ἑτοιμάζω; preparation:--preparation.
from an old noun  (fitness); adjusted, i.e. ready:--prepared, (made) ready(-iness, to our hand).
adverb from ἕτοιμος; in readiness:--ready.
apparently a primary word; a year:--year.
neuter of a primary  (good); (adverbially) well:--good, well (done).
of Hebrew origin (חַוָּה); Eua (or Eva, i.e. Chavvah), the first woman:--Eve.
from εὖ and ἄγγελος; to announce good news ("evangelize") especially the gospel:--declare, bring (declare, show) glad (good) tidings, preach (the gospel).
from the same as εὐαγγελίζω; a good message, i.e. the gospel:--gospel.
from εὐαγγελίζω; a preacher of the gospel:--evangelist.
from εὐάρεστος; to gratify entirely:--please (well).
from εὖ and ἀρεστός; fully agreeable:--acceptable(-ted), wellpleasing.
adverb from εὐάρεστος; quite agreeably:--acceptably, + please well.
from εὖ and βούλομαι; good-willer; Eubulus, a Christian:--Eubulus.
from εὖ and γίνομαι; well born, i.e. (literally) high in rank, or (figuratively) generous:--more noble, nobleman.
feminine from εὖ and the alternate of Ζεύς (as the god of the weather); a clear sky, i.e. fine weather:--fair weather.
from εὖ and δοκέω; to think well of, i.e. approve (an act); specially, to approbate (a person or thing):--think good, (be well) please(-d), be the good (have, take) pleasure, be willing.
from a presumed compound of εὖ and the base of δοκέω; satisfaction, i.e. (subjectively) delight, or (objectively) kindness, wish, purpose:--desire, good pleasure (will), X seem good.
from εὐεργέτης; beneficence (genitive case or specially):--benefit, good deed done.
from εὐεργέτης; to be philanthropic:--do good.
from εὖ and the base of ἔργον; a worker of good, i.e. (specially) a philanthropist:--benefactor.
from εὖ and a derivative of τίθημι; well placed, i.e. (figuratively) appropriate:--fit, meet.
adverb from εὐθύς; directly, i.e. at once or soon:--anon, as soon as, forthwith, immediately, shortly, straightway.
from εὐθύς and δρόμος; to lay a straight course, i.e. sail direct:--(come) with a straight course.
from εὔθυμος; to cheer up, i.e. (intransitively) be cheerful; neuter comparative (adverbially) more cheerfully:--be of good cheer (merry).
from εὖ and θυμός; in fine spirits, i.e. cheerful:--of good cheer, the more cheerfully.
from εὐθύς; to straighten (level); technically, to steer:--governor, make straight.
perhaps from εὖ and τίθημι; straight, i.e. (literally) level, or (figuratively) true; adverbially (of time) at once:--anon, by and by, forthwith, immediately, straightway.
from εὐθύς; rectitude:--righteousness.
from εὔκαιρος; to have good time, i.e. opportunity or leisure:--have leisure (convenient time), spend time.
from εὔκαιρος; a favorable occasion:--opportunity.
from εὖ and καιρός; well-timed, i.e. opportune:--convenient, in time of need.
adverb from εὔκαιρος; opportunely:--conveniently, in season.
comparative of a compound of εὖ and κόπος; better for toil, i.e. more facile:--easier.
from εὐλαβής; properly, caution, i.e. (religiously) reverence (piety); by implication, dread (concretely):--fear(-ed).
middle voice from εὐλαβής; to be circumspect, i.e. (by implication) to be apprehensive; religiously, to reverence:--(moved with) fear.
from εὖ and λαμβάνω; taking well (carefully), i.e. circumspect (religiously, pious):--devout.
from a compound of εὖ and λόγος; to speak well of, i.e. (religiously) to bless (thank or invoke a benediction upon, prosper):--bless, praise.
from εὐλογέω; adorable:--blessed.

from the same as εὐλογέω; fine speaking, i.e. elegance of language; commendation ("eulogy"), i.e. (reverentially) adoration; religiously, benediction; by implication, consecration; by extension, benefit or largess:--blessing (a matter of) bounty (X -tifully), fair speech.
from εὖ and a presumed derivative of μεταδίδωμι; good at imparting, i.e. liberal:--ready to distribute.
from εὖ and νίκη; victorious; Eunice, a Jewess:--Eunice.
from a compound of εὖ and νοῦς; to be well- minded, i.e. reconcile:--agree.
from the same as εὐνοέω; kindness; euphemistically, conjugal duty:--benevolence, good will.
from εὐνοῦχος; to castrate (figuratively, live unmarried):--make…eunuch.
from  (a bed) and ἔχω; a castrated person (such being employed in Oriental bed-chambers); by extension an impotent or unmarried man; by implication, a chamberlain (state-officer):--eunuch.
from the same as εὐοδόω; fine travelling; Euodia, a Christian woman:--Euodias.
from a compound of εὖ and ὁδός; to help on the road, i.e. (passively) succeed in reaching; figuratively, to succeed in business affairs:--(have a) prosper(-ous journey).
from εὖ and πείθω; good for persuasion, i.e. (intransitively) complaint:--easy to be intreated.

from εὖ and a derivative of a presumed compound of περί and ἵστημι; well standing around, i.e. (a competitor) thwarting (a racer) in every direction (figuratively, of sin in genitive case):--which doth so easily beset.
from a compound of εὖ and ποιέω; well-doing, i.e. beneficence:--to do good.
from a compound of ἑτοιμάζω and the base of πορεία; (intransitively) to be good for passing through, i.e. (figuratively) have pecuniary means:--ability.
from the same as εὐπορέω; pecuniary resources:--wealth.
from a compound of εὖ and πρέπω; good suitableness, i.e. gracefulness:--grace.
from εὖ and a derivative of προσδέχομαι; well-received, i.e. approved, favorable:--acceptable(-ted).
from εὖ and the same as προσεδρεύω; sitting well towards, i.e. (figuratively) assiduous (neuter, diligent service):--X attend upon.
from a compound of εὖ and πρόσωπον; to be of good countenance, i.e. (figuratively) to make a display:--make a fair show.

a prolonged form of a primary               ,      which                                 (together with another cognate form)                   is used for it in all the tenses                                except the present and imperfect; to find (literally or figuratively):--find, get, obtain, perceive, see.
from  (the east wind) and κλύδων; a storm from the East (or southeast), i.e. (in modern phrase) a Levanter:--Euroklydon.
from  (wide) and χώρα; spacious:--broad.
from εὐσεβής; piety; specially, the gospel scheme:--godliness, holiness.
from εὐσεβής; to be pious, i.e. (towards God) to worship, or (towards parents) to respect (support):--show piety, worship.
from εὖ and σέβομαι; well-reverent, i.e. pious:--devout, godly.
adverb from εὐσεβής; piously:--godly.
from εὖ and the base of σημαίνω; well indicated, i.e. (figuratively) significant:--easy to be understood.
from εὖ and σπλάγχνον; well compassioned, i.e. sympathetic:--pitiful, tender-hearted.
adverb from εὐσχήμων; decorously:--decently, honestly.
from εὐσχήμων; decorousness:--comeliness.
from εὖ and σχῆμα; well-formed, i.e. (figuratively) decorous, noble (in rank):--comely, honourable.
adverb from a compound of εὖ and a derivative of  (to stretch); in a well-strung manner, i.e. (figuratively) intensely (in a good sense, cogently; in a bad one, fiercely):--mightily, vehemently.
from a compound of εὖ and a derivative of the base of τροπή (meaning well-turned, i.e. ready at repartee, jocose); witticism, i.e. (in a vulgar sense) ribaldry:--jesting.
from εὖ and a derivative of τυγχάνω; well- fated, i.e. fortunate; Eutychus, a young man:--Eutychus.
from εὔφημος; good language ("euphemy"), i.e. praise (repute):--good report.
from εὖ and φήμη; well spoken of, i.e. reputable:--of good report.
from εὖ and φορέω; to bear well, i.e. be fertile:--bring forth abundantly.
from εὖ and φρήν; to put (middle voice or passively, be) in a good frame of mind, i.e. rejoice:--fare, make glad, be (make) merry, rejoice.
of foreign origin (compare פְּרָת); Euphrates, a river of Asia:--Euphrates.
from the same as εὐφραίνω; joyfulness:--gladness, joy.
from εὐχάριστος; to be grateful, i.e. (actively) to express gratitude (towards); specially, to say grace at a meal:--(give) thank(-ful, -s).
from εὐχάριστος; gratitude; actively, grateful language (to God, as an act of worship):--thankfulness, (giving of) thanks(-giving).
from εὖ and a derivative of χαρίζομαι; well favored, i.e. (by implication) grateful:--thankful.
from εὔχομαι; properly, a wish, expressed as a petition to God, or in votive obligation:--prayer, vow.
middle voice of a primary verb; to wish; by implication, to pray to God:--pray, will, wish.
from εὖ and χρηστός; easily used, i.e. useful:--profitable, meet for use.
from a compound of εὖ and ψυχή; to be in good spirits, i.e. feel encouraged:--be of good comfort.
from a compound of εὖ and a derivative of ὄζω; good-scentedness, i.e. fragrance:--sweet savour (smell, -smelling).
from εὖ and ὄνομα; properly, well-named (good-omened), i.e. the left (which was the lucky side among the pagan Greeks); neuter as adverbial, at the left hand:--(on the) left.
from ἐπί and ἅλλομαι; to spring upon:--leap on.
from ἐπί and ἅπαξ; upon one occasion (only):--(at) once (for all).
from Ἔφεσος; Ephesine, or situated at Ephesus:--of Ephesus.
from Ἔφεσος; an Ephesian or inhabitant of Ephesus:--Ephesian, of Ephesus.
probably of foreign origin; Ephesus, a city of Asia Minor:--Ephesus.
from a compound of ἐπί and εὑρίσκω; a discoverer, i.e. contriver:--inventor.
from ἐφήμερος; diurnality, i.e. (specially) the quotidian rotation or class of the Jewish priests' service at the Temple, as distributed by families:--course.
from ἐπί and ἡμέρα; for a day ("ephemeral"), i.e. diurnal:--daily.
from ἐπί and a cognate of ἥκω; to arrive upon, i.e. extend to:--reach.

from ἐπί and ἵστημι; to stand upon, i.e. be present (in various applications, friendly or otherwise, usually literal); --assault, come (in, to, unto, upon), be at hand (instant), present, stand (before, by, over).
of Hebrew origin (אֶפְרַיִם or better עֶפְרוֹן); Ephraim, a place in Palestine:--Ephraim.
of Chaldee origin (פְּתַח); be opened!:--Ephphatha.
feminine of ἐχθρός; hostility; by implication, a reason for opposition:--enmity, hatred.
from a primary  (to hate); hateful (passively, odious, or actively, hostile); usually as a noun, an adversary (especially Satan):--enemy, foe.
of uncertain origin; an adder or other poisonous snake (literally or figuratively):--viper.

a primary verb; to hold (used in very various applications, literally or figuratively, direct or remote; such as possession; ability, contiuity, relation, or condition):--be (able, X hold, possessed with), accompany, + begin to amend, can(+ -not), X conceive, count, diseased, do + eat, + enjoy, + fear, following, have, hold, keep, + lack, + go to law, lie, + must needs, + of necessity, + need, next, + recover, + reign, + rest, + return, X sick, take for, + tremble, + uncircumcised, use.
of uncertain affinity; a conjunction, preposition and adverb of continuance, until (of time and place):--even (until, unto), (as) far (as), how long, (un-)til(-l), (hither-, un-, up) to, while(-s).
of Hebrew origin (זְבוּלוּן); Zabulon (i.e. Zebulon), a region of Palestine:--Zabulon.
of Hebrew origin (compare זַכַּי); Zacchæus, an Israelite:--Zacchæus.
of Hebrew origin (זֶרַח); Zara, (i.e. Zerach), an Israelite:--Zara.
of Hebrew origin (זְכַרְיָה); Zacharias (i.e. Zechariah), the name of two Israelites:--Zacharias.
a primary verb; to live (literally or figuratively):--life(-time), (a-)live(-ly), quick.
of Hebrew origin (compare זַבְדִּי); Zebedæus, an Israelite:--Zebedee.
from ζέω; boiled, i.e. (by implication) calid (figuratively, fervent):--hot.
from the same as ζυγός; a couple, i.e. a team (of oxen yoked together) or brace (of birds tied together):--yoke, pair.
feminine of a derivative (at the second stage) from the same as ζυγός; a fastening (tiller-rope):--band.

of uncertain affinity; in the oblique cases there is used instead of it a (probably cognate) name        , which is otherwise obsolete;        Zeus or Dis (among the Latins, Jupiter or Jove), the supreme deity of the Greeks:--Jupiter.
a primary verb; to be hot (boil, of liquids; or glow, of solids), i.e. (figuratively) be fervid (earnest):--be fervent.

from ζέω; properly, heat, i.e. (figuratively) "zeal" (in a favorable sense, ardor; in an unfavorable one, jealousy, as of a husband (figuratively, of God), or an enemy, malice):--emulation, envy(-ing), fervent mind, indignation, jealousy, zeal.
from ζῆλος; to have warmth of feeling for or against:--affect, covet (earnestly), (have) desire, (move with) envy, be jealous over, (be) zealous(-ly affect).
from ζηλόω; a "zealot":--zealous.
the same as ζηλωτής; a Zealot, i.e. (specially) partisan for Jewish political independence:--Zelotes.
probably akin to the base of δαμάζω (through the idea of violence); detriment:--damage, loss.
from ζημία; to injure, i.e. (reflexively or passively) to experience detriment:--be cast away, receive damage, lose, suffer loss.
probably contracted from a poetic form of Ζεύς and δῶρον; Jove-given; Zenas, a Christian:--Zenas.

of uncertain affinity; to seek (literally or figuratively); specially, (by Hebraism) to worship (God), or (in a bad sense) to plot (against life):--be (go) about, desire, endeavour, enquire (for), require, (X will) seek (after, for, means). Compare πυνθάνομαι.
from ζητέω; a search (properly concretely), i.e. (in words) a debate:--question.
from ζητέω; a searching (properly, the act), i.e. a dispute or its theme:--question.
of uncertain origin; darnel or false grain:--tares.
of Hebrew origin (זְרֻבָּבֶל); Zorobabel (i.e. Zerubbabel), an Israelite:--Zorobabel.
akin to the base of νέφος; gloom (as shrouding like a cloud):--blackness, darkness, mist.

from the root of  (to join, especially by a "yoke"); a coupling, i.e. (figuratively) servitude (a law or obligation); also (literally) the beam of the balance (as connecting the scales):--pair of balances, yoke.
probably from ζέω; ferment (as if boiling up):--leaven.
from ζύμη; to cause to ferment:--leaven.
from the same as ζῶον and ἀγρεύω; to take alive (make a prisoner of war), i.e. (figuratively) to capture or ensnare:--take captive, catch.
from ζάω; life (literally or figuratively):--life(-time). Compare ψυχή.
probably akin to the base of ζυγός; a belt; by implication, a pocket:--girdle, purse.
from ζώνη; to bind about (especially with a belt):--gird.
from the same as ζῶον and a derivative of γίνομαι; to engender alive, i.e. (by analogy) to rescue (passively, be saved) from death:--live, preserve.
neuter of a derivative of ζάω; a live thing, i.e. an animal:--beast.
from the same as ζῶον and ποιέω; to (re-)vitalize (literally or figuratively):--make alive, give life, quicken.

a primary particle of distinction between two connected terms; disjunctive, or; comparative, than:--and, but (either), (n-)either, except it be, (n-)or (else), rather, save, than, that, what, yea. Often used in connection with other particles. Compare especially ἤδη, ἤπερ, ἤτοι.
an adverb of confirmation; perhaps intensive of ἤ; used only (in the New Testament) before μέν; assuredly:--surely.
from ἡγεμών; to act as ruler:--be governor.
from ἡγεμών; government, i.e. (in time) official term:--reign.
from ἡγέομαι; a leader, i.e. chief person (or figuratively, place) of a province:--governor, prince, ruler.

middle voice of a (presumed) strengthened form of ἄγω; to lead, i.e. command (with official authority); figuratively, to deem, i.e. consider:--account, (be) chief, count, esteem, governor, judge, have the rule over, suppose, think.
adverb from a derivative of the base of ἡδονή; sweetly, i.e. (figuratively) with pleasure:--gladly.
apparently from ἤ (or possibly ἦ) and δή; even now:--already, (even) now (already), by this time.
neuter plural of the superlative of the same as ἡδέως; with great pleasure:--most (very) gladly.
from  (to please); sensual delight; by implication, desire:--lust, pleasure.
neuter of the compound of the same as ἡδέως and ὀσμή; a sweet-scented plant, i.e. mint:--mint.
a strengthened form of ἔθος; usage, i.e. (plural) moral habits:--manners.
a primary verb; to arrive, i.e. be present (literally or figuratively):--come.
of Hebrew origin (אֵל with pronominal suffix); my God:-- Eli.
of Hebrew origin (עֵלִי); Heli (i.e. Eli), an Israelite:--Heli.
of Hebrew origin (אֵלִיָּה); Helias (i.e. Elijah), an Israelite:--Elias.
from the same as ἡλίκος; maturity (in years or size):--age, stature.
from  (a comrade, i.e. one of the same age); as big as, i.e. (interjectively) how much:--how (what) great.
from  (a ray; perhaps akin to the alternate of αἱρέομαι); the sun; by implication, light:--+ east, sun.
of uncertain affinity; a stud, i.e. spike:--nail.
accusative case plural of ἐγώ; us:--our, us, we.
nominative plural of ἐγώ; we (only used when emphatic):--us, we (ourselves).

feminine (with ὥρα implied) of a derivative of  (to sit; akin to the base of ἑδραῖος) meaning tame, i.e. gentle; day, i.e. (literally) the time space between dawn and dark, or the whole 24 hours (but several days were usually reckoned by the Jews as inclusive of the parts of both extremes); figuratively, a period (always defined more or less clearly by the context):--age, + alway, (mid-)day (by day, (-ly)), + for ever, judgment, (day) time, while, years.
from θνητός; our:--our, your (by a different reading).
a prolonged form of ἦν; I was:--be, was. (Sometimes unexpressed).
from a presumed compound of the base of ἥμισυ and θνήσκω; half dead, i.e. entirely exhausted:--half dead.
dative case plural of ἐγώ; to (or for, with, by) us:--our, (for) us, we.
neuter of a derivative from an inseparable prefix akin to ἅμα (through the idea of partition involved in connection) and meaning semi-; (as noun) half:--half.
from the base of ἥμισυ and ὥρα; a half-hour:--half an hour.
genitive case plural of ἐγώ; of (or from) us:--our (company), us, we.
imperfect of εἰμί; I (thou, etc.) was (wast or were):--+ agree, be, X have (+ charge of), hold, use, was(-t), were.
of uncertain affinity; at which time:--when.
from ἤ and περ; than at all (or than perhaps, than indeed):--than.
probably from ἔπος; properly, affable, i.e. mild or kind:--gentle.
of Hebrew origin (עֵר); Er, an Israelite:--Er.
perhaps by transposition from ἔρημος (through the idea of stillness); tranquil:--quiet.
compound of  (a "hero") and εἶδος; heroic; Herod, the name of four Jewish kings:--Herod.
plural of a derivative of Ἡρώδης; Herodians, i.e. partisans of Herod:--Herodians.
from Ἡρώδης; Herodias, a woman of the Heodian family:--Herodias.
from Ἡρώδης; Herodion, a Christian:--Herodion.
of Hebrew origin (יְשַׁעְיָה); Hesaias (i.e. Jeshajah), an Israelite:--Esaias.
of Hebrew origin (עֵשָׂו); Esau, an Edomite:--Esau.
from the same as ἡσύχιος; to keep still (intransitively), i.e. refrain from labor, meddlesomeness or speech:--cease, hold peace, be quiet, rest.
feminine of ἡσύχιος; (as noun) stillness, i.e. desistance from bustle or language:--quietness, silence.

a prolonged form of a compound probably of a derivative of the base of ἑδραῖος and perhaps ἔχω; properly, keeping one's seat (sedentary), i.e. (by implication) still (undisturbed, undisturbing):--peaceable, quiet.
from ἤ and τοί; either indeed:--whether.
from the same as ἥττον; to make worse, i.e. vanquish (literally or figuratively); by implication, to rate lower:--be inferior, overcome.
from ἡττάω; a deterioration, i.e. (objectively) failure or (subjectively) loss:--diminishing, fault.
neuter of comparative of  (slightly) used for that of κακός; worse (as noun); by implication, less (as adverb):--less, worse.
third person singular imperative of εἰμί; let him (or it) be:--let … be.
from ἦχος; to make a loud noise, i.e. reverberate:--roar, sound.
of uncertain affinity; a loud or confused noise ("echo"), i.e. roar; figuratively, a rumor:--fame, sound.
of uncertain origin; Thaddæus, one of the Apostles:--Thaddæus.
probably prolonged from ἅλς; the sea (genitive case or specially):--sea.
probably akin to  (to warm); to brood, i.e. (figuratively) to foster:--cherish.
of Hebrew origin (תָּמָר); Thamar (i.e. Tamar), an Israelitess:--Thamar.
from θάμβος; to stupefy (with surprise), i.e. astound:--amaze, astonish.
akin to an obsolete  (to dumbfound); stupefaction (by surprise), i.e. astonishment:--X amazed, + astonished, wonder.
from θάνατος; fatal, i.e. poisonous:--deadly.
from (the feminine form of) θάνατος and φέρω; death-bearing, i.e. fatal:--deadly.
from θνήσκω; (properly, an adjective used as a noun) death (literally or figuratively):--X deadly, (be…) death.
from θάνατος to kill (literally or figuratively):--become dead, (cause to be) put to death, kill, mortify.
a primary verb; to celebrate funeral rites, i.e. inter:--bury.
of Hebrew origin (תֶּרַח); Thara (i.e. Terach), the father of Abraham:--Thara.
another form for θαρσέω; to exercise courage:--be bold, X boldly, have confidence, be confident. Compare τολμάω.
from θάρσος; to have courage:--be of good cheer (comfort). Compare θαῤῥέω.
akin (by transposition) to  (daring); boldness (subjectively):--courage.
apparently from a form of θεάομαι; wonder (properly concrete; but by implication, abstract):--admiration.
from θαῦμα; to wonder; by implication, to admire:--admire, have in admiration, marvel, wonder.
from θαῦμα; wondrous, i.e. (neuter as noun) a miracle:--wonderful thing.
from θαυμάζω; wondered at, i.e. (by implication) wonderful:--marvel(-lous).
feminine of θεός; a female deity:--goddess.
a prolonged form of a primary verb; to look closely at, i.e. (by implication) perceive (literally or figuratively); by extension to visit:--behold, look (upon), see. Compare ὀπτάνομαι.
from θέατρον; to expose as a spectacle:--make a gazing stock.
from θεάομαι; a place for public show ("theatre"), i.e. general audience-room; by implication, a show itself (figuratively):--spectacle, theatre.
probably neuter of θεῖος (in its original sense of flashing); sulphur:--brimstone.
from θεός; godlike (neuter as noun, divinity):-- divine, godhead.
from θεῖος; divinity (abstractly):--godhead.
from θεῖον and 1491; sulphur-like, i.e. sulphurous:--brimstone.
from the prolonged form of θέλω; a determination (properly, the thing), i.e. (actively) choice (specially, purpose, decree; abstractly, volition) or (passively) inclination:-- desire, pleasure, will.
from θέλω; determination (properly, the act), i.e. option:--will.

apparently strengthened from the alternate form of αἱρέομαι; to determine (as an active option from subjective impulse; whereas βούλομαι properly denotes rather a passive acquiescence in objective considerations), i.e. choose or prefer (literally or figuratively); by implication, to wish, i.e. be inclined to (sometimes adverbially, gladly); impersonally for the future tense, to be about to; by Hebraism, to delight in:--desire, be disposed (forward), intend, list, love, mean, please, have rather, (be) will (have, -ling, - ling(-ly)).
from a derivative of τίθημι; something put down, i.e. a substruction (of a building, etc.), (literally or figuratively):--foundation.
from θεμέλιος; to lay a basis for, i.e. (literally) erect, or (figuratively) consolidate:--(lay the) found(- ation), ground, settle.
from θεός and διδάσκω; divinely instructed:--taught of God.
from θεομάχος; to resist deity:--fight against God.
from θεός and μάχομαι; an opponent of deity:--to fight against God.
from θεός and a presumed derivative of πνέω; divinely breathed in:--given by inspiration of God.
of uncertain affinity; a deity, especially (with ὁ) the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very:--X exceeding, God, god(-ly, -ward).
from θεοσεβής; devoutness, i.e. piety:--godliness.
from θεός and σέβομαι; reverent of God, i.e. pious:--worshipper of God.
from θεός and the base of στυγνητός; hateful to God, i.e. impious:--hater of God.
from θεός; divinity (abstractly):--godhead.
from θεός and φίλος; friend of God; Theophilus, a Christian:--Theophilus.
from θεραπεύω; attendance (specially, medical, i.e. cure); figuratively and collectively, domestics:--healing, household.
from the same as θεράπων; to wait upon menially, i.e. (figuratively) to adore (God), or (specially) to relieve (of disease):--cure, heal, worship.
apparently a participle from an otherwise obsolete derivative of the base of θέρος; a menial attendant (as if cherishing):--servant.
from θέρος (in the sense of the crop); to harvest:--reap.
from θερίζω; reaping, i.e. the crop:--harvest.
from θερίζω; a harvester:--reaper.
from θέρμη; to heat (oneself):--(be) warm(-ed, self).
from the base of θέρος; warmth:--heat.
from a primary  (to heat); properly, heat, i.e. summer:--summer.
from Θεσσαλονίκη; a Thessalonican, i.e. inhabitant of Thessalonice:--Thessalonian.
from  (a Thessalian) and νίκη; Thessalonice, a place in Asia Minor:--Thessalonica.
of uncertain origin; Theudas, an Israelite:--Theudas.

from a derivative of θεάομαι (perhaps by addition of ὁράω); to be a spectator of, i.e. discern, (literally, figuratively (experience) or intensively (acknowledge)):--behold, consider, look on, perceive, see. Compare ὀπτάνομαι.
from the same as θεωρέω; spectatorship, i.e. (concretely) a spectacle:--sight.
from τίθημι; a receptacle, i.e. scabbard:--sheath.
from  (the nipple); to suckle, (by implication) to suck:--(give) suck(-ling).
from the same as θηλάζω; female:--female, woman.
from  (a wild animal, as game); hunting, i.e. (figuratively) destruction:--trap.
from θήρα; to hunt (an animal), i.e. (figuratively) to carp at:--catch.
from a compound of θηρίον and μάχομαι; to be a beast-fighter (in the gladiatorial show), i.e. (figuratively) to encounter (furious men):--fight with wild beasts.
diminutive from the same as θήρα; a dangerous animal:--(venomous, wild) beast.
from θησαυρός; to amass or reserve (literally or figuratively):--lay up (treasure), (keep) in store, (heap) treasure (together, up).
from τίθημι; a deposit, i.e. wealth (literally or figuratively):--treasure.
a prolonged form of an obsolete primary  (to finger); to manipulate, i.e. have to do with; by implication, to injure:--handle, touch.
akin to the base of τρίβος; to crowd (literally or figuratively):--afflict, narrow, throng, suffer tribulation, trouble.
from θλίβω; pressure (literally or figuratively):--afflicted(-tion), anguish, burdened, persecution, tribulation, trouble.
a strengthened form of a simpler primary   (which is used for it only in certain tenses); to die (literally or figuratively):--be dead, die.
from θνήσκω; liable to die:--mortal(-ity).
from θόρυβος; to be in tumult, i.e. disturb, clamor:--make ado (a noise), trouble self, set on an uproar.
from the base of θροέω; a disturbance:--tumult, uproar.
a primary verb; to crush:--bruise. Compare ῥήγνυμι.
from τρέφω; stock (as raised on a farm):--cattle.
from θρῆνος; to bewail:--lament, mourn.
from the base of θροέω; wailing:--lamentation.
from a derivative of θρησκός; ceremonial observance:--religion, worshipping.
probably from the base of θροέω; ceremonious in worship (as demonstrative), i.e. pious:--religious.

from a prolonged compound of the base of θροέω; and a derivative of ἅπτομαι (meaning a noisy iambus, sung in honor of Bacchus); to make an acclamatory procession, i.e. (figuratively) to conquer or (by Hebraism) to give victory:--(cause) to triumph (over).
genitive case , etc.; of uncertain derivation; hair:--hair. Compare κόμη.
from  to wail; to clamor, i.e. (by implication) to frighten:--trouble.
perhaps from τρέφω (in the sense of thickening); a clot:--great drop.
from  (to sit); a stately seat ("throne"); by implication, power or (concretely) a potentate:--seat, throne.
of uncertain derivation; Thyatira, a place in Asia Minor:--Thyatira.
apparently a primary word (compare "daughter"); a female child, or (by Hebraism) descendant (or inhabitant):--daughter.
from θυγάτηρ; a daughterling:--little (young) daughter.
from θύω (in the sense of blowing) a storm:--tempest.
from a derivative of θύω (in the sense of blowing; denoting a certain fragrant tree); made of citron-wood:--thyine.
from θυμιάω; an aroma, i.e. fragrant powder burnt in religious service; by implication, the burning itself:--incense, odour.
from a derivative of θυμιάω; a place of fumigation, i.e. the alter of incense (in the Temple):--censer.
from a derivative of θύω (in the sense of smoking); to fumigate, i.e. offer aromatic fumes:--burn incense.
from a presumed compound of θυμός and μάχομαι; to be in a furious fight, i.e. (figuratively) to be exasperated:--be highly displeased.
from θύω; passion (as if breathing hard):--fierceness, indignation, wrath. Compare ψυχή.
from θυμός; to put in a passion, i.e. enrage:--be wroth.
apparently a primary word (compare "door"); a portal or entrance (the opening or the closure, literally or figuratively):--door, gate.
from θύρα; a large shield (as door-shaped):--shield.
from θύρα; an aperture, i.e. window:--window.
from θύρα and  (a watcher); a gate- warden:--that kept the door, porter.
from θύω; sacrifice (the act or the victim, literally or figuratively):--sacrifice.
from a derivative of θυσία; a place of sacrifice, i.e. an altar (special or genitive case, literal or figurative):--altar.

a primary verb; properly, to rush (breathe hard, blow, smoke), i.e. (by implication) to sacrifice (properly, by fire, but genitive case); by extension to immolate (slaughter for any purpose):--kill, (do) sacrifice, slay.
of Chaldee origin (compare תָּאוֹם); the twin; Thomas, a Christian:--Thomas.
of uncertain affinity; the chest ("thorax"), i.e. (by implication) a corslet:--breast-plate.
of Hebrew origin (יָאִיר); Jairus (i.e. Jair), an Israelite:--Jairus.
of Hebrew origin (יַעֲקֹב); Jacob (i.e. Ja`akob), the progenitor of the Israelites:--also an Israelite:--Jacob.
the same as Ἰακώβ Græcized; Jacobus, the name of three Israelites:--James.
from ἰάομαι; a cure (the effect):--healing.
of Egyptian origin; Jambres, an Egyptian:--Jambres.
probably of Hebrew origin (compare יָנָה); Janna, an Israelite:--Janna.
of Egyptian origin; Jannes, an Egyptian:--Jannes.
middle voice of apparently a primary verb; to cure (literally or figuratively):--heal, make whole.
of Hebrew origin (יֶרֶד); Jared (i.e. Jered), an antediluvian:--Jared.
from ἰάομαι; curing (the act):--cure, heal(-ing).
probably of foreign origin (see יָשְׁפֵה); "jasper", a gem:--jasper.
future active participle masculine of ἰάομαι; about to cure; Jason, a Christian:--Jason.
from ἰάομαι; a physician:--physician.
second person singular imperative active of εἴδω; used as an interjection to denote surprise; lo!:--behold, lo, see.
from εἴδω; a sight (comparative figuratively "idea"), i.e. aspect:--countenance.

of uncertain affinity; pertaining to self, i.e. one's own; by implication, private or separate:--X his acquaintance, when they were alone, apart, aside, due, his (own, proper, several), home, (her, our, thine, your) own (business), private(-ly), proper, severally, their (own).
from ἴδιος; a private person, i.e. (by implication) an ignoramus (compare "idiot"):--ignorant, rude, unlearned.
second person singular imperative middle voice of εἴδω; used as imperative lo!; --behold, lo, see.
of Hebrew origin (אֱדֹם); Idumæa (i.e. Edom), a region East (and South) of Palestine:--Idumæa.
a strengthened form of a primary idos (sweat); perspiration:--sweat.
of Hebrew origin (אִיזֶבֶל); Jezabel (i.e. Jezebel), a Tyrian woman (used as a synonym of a termagant or false teacher):--Jezabel.
from ἱερός and πόλις; holy city; Hierapolis, a place in Asia Minor:--Hierapolis.
from ἱερατεύω; priestliness, i.e. the sacerdotal function:--office of the priesthood, priest's office.
from ἱερατεύω; the priestly fraternity, i.e. sacerdotal order (figuratively):--priesthood.
prolongation from ἱερεύς; to be a priest, i.e. perform his functions:--execute the priest's office.
of Hebrew origin (יִרְמְיָה); Hieremias (i.e. Jermijah), an Israelite:--Jeremiah.
from ἱερός; a priest (literally or figuratively):--(high) priest.
of Hebrew origin (יְרִיחוֹ); Jericho, a place in Palestine:--Jericho.
neuter of ἱερός; a sacred place, i.e. the entire precincts (whereas ναός denotes the central sanctuary itself) of the Temple (at Jerusalem or elsewhere):--temple.
from ἱερός and the same as πρέπω; reverent:--as becometh holiness.
of uncertain affinity; sacred:--holy.
of Hebrew origin (יְרוּשָׁלַ͏ִם); Hierosolyma (i.e. Jerushalaim), the capitol of Palestine:--Jerusalem. Compare Ἱερουσαλήμ.
from Ἱεροσόλυμα; a Hierosolymite, i.e. inhabitant of Hierosolyma:--of Jerusalem.
from ἱερόσυλος; to be a temple-robber (figuratively):--commit sacrilege.
from ἱερόν and συλάω; a temple-despoiler:--robber of churches.
from a compound of ἱερόν and the base of ἔργον; to be a temple-worker, i.e. officiate as a priest (figuratively):--minister.
of Hebrew origin (יְרוּשָׁלַ͏ִם); Hierusalem (i.e. Jerushalem), the capitol of Palestine:--Jerusalem. Compare Ἱεροσόλυμα.
from ἱερός; sacredness, i.e. (by implication) the priestly office:--priesthood.
of Hebrew origin (יִשַׁי); Jessæ (i.e. Jishai), an Israelite:--Jesse.
of Hebrew origin (יִפְתָּח); Jephthaë (i.e. Jiphtach), an Israelite:--Jephthah.
of Hebrew origin (יְכׇנְיָה); Jechonias (i.e. Jekonjah), an Israelite:--Jechonias.
of Hebrew origin (יְהוֹשׁוּעַ); Jesus (i.e. Jehoshua), the name of our Lord and two (three) other Israelites:--Jesus.

from  ( or , akin to ἥκω) (to arrive); competent (as if coming in season), i.e. ample (in amount) or fit (in character):--able, + content, enough, good, great, large, long (while), many, meet, much, security, sore, sufficient, worthy.
from ἱκανός; ability:--sufficiency.
from ἱκανός; to enable, i.e. qualify:--make able (meet).
from a derivative of the base of ἱκανός (through the idea of approaching for a favor); intreaty:--supplication.
of uncertain affinity; dampness:--moisture.
perhaps from εἰκών; image-like; Iconium, a place in Asia Minor:--Iconium.
from the same as ἵλεως; propitious or merry ("hilarious"), i.e. prompt or willing:--cheerful.
from ἱλαρός; alacrity:--cheerfulness.
middle voice from the same as ἵλεως; to conciliate, i.e. (transitively) to atone for (sin), or (intransitively) be propitious:--be merciful, make reconciliation for.
neuter of a derivative of ἱλάσκομαι; an expiatory (place or thing), i.e. (concretely) an atoning victim, or (specially) the lid of the Ark (in the Temple):--mercyseat, propitiation.
perhaps from the alternate form of αἱρέομαι; cheerful (as attractive), i.e. propitious; adverbially (by Hebraism) God be gracious!, i.e. (in averting some calamity) far be it:--be it far, merciful.
neuter of an adjective from a name of uncertain derivation; (the) Illyrican (shore), i.e. (as a name itself) Illyricum, a region of Europe:--Illyricum.
perhaps from the same as ἅμα; a strap, i.e. (specially) the tie (of a sandal) or the lash (of a scourge):--latchet, thong.
from ἱμάτιον; to dress:--clothe.
neuter of a presumed derivative of ennumi (to put on); a dress (inner or outer):--apparel, cloke, clothes, garment, raiment, robe, vesture.
from ἱματίζω; clothing:--apparel (X -led), array, raiment, vesture.
middle voice from  (a yearning; of uncertain affinity); to long for:--be affectionately desirous.

probably from the same as the former part of ἑαυτοῦ (through the demonstrative idea; compare ὁ); in order that (denoting the purpose or the result):--albeit, because, to the intent (that), lest, so as, (so) that, (for) to. Compare ἵνα μή.
from ἵνα and τίς; for what reason ?, i.e. why?:--wherefore, why.
of Hebrew origin (יָפוֹ); Joppe (i.e. Japho), a place in Palestine:--Joppa.
of Hebrew origin (יַרְדֵּן); the Jordanes (i.e. Jarden), a river of Palestine:--Jordan.
perhaps from  (to go) or  (to send); rust (as if emitted by metals); also venom (as emitted by serpents):--poison, rust.
of Hebrew origin (יְהוּדָה or perhaps יֻטָּה); Judah (i.e. Jehudah or Juttah), a part of (or place in) Palestine:--Judah.
feminine of Ἰουδαῖος (with γῆ implied); the Judæan land (i.e. Judæa), a region of Palestine:--Judæa.
from Ἰουδαῖος; to become a Judæan, i.e. "Judaize":--live as the Jews.
from Ἰουδαῖος; Judaïc, i.e. resembling a Judæan:--Jewish.
adverb from Ἰουδαϊκός; Judaïcally or in a manner resembling a Judæan:--as do the Jews.
from Ἰουδά (in the sense of Ἰούδας as a country); Judæan, i.e. belonging to Jehudah:--Jew(-ess), of Judæa.
from Ἰουδαΐζω; "Judaism", i.e. the Jewish faith and usages:--Jews' religion.
of Hebrew origin (יְהוּדָה); Judas (i.e. Jehudah), the name of ten Israelites; also of the posterity of one of them and its region:--Juda(-h, -s); Jude.
feminine of the same as Ἰούλιος; Julia, a Christian woman:--Julia.
of Latin origin; Julius, a centurion:--Julius.
of Latin origin; Junias, a Christian:--Junias.
of Latin origin ("just"); Justus, the name of three Christian:--Justus.
from ἵππος; an equestrian, i.e. member of a cavalry corps:--horseman.
neuter of a derivative of ἵππος; the cavalry force:--horse(-men).
of uncertain affinity; a horse:--horse.
perhaps from ἐρέω (as a symbol of the female messenger of the pagan deities); a rainbow ("iris"):--rainbow.
of Hebrew origin (יִצְחָק); Isaac (i.e. Jitschak), the son of Abraham:--Isaac.
from ἴσος and ἄγγελος; like an angel, i.e. angelic:--equal unto the angels.
of Hebrew origin (יִשָּׂשכָר); Isachar (i.e. Jissaskar), a son of Jacob (figuratively, his descendant):--Issachar.
assumed by some as the base of certain irregular forms of εἴδω; to know:--know.
second person imperative present of εἰμί; be thou:--+ agree, be, X give thyself wholly to.
of Hebrew origin (probably אִישׁ and קִרְיָא); inhabitant of Kerioth; Iscariotes (i.e. Keriothite), an epithet of Judas the traitor:--Iscariot.
probably from εἴδω (through the idea of seeming); similar (in amount and kind):--+ agree, as much, equal, like.
from ἴσος and τιμή; of equal value or honor:--like precious.
from ἴσος and ψυχή; of similar spirit:--likeminded.
of Hebrew origin (יִשְׂרָאֵל); Israel (i.e. Jisrael), the adopted name of Jacob, including his descendants (literally or figuratively):--Israel.
from Ἰσραήλ; an "Israelite", i.e. descendant of Israel (literally or figuratively):--Israelite.

a prolonged form of a primary   (of the same meaning, and used for it in certain tenses); to stand (transitively or intransitively), used in various applications (literally or figuratively):--abide, appoint, bring, continue, covenant, establish, hold up, lay, present, set (up), stanch, stand (by, forth, still, up). Compare τίθημι.
from a derivative of εἴδω; to be knowing (learned), i.e. (by implication) to visit for information (interview):--see.
from ἰσχύς; forcible (literally or figuratively):--boisterous, mighty(-ier), powerful, strong(-er, man), valiant.
from a derivative of  (force; compare , a form of ἔχω); forcefulness (literally or figuratively):--ability, might(-ily), power, strength.
from ἰσχύς; to have (or exercise) force (literally or figuratively):--be able, avail, can do(-not), could, be good, might, prevail, be of strength, be whole, + much work.
adverb from ἴσος; likely, i.e. perhaps:--it may be.
probably of foreign origin; Italia, a region of Europe:--Italy.
from Ἰταλία; Italic, i.e. belonging to Italia:--Italian.
of Hebrew origin (יְטוּר); Ituræa (i.e. Jetur), a region of Palestine:--Ituræa.
diminutive from ἰχθύς; a petty fish:--little (small) fish.
of uncertain affinity; a fish:--fish.
from  (to arrive; compare ἥκω); a track (figuratively):--step.
of Hebrew origin (יוֹתָם); Joatham (i.e. Jotham), an Israelite:--Joatham.
feminine of the same as Ἰωάννης; Joanna, a Christian:--Joanna.
a form of Ἰωάννης; Joannas, an Israelite:--Joannas.
of Hebrew origin (יוֹחָנָן); Joannes (i.e. Jochanan), the name of four Israelites:--John.
of Hebrew origin (אִיּוֹב); Job (i.e. Ijob), a patriarch:--Job.
of Hebrew origin (יוֹאֵל); Joel, an Israelite:--Joel.
probably for Ἰωάννης or Ἰωνᾶς; Jonan, an Israelite:--Jonan.
of Hebrew origin (יוֹנָה); Jonas (i.e. Jonah), the name of two Israelites:--Jonas.
of Hebrew origin (יוֹרָם); Joram, an Israelite:--Joram.
perhaps for Ἰωράμ; Jorim, an Israelite:--Jorim.
of Hebrew origin (יְהוֹשָׁפָט); Josaphat (i.e. Jehoshaphat), an Israelite:--Josaphat.
genitive case of Ἰωσῆς; Jose, an Israelite:--Jose.
perhaps for Ἰωσήφ; Joses, the name of two Israelites:--Joses. Compare Ἰωσή.
of Hebrew origin (יוֹסֵף); Joseph, the name of seven Israelites:--Joseph.
of Hebrew origin (יֹאשִׁיָּה); Josias (i.e. Joshiah), an Israelite:--Josias.
of Hebrew origin (the tenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet); "iota", the name of the eighth letter of the Greek alphabet, put (figuratively) for a very small part of anything:--jot.
from καί and ἐγώ;   so also the dative case          ,  and accusative case                and (or also, even, etc.) I, (to) me:--(and, even, even so, so) I  (also, in like wise), both me, me also.
from κατά and the neuter plural of ὅς; according to which things, i.e. just as:--as.
from καθαιρέω; demolition; figuratively, extinction:--destruction, pulling down.
from κατά and αἱρέομαι (including its alternate); to lower (or with violence) demolish (literally or figuratively):--cast (pull, put, take) down, destroy.
from καθαρός; to cleanse, i.e. (specially) to prune; figuratively, to expiate:--purge.
from καθά and περ; exactly as:--(even, as well) as.
from κατά and ἅπτομαι; to seize upon:--fasten on.
from καθαρός; to cleanse (literally or figuratively):--(make) clean(-se), purge, purify.
from καθαρίζω; a washing off, i.e. (ceremonially) ablution, (morally) expiation:--cleansing, + purge, purification(-fying).
of uncertain affinity; clean (literally or figuratively):--clean, clear, pure.
from καθαρός; cleanness (ceremonially):--purification.
from κατά and the same as ἑδραῖος; a bench (literally or figuratively):--seat.
from κατά and the base of ἑδραῖος; to sit down:--sit.
from κατά and ἑξῆς; thereafter, i.e. consecutively; as a noun (by ellipsis of noun) a subsequent person or time:--after(-ward), by (in) order.
from κατά and  (to sleep); to lie down to rest, i.e. (by implication) to fall asleep (literally or figuratively):--(be a-)sleep.
from a compound of κατά and ἡγέομαι; a guide, i.e. (figuratively) a teacher:--master.
from κατά and ἥκω; to reach to, i.e. (neuter of present active participle, figuratively as adjective) becoming:-- convenient, fit.
from κατά; and  (to sit; akin to the base of ἑδραῖος); to sit down; figuratively, to remain, reside:--dwell, sit (by, down).
from κατά and ἡμέρα; quotidian:--daily.
another (active) form for καθέζομαι; to seat down, i.e. set (figuratively, appoint); intransitively, to sit (down); figuratively, to settle (hover, dwell):--continue, set, sit (down), tarry.
from κατά; and  (to send); to lower:--let down.
from κατά and ἵστημι; to place down (permanently), i.e. (figuratively) to designate, constitute, convoy:--appoint, be, conduct, make, ordain, set.
from κατά and ὅς; according to which thing, i.e. precisely as, in proportion as:--according to that, (inasmuch) as.
from κατά and ὅλος; on the whole, i.e. entirely:--at all.
from κατά; and ὁπλίζω; to equip fully with armor:--arm.
from κατά and ὁράω; to behold fully, i.e. (figuratively) distinctly apprehend:--clearly see.
from κατά; and ὅς and τὶς; according to which certain thing, i.e. as far (or inasmuch) as:--(according, forasmuch) as, because (that).
from κατά and ὡς; just (or inasmuch) as, that:--according to, (according, even) as, how, when.

apparently, a primary particle, having a copulative and sometimes also a cumulative force; and, also, even, so then, too, etc.; often used in connection (or composition) with other particles or small words:--and, also, both, but, even, for, if, or, so, that, then, therefore, when, yet.
of Chaldee origin; the dell; Caiaphas (i.e. Cajepha), an Israelite:--Caiaphas.
from καί and γέ; and at least (or even, indeed):--and, at least.
of Hebrew origin (קַיִן); Cain, (i.e. Cajin), the son of Adam:--Cain.
of Hebrew origin (קֵינָן); Cainan (i.e. Kenan), the name of two patriarchs:--Cainan.
of uncertain affinity; new (especially in freshness; while νέος is properly so with respect to age:--new.
from καινός; renewal (figuratively):--newness.
from καί and περ; and indeed, i.e. nevertheless or notwithstanding:--and yet, although.
of uncertain affinity; an occasion, i.e. set or proper time:--X always, opportunity, (convenient, due) season, (due, short, while) time, a while. Compare χρόνος.
of Latin origin; Cæsar, a title of the Roman emperor:--Cæsar.
from Καῖσαρ; Cæsaria, the name of two places in Palestine:--Cæsarea.
from καί and τοί; and yet, i.e. nevertheless:--although.
from καίτοι and γέ; and yet indeed, i.e. although really:--nevertheless, though.
apparently a primary verb; to set on fire, i.e. kindle or (by implication) consume:--burn, light.
from καί and ἐκεῖ; likewise in that place:--and there, there (thither) also.
from καί and ἐκεῖθεν; likewise from that place (or time):--and afterward (from) (thence), thence also.
from καί and ἐκεῖνος; likewise that (or those):--and him (other, them), even he, him also, them (also), (and) they.
from κακός; badness, i.e. (subjectively) depravity, or (actively) malignity, or (passively) trouble:--evil, malice(-iousness), naughtiness, wickedness.
from a compound of κακός and ἦθος; bad character, i.e. (specially) mischievousness:--malignity.
from a compound of κακός and λόγος; to revile:--curse, speak evil of.
from a compound of ἡμιώριον and πάθος; hardship:--suffering affliction.
from the same as κακοπάθεια; to undergo hardship:--be afflicted, endure afflictions (hardness), suffer trouble.
from κακοποιός; to be a bad-doer, i.e. (objectively) to injure, or (genitive) to sin:--do(ing) evil.
from κακός and ποιέω; a bad-doer; (specially), a criminal:--evil-doer, malefactor.

apparently a primary word; worthless (intrinsically, such; whereas πονηρός properly refers to effects), i.e. (subjectively) depraved, or (objectively) injurious:--bad, evil, harm, ill, noisome, wicked.
from κακός and the base of ἔργον; a wrong-doer, i.e. criminal:--evil-doer, malefactor.
from a presumed compound of κακός and ἔχω; to maltreat:--which suffer adversity, torment.
from κακός; to injure; figuratively, to exasperate:--make evil affected, entreat evil, harm, hurt, vex.
from κακός; badly (physically or morally):--amiss, diseased, evil, grievously, miserably, sick, sore.
from κακόω; maltreatment:--affliction.
feminine of κάλαμος; a stalk of grain, i.e. (collectively) stubble:--stubble.
of uncertain affinity; a reed (the plant or its stem, or that of a similar plant); by implication, a pen:--pen, reed.
akin to the base of κελεύω; to "call" (properly, aloud, but used in a variety of applications, directly or otherwise):--bid, call (forth), (whose, whose sur-)name (was (called)).
from the base of καλλίον and ἐλαία; a cultivated olive tree, i.e. a domesticated or improved one:--good olive tree.
neuter of the (irregular) comparative of καλός; (adverbially) better than many:--very well.
from καλός and διδάσκαλος; a teacher of the right:--teacher of good things.
plural of καλός and λιμήν; Good Harbors, i.e. Fairhaven, a bay of Crete:--fair havens.
from καλός and ποιέω; to do well, i.e. live virtuously:--well doing.

of uncertain affinity; properly, beautiful, but chiefly (figuratively) good (literally or morally), i.e. valuable or virtuous (for appearance or use, and thus distinguished from ἀγαθός, which is properly intrinsic):--X better, fair, good(-ly), honest, meet, well, worthy.
from καλύπτω; a cover, i.e. veil:--vail.
akin to κλέπτω and κρύπτω; to cover up (literally or figuratively):--cover, hide.
adverb from καλός; well (usually morally):--(in a) good (place), honestly, + recover, (full) well.
of Hebrew origin (גָּמָל); a "camel":--camel.
probably from καίω; a furnace:--furnace.
from a compound of κατά and the base of μυστήριον; to shut down, i.e. close the eyes:--close.
apparently a primary verb; properly, to toil, i.e. (by implication) to tire (figuratively, faint, sicken):--faint, sick, be wearied.
apparently a primary verb; to bend:--bow.
from καί and ἐάν; and (or even) if:--and (also) if (so much as), if but, at the least, though, yet.
of Hebrew origin (compare קָנָה); Cana, a place in Palestine:--Cana.
of Chaldee origin (compare קַנָּא); zealous; Cananites, an epithet:--Canaanite (by mistake for a derivative from Χαναάν).
of foreign origin; Candacè, an Egyptian queen:--Candace.
from  (a straight reed, i.e. rod); a rule ("canon"), i.e. (figuratively) a standard (of faith and practice); by implication, a boundary, i.e. (figuratively) a sphere (of activity):--line, rule.
of Hebrew origin (probably כָּפָר and נַחוּם); Capernaum (i.e. Caphanachum), a place in Palestine:--Capernaum.
from  (a huckster); to retail, i.e. (by implication) to adulterate (figuratively):--corrupt.
of uncertain affinity; smoke:--smoke.
of foreign origin; Cappadocia, a region of Asia Minor:--Cappadocia.
prolonged from a primary  (Latin cor, "heart"); the heart, i.e. (figuratively) the thoughts or feelings (mind); also (by analogy) the middle:--(+ broken-)heart(-ed).
from καρδία and γινώσκω; a heart-knower:--which knowest the hearts.
probably from the base of ἁρπάζω; fruit (as plucked), literally or figuratively:--fruit.
perhaps for καρπός; Carpus, probably a Christian:--Carpus.
from καρποφόρος; to be fertile (literally or figuratively):--be (bear, bring forth) fruit(-ful).
from καρπός and φέρω; fruitbearing (figuratively):--fruitful.
from a derivative of κράτος (transposed); to be strong, i.e. (figuratively) steadfast (patient):--endure.
from  (to wither); a dry twig or straw:--mote.

a primary particle; (prepositionally) down (in place or time), in varied relations (according to the case (genitive, dative or accusative) with which it is joined):--about, according as (to), after, against, (when they were) X alone, among, and, X apart, (even, like) as (concerning, pertaining to touching), X aside, at, before, beyond, by, to the charge of, (charita-)bly, concerning, + covered, (dai-)ly, down, every, (+ far more) exceeding, X more excellent, for, from … to, godly, in(-asmuch, divers, every, -to, respect of), … by, after the manner of, + by any means, beyond (out of) measure, X mightily, more, X natural, of (up-)on (X part), out (of every), over against, (+ your) X own, + particularly, so, through(-oughout, -oughout every), thus, (un-)to(-gether, -ward), X uttermost, where(-by), with. In composition it retains many of these applications, and frequently denotes opposition, distribution, or intensity.
from κατά and the base of βάσις; to descend (literally or figuratively):--come (get, go, step) down, fall (down).
from κατά and βάλλω; to throw down:--cast down, lay.
from κατά and βαρέω; to impose upon:--burden.
from καταβαίνω; a declivity:--descent.
from κατά and a derivative of the base of βάσις; to cause to go down, i.e. precipitate:--bring (thrust) down.
from καταβάλλω; a deposition, i.e. founding; figuratively, conception:--conceive, foundation.
from κατά and βραβεύω (in its original sense); to award the price against, i.e. (figuratively) to defraud (of salvation):--beguile of reward.
from καταγγέλλω; a proclaimer:--setter forth.
from κατά and the base of ἄγγελος; to proclaim, promulgate:--declare, preach, shew, speak of, teach.
from κατά and γινώσκω; to note against, i.e. find fault with:--blame, condemn.
from κατά and the base of ῥήγνυμι; to rend in pieces, i.e. crack apart:--break.
from κατά and ἄγω; to lead down; specially, to moor a vessel:--bring (down, forth), (bring to) land, touch.
from κατά and ἀγωνίζομαι; to struggle against, i.e. (by implication) to overcome:--subdue.
from κατά and δέω; to tie down, i.e. bandage (a wound):--bind up.
from κατά intensive and δῆλος; manifest:--far more evident.
from κατά and a derivative of δίκη; to adjudge against, i.e. pronounce guilty:--condemn.
from κατά and διώκω; to hunt down, i.e. search for:--follow after.
from κατά and δουλόω; to enslave utterly:--bring into bondage.
from κατά and a derivative of δυνάστης; to exercise dominion against, i.e. oppress:--oppress.
from κατά and αἰσχύνομαι; to shame down, i.e. disgrace or (by implication) put to the blush:--confound, dishonour, (be a-, make a-)shame(-d).
from κατά and καίω; to burn down (to the ground), i.e. consume wholly:--burn (up, utterly).
from κατά and καλύπτω; to cover wholly, i.e. veil:--cover, hide.
from κατά and καυχάομαι; to exult against (i.e. over):--boast (against), glory, rejoice against.
from κατά and κεῖμαι; to lie down, i.e. (by implication) be sick; specially, to recline at a meal:--keep, lie, sit at meat (down).
from κατά and κλάω; to break down, i.e. divide:--break.
from κατά and κλείω; to shut down (in a dungeon), i.e. incarcerate:--shut up.
from κατά and a derivative of a compound of κλῆρος and δίδωμι; to be a giver of lots to each, i.e. (by implication) to apportion an estate:--divide by lot.
from κατά and κλίνω; to recline down, i.e. (specially) to take a place at table:--(make) sit down (at meat).
from κατά and the base of κλύδων; to dash (wash) down, i.e. (by implication) to deluge:--overflow.
from κατακλύζω; an inundation:--flood.
from κατά and ἀκολουθέω; to accompany closely:--follow (after).
from κατά and κόπτω; to chop down, i.e. mangle:--cut.
from κατά and a derivative of κρημνός; to precipitate down:--cast down headlong.
from κατακρίνω; an adverse sentence (the verdict):--condemnation.
from κατά and κρίνω; to judge against, i.e. sentence:--condemn, damn.
from κατακρίνω; sentencing adversely (the act):--condemn(-ation).
from κατά and κυριεύω; to lord against, i.e. control, subjugate:--exercise dominion over (lordship), be lord over, overcome.
from κατάλαλος; to be a traducer, i.e. to slander:--speak against (evil of).
from κατάλαλος; defamation:--backbiting, evil speaking.
from κατά and the base of λαλέω; talkative against, i.e. a slanderer:--backbiter.
from κατά and λαμβάνω; to take eagerly, i.e. seize, possess, etc. (literally or figuratively):--apprehend, attain, come upon, comprehend, find, obtain, perceive, (over-)take.
from κατά and λέγω (in its original meaning); to lay down, i.e. (figuratively) to enrol:--take into the number.
from καταλείπω; a remainder, i.e. (by implication) a few:--remnant.
from κατά and λείπω; to leave down, i.e. behind; by implication, to abandon, have remaining:--forsake, leave, reserve.
from κατά and λιθάζω; to stone down, i.e. to death:--stone.
from καταλλάσσω; exchange (figuratively, adjustment), i.e. restoration to (the divine) favor:--atonement, reconciliation(-ing).
from κατά and ἀλλάσσω; to change mutually, i.e. (figuratively) to compound a difference:--reconcile.
from κατά and λοιποί; left down (behind), i.e remaining (plural the rest):--residue.
from καταλύω; properly, a dissolution (breaking up of a journey), i.e. (by implication) a lodging-place:-- guestchamber, inn.

from κατά and λύω; to loosen down (disintegrate), i.e. (by implication) to demolish (literally or figuratively); specially (compare κατάλυμα) to halt for the night:--destroy, dissolve, be guest, lodge, come to nought, overthrow, throw down.
from κατά and μανθάνω; to learn thoroughly, i.e. (by implication) to note carefully:--consider.
from κατά and μαρτυρέω; to testify against:--witness against.
from κατά and μένω; to stay fully, i.e. reside:--abide.
from κατά and accusative case plural feminine of μόνος (with χώρα implied); according to sole places, i.e. (adverbially) separately:--alone.
from κατά (intensive) and ἀνάθεμα; an imprecation:--curse.
from κατά (intensive) and ἀναθεματίζω; to imprecate:--curse.
from κατά and ἀναλίσκω; to consume utterly:--consume.
from κατά and  (to be numb); to grow utterly torpid, i.e. (by implication) slothful (figuratively, expensive):--be burdensome (chargeable).
from κατά and νεύω; to nod down (towards), i.e. (by analogy) to make signs to:--beckon.
from κατά and νοιέω; to observe fully:--behold, consider, discover, perceive.
from κατά and a derivative of ἀντί; to meet against, i.e. arrive at (literally or figuratively):--attain, come.
from κατανύσσω; a prickling (sensation, as of the limbs asleep), i.e. (by implication, (perhaps by some confusion with νεύω or even with νύξ)) stupor (lethargy):--slumber.
from κατά and νύσσω; to pierce thoroughly, i.e. (figuratively) to agitate violently ("sting to the quick"):--prick.
from κατά and ἀξιόω; to deem entirely deserving:--(ac-)count worthy.
from κατά and πατέω; to trample down; figuratively, to reject with disdain:--trample, tread (down, underfoot).
from καταπαύω; reposing down, i.e. (by Hebraism) abode:--rest.
from κατά and παύω; to settle down, i.e. (literally) to colonize, or (figuratively) to (cause to) desist:--cease, (give) rest(-rain).
from a compound of κατά and a congener of πέτομαι; something spread thoroughly, i.e. (specially) the door screen (to the Most Holy Place) in the Jewish Temple:--vail.
from κατά and πίνω; to drink down, i.e. gulp entire (literally or figuratively):--devour, drown, swallow (up).
from κατά and πίπτω; to fall down:--fall (down).
from κατά and πλέω; to sail down upon a place, i.e. to land at:--arrive.
from κατά and a derivative of πόνος; to labor down, i.e. wear with toil (figuratively, harass):--oppress, vex.
from κατά and a derivative of the same as Πόντος; to plunge down, i.e. submerge:--drown, sink.
from κατά (intensive) and ἀρά; imprecation, execration:--curse(-d, ing).
middle voice from κατάρα; to execrate; by analogy, to doom:--curse.

from κατά and ἀργέω; to be (render) entirely idle (useless), literally or figuratively:--abolish, cease, cumber, deliver, destroy, do away, become (make) of no (none, without) effect, fail, loose, bring (come) to nought, put away (down), vanish away, make void.
from κατά and ἀριθμέω; to reckon among:--number with.
from κατά and a derivative of ἄρτιος; to complete thoroughly, i.e. repair (literally or figuratively) or adjust:--fit, frame, mend, (make) perfect(-ly join together), prepare, restore.
from καταρτίζω; thorough equipment (subjectively):--perfection.
from καταρτίζω; complete furnishing (objectively):--perfecting.
from κατά and σείω; to sway downward, i.e. make a signal:--beckon.
from κατά and σκάπτω; to undermine, i.e. (by implication) destroy:--dig down, ruin.

from κατά and a derivative of σκεῦος; to prepare thoroughly (properly, by external equipment; whereas ἑτοιμάζω refers rather to internal fitness); by implication, to construct, create:--build, make, ordain, prepare.
from κατά and σκηνόω; to camp down, i.e. haunt; figuratively, to remain:--lodge, rest.
from κατασκηνόω; an encamping, i.e. (figuratively) a perch:--nest.
from κατά and a derivative of σκιά; to overshade, i.e. cover:--shadow.
from κατάσκοπος; to be a sentinel, i.e. to inspect insidiously:--spy out.
from κατά (intensive) and σκοπός (in the sense of a watcher); a reconnoiterer:--spy.
middle voice from κατά and σοφίζω; to be crafty against, i.e. circumvent:--deal subtilly with.
from κατά and στέλλω; to put down, i.e. quell:--appease, quiet.
from καθίστημι; properly, a position or condition, i.e. (subjectively) demeanor:--behaviour.
from καταστέλλω; a deposit, i.e. (specially) costume:--apparel.
from κατά and στρέφω; to turn upside down, i.e. upset:--overthrow.
from κατά and στρηνιάω; to become voluptuous against:--begin to wax wanton against.
from καταστρέφω; an overturn ("catastrophe"), i.e. demolition; figuratively, apostasy:--overthrow, subverting.
from κατά and στρώννυμι; to strew down, i.e. (by implication) to prostrate (slay):--overthrow.
from κατά and σύρω; to drag down, i.e. arrest judicially:--hale.
from κατά and σφάζω; to kill down, i.e. slaughter:--slay.
from κατά and σφραγίζω; to seal closely:--seal.
from κατέχω; a holding down, i.e. occupancy:--possession.
from κατά and τίθημι; to place down, i.e. deposit (literally or figuratively):--do, lay, shew.
from a compound of κατά and  (to cut); a cutting down (off), i.e. mutilation (ironically):--concision. Compare ἀποκόπτω.
from κατά and a derivative of τόξον; to shoot down with an arrow or other missile:--thrust through.
from κατά and τρέχω; to run down, i.e. hasten from a tower:--run down.
from κατά and φέρω (including its alternate); to bear down, i.e. (figuratively) overcome (with drowsiness); specially, to cast a vote:--fall, give, sink down.
from κατά and φεύγω; to flee down (away):--flee.
from κατά and φθείρω; to spoil entirely, i.e. (literally) to destroy; or (figuratively) to deprave; --corrupt, utterly perish.
from 2596 and 5368; to kiss earnestly:--kiss.
from κατά and φρονέω; to think against, i.e. disesteem:--despise.
from καταφρονέω; a contemner:--despiser.
from κατά and cheo (to pour); to pour down (out):--pour.
from κατά and  (the ground); subterranean, i.e. infernal (belonging to the world of departed spirits):--under the earth.
from κατά and χράομαι; to overuse, i.e. misuse:--abuse.
from κατά and ψύχω; to cool down (off), i.e. refresh:--cool.
from κατά (intensively) and εἴδωλον; utterly idolatrous:--wholly given to idolatry.
from κατά and ἔναντι; directly opposite:--before, over against.
from κατά and ἐνώπιον; directly in front of:--before (the presence of), in the sight of.
from κατά and ἐξουσιάζω; to have (wield) full privilege over:--exercise authority.
from κατά and ἐργάζομαι; to work fully, i.e. accomplish; by implication, to finish, fashion:--cause, to (deed), perform, work (out).
from κατά and ἔρχομαι (including its alternate); to come (or go) down (literally or figuratively):--come (down), depart, descend, go down, land.
from κατά and ἐσθίω (including its alternate); to eat down, i.e. devour (literally or figuratively):--devour.
from κατά and εὐθύνω; to straighten fully, i.e. (figuratively) direct:--guide, direct.
from κατά and ἐφίστημι; to stand over against, i.e. rush upon (assault):--make insurrection against.
from κατά and ἔχω; to hold down (fast), in various applications (literally or figuratively):--have, hold (fast), keep (in memory), let, X make toward, possess, retain, seize on, stay, take, withhold.
from κατήγορος; to be a plaintiff, i.e. to charge with some offence:--accuse, object.
from κατήγορος; a complaint ("category"), i.e. criminal charge:--accusation (X -ed).
from κατά and ἀγορά; against one in the assembly, i.e. a complainant at law; specially, Satan:--accuser.
from a compound of κατά and perhaps a derivative of the base of φαίνω (meaning downcast in look); demureness, i.e. (by implication) sadness:--heaviness.
from κατά and ἦχος; to sound down into the ears, i.e. (by implication) to indoctrinate ("catechize") or (genitive case) to apprise of:--inform, instruct, teach.
from κατά and a derivative of ἰός; to rust down, i.e. corrode:--canker.
from κατά and ἰσχύω; to overpower:--prevail (against).
from κατά and οἰκέω; to house permanently, i.e. reside (literally or figuratively):--dwell(-er), inhabitant(-ter).
from κατοικέω; residence (properly, the act; but by implication, concretely, the mansion):--dwelling.
from a derivative of κατοικέω; a dwelling-place:--habitation.
middle voice from a compound of κατά and a derivative of ὀπτάνομαι (compare ἔσοπτρον); to mirror oneself, i.e. to see reflected (figuratively):--behold as in a glass.
from a compound of κατά and a derivative of ὀρθός (compare διόρθωσις); something made fully upright, i.e. (figuratively) rectification (specially, good public administration):--very worthy deed.
(compare κατώτερος); adverb from κατά; downwards:--beneath, bottom, down, under.
comparative from κάτω; inferior (locally, of Hades):--lower.
from καίω; properly, a burn (concretely), but used (abstractly) of a glow:--heat.
from καῦμα; to burn:--scorch.
from καίω; burning (the act):--be burned.
from καῦσις; to set on fire:--fervent heat.
from καυσόω; a glare:--(burning) heat.
from a derivative of καίω; to brand ("cauterize"), i.e. (by implication) to render unsensitive (figuratively):--sear with a hot iron.
from some (obsolete) base akin to that of  (to boast) and εὔχομαι; to vaunt (in a good or a bad sense):--(make) boast, glory, joy, rejoice.
from καυχάομαι; a boast (properly, the object; by implication, the act) in a good or a bad sense:--boasting, (whereof) to glory (of), glorying, rejoice(-ing).
from καυχάομαι; boasting (properly, the act; by implication, the object), in a good or a bad sense:--boasting, whereof I may glory, glorying, rejoicing.
probably from kegchros (millet); Cenchreæ, a port of Corinth:--Cencrea.
of Hebrew origin (קִדְרוֹן); Cedron (i.e. Kidron), a brook near Jerusalem:--Cedron.
middle voice of a primary verb; to lie outstretched (literally or figuratively):--be (appointed, laid up, made, set), lay, lie. Compare τίθημι.
of uncertain affinity; a swathe, i.e. winding-sheet:--graveclothes.
a primary verb; to shear:--shear(-er).
from κελεύω; a cry of incitement:--shout.
from a primary  (to urge on); "hail"; to incite by word, i.e. order:--bid, (at, give) command(-ment).
from κενόδοξος; empty glorying, i.e. self-conceit:--vain-glory.
from κενός and δόξα; vainly glorifying, i.e. self-conceited:--desirous of vain-glory.
apparently a primary word; empty (literally or figuratively):--empty, (in) vain.
from a presumed compound of κενός and φωνή; empty sounding, i.e. fruitless discussion:--vain.
from κενός; to make empty, i.e. (figuratively) to abase, neutralize, falsify:--make (of none effect, of no reputation, void), be in vain.
from  (to prick); a point ("centre"), i.e. a sting (figuratively, poison) or goad (figuratively, divine impulse):--prick, sting.
of Latin origin; a centurion, i.e. captain of one hundred soldiers:--centurion.
adverb from κενός; vainly, i.e. to no purpose:--in vain.
feminine of a presumed derivative of the base of κέρας; something horn-like, i.e. (specially) the apex of a Hebrew letter (figuratively, the least particle):--tittle.
from κέραμος; a potter:--potter.
from κέραμος; made of clay, i.e. earthen:--of a potter.
neuter of a presumed derivative of κέραμος; an earthenware vessel, i.e. jar:--pitcher.
probably from the base of κεράννυμι (through the idea of mixing clay and water); earthenware, i.e. a tile (by analogy, a thin roof or awning):--tiling.
prolonged form of a more primary   (which is used in certain tenses); to mingle, i.e. (by implication) to pour out (for drinking):--fill, pour out. Compare μίγνυμι.
from a primary  (the hair of the head); a horn (literally or figuratively):--horn.
neuter of a presumed derivative of κέρας; something horned, i.e. (specially) the pod of the carob-tree:--husk.
from κέρδος; to gain (literally or figuratively):--(get) gain, win.
of uncertain affinity; gain (pecuniary or genitive case):--gain, lucre.
from κείρω; a clipping (bit), i.e. (specially) a coin:--money.
from a derivative of κέρμα; a handler of coins, i.e. money-broker:--changer of money.
neuter of a derivative of κεφαλή; a principal thing, i.e. main point; specially, an amount (of money):--sum.
from the same as κεφάλαιον; (specially) to strike on the head:--wound in the head.
from the primary  (in the sense of seizing); the head (as the part most readily taken hold of), literally or figuratively:--head.
from κεφαλή; properly, a knob, i.e. (by implication) a roll (by extension from the end of a stick on which the manuscript was rolled):--volume.
of Latin origin; properly, an enrollment ("census"), i.e. (by implication) a tax:--tribute.
of uncertain affinity; a garden:--garden.
from κῆπος and  (a warden); a garden-keeper, i.e. gardener:--gardener.
diminutive from  (wax); a cell for honey, i.e. (collectively) the comb:--(honey-)comb.
from κηρύσσω; a proclamation (especially of the gospel; by implication, the gospel itself):--preaching.
from κηρύσσω; a herald, i.e. of divine truth (especially of the gospel):--preacher.
of uncertain affinity; to herald (as a public crier), especially divine truth (the gospel):--preacher(-er), proclaim, publish.
probably from the base of χάσμα; a huge fish (as gaping for prey):--whale.
of Chaldee origin (compare כֵּף); the Rock; Cephas (i.e. Kepha), a surname of Peter:--Cephas.
of uncertain derivation; a box, i.e. the sacred ark and that of Noah:--ark.
of uncertain affinity; a lyre:--harp.
from κιθάρα; to play on a lyre:--harp.
from κιθάρα and a derivative of the same as ᾠδή; a lyre-singer(-player), i.e. harpist:--harper.
probably of foreign origin; Cilicia, a region of Asia Minor:--Cilicia.
of foreign origin (compare קִנָּמוֹן); cinnamon:--cinnamon.
from κίνδυνος; to undergo peril:--be in danger, be (stand) in jeopardy.
of uncertain derivation; danger:--peril.
from  (poetic for , to go); to stir (transitively), literally or figuratively:--(re-)move(-r), way.
from κινέω; a stirring:--moving.
of Hebrew origin (קִישׁ); Cis (i.e. Kish), an Israelite:--Cis.
from κλάω; a twig or bough (as if broken off):--branch.
of uncertain affinity; to sob, i.e. wail aloud (whereas 1145 is rather to cry silently):--bewail, weep.
from κλάω; fracture (the act):--breaking.
from κλάω; a piece (bit):--broken, fragment.
of uncertain derivation; Claude, an island near Crete:--Clauda.
feminine of Κλαύδιος; Claudia, a Christian woman:--Claudia.
of Latin origin; Claudius, the name of two Romans:--Claudius.
from κλαίω; lamentation:--wailing, weeping, X wept.
a primary verb; to break (specially, of bread):--break.
from κλείω; a key (as shutting a lock), literally or figuratively:--key.
a primary verb; to close (literally or figuratively):--shut (up).
from κλέπτω; stealing (properly, the thing stolen, but used of the act):--theft.
probably contracted from  (compound of κλέος and πατήρ); Cleopas, a Christian:--Cleopas.
from a shorter form of καλέω; renown (as if being called):--glory.
from κλέπτω; a stealer (literally or figuratively):--thief. Compare λῃστής.
a primary verb; to filch:--steal.
from κλάω; a limb or shoot (as if broken off):--branch.
of Latin origin; merciful; Clemes (i.e. Clemens), a Christian:--Clement.
from κληρονόμος; to be an heir to (literally or figuratively):--be heir, (obtain by) inherit(-ance).
from κληρονόμος; heirship, i.e. (concretely) a patrimony or (genitive case) a possession:--inheritance.

from κλῆρος and the base of νόμος (in its original sense of partitioning, i.e. (reflexively) getting by apportionment); a sharer by lot, i.e. inheritor (literally or figuratively); by implication, a possessor:--heir.

probably from κλάω (through the idea of using bits of wood, etc., for the purpose; a die (for drawing chances); by implication, a portion (as if so secured); by extension, an acquisition (especially a patrimony, figuratively):--heritage, inheritance, lot, part.
from κλῆρος; to allot, i.e. (figuratively) to assign (a privilege):--obtain an inheritance.
from a shorter form of καλέω; an invitation (figuratively):--calling.
from the same as κλῆσις; invited, i.e. appointed, or (specially), a saint:--called.
of uncertain derivation; an earthen pot used for baking in:--oven.
from κλίνω; a slope, i.e. (specially) a "clime" or tract of country:--part, region.
from κλίνω; a couch (for sleep, sickness, sitting or eating):--bed, table.
neuter of a presumed derivative of κλίνη; a pallet or little couch:--bed.
a primary verb; to slant or slope, i.e. incline or recline (literally or figuratively):--bow (down), be far spent, lay, turn to flight, wear away.
from a derivative of κλίνω; properly, reclination, i.e. (concretely and specially), a party at a meal:--company.
from κλέπτω; stealing:--theft.
from  (to billow or dash over); a surge of the sea (literally or figuratively):--raging, wave.
middle voice from κλύδων; to surge, i.e. (figuratively) to fluctuate:--toss to and fro.
of Chaldee origin (corresponding to אַחְאָב); Clopas, an Israelite:--Cleophas.
from a primary  (to scrape); to scratch, i.e. (by implication) to tickle:--X itching.
probably of foreign origin; Cnidus, a place in Asia Minor:--Cnidus.
of Latin origin; a quadrans, i.e. the fourth part of an as:--farthing.
from  ("hollow"); a cavity, i.e. (especially) the abdomen; by implication, the matrix; figuratively, the heart:--belly, womb.
from κεῖμαι; to put to sleep, i.e. (passively or reflexively) to slumber; figuratively, to decease:--(be a-, fall a-, fall on) sleep, be dead.
from κοιμάω; sleeping, i.e. (by implication) repose:--taking of rest.
probably from σύν; common, i.e. (literally) shared by all or several, or (ceremonially) profane:--common, defiled, unclean, unholy.
from κοινός; to make (or consider) profane (ceremonially):--call common, defile, pollute, unclean.
from κοινωνός; to share with others (objectively or subjectively):--communicate, distribute, be partaker.
from κοινωνός; partnership, i.e. (literally) participation, or (social) intercourse, or (pecuniary) benefaction:--(to) communicate(-ation), communion, (contri-)distribution, fellowship.
from κοινωνός; communicative, i.e. (pecuniarily) liberal:--willing to communicate.
from κοινός; a sharer, i.e. associate:--companion, X fellowship, partaker, partner.
from κεῖμαι; a couch; by extension, cohabitation; by implication, the male sperm:--bed, chambering, X conceive.
from κοίτη; a bedroom:--+ chamberlain.
from κόκκος (from the kernel-shape of the insect); crimson-colored:--scarlet (colour, coloured).
apparently a primary word; a kernel of seed:--corn, grain.
from  (dwarf); properly, to curtail, i.e. (figuratively) to chastise (or reserve for infliction):--punish.
from a derivative of  (a fawner); flattery:-- X flattering.
from κολάζω; penal infliction:--punishment, torment.
from a derivative of the base of κολάζω; to rap with the fist:--buffet.
from  ("glue"); to glue, i.e. (passively or reflexively) to stick (figuratively):--cleave, join (self), keep company.
neuter of a presumed derivative of  (a cake; prob akin to the base of κολλάω); properly, a poultice (as made of or in the form of crackers), i.e. (by analogy) a plaster:-- eyesalve.
from a presumed derivative of  (a small coin; probably akin to κολλούριον); a coin-dealer:--(money-)changer.
from a derivative of the base of κολάζω; to dock, i.e. (figuratively) abridge:--shorten.
apparently feminine plural of kolossos ("colossal"); Colossæ, a place in Asia Minor:--Colosse.
