from Κολοσσαί; a Colossæan, (i.e. inhabitant of Colossæ:--Colossian.
apparently a primary word; the bosom; by analogy, a bay:--bosom, creek.
from  (a diver); to plunge into water:--swim.
from κολυμβάω; a diving-place, i.e. pond for bathing (or swimming):--pool.
of Latin origin; a Roman "colony" for veterans:--colony.
from κόμη; to wear tresses of hair:--have long hair.
apparently from the same as κομίζω; the hair of the head (locks, as ornamental, and thus differing from θρίξ; which properly denotes merely the scalp):--hair.
from a primary  (to tend, i.e. take care of); properly, to provide for, i.e. (by implication) to carry off (as if from harm; genitive case obtain):--bring, receive.
neuter comparative of a derivative of the base of 2865 (meaning, properly, well dressed, i.e. nice); figuratively, convalescent:--+ began to amend.
from  (dust; by analogy, lime); to whitewash:--whiten.
from the base of κονιάω and ornumi (to "rouse"); pulverulence (as blown about):--dust.
from κόπος; to tire, i.e. (figuratively) to relax:--cease.
from κόπτω; mourning (properly, by beating the breast):--lamentation.
from κόπτω; cutting, i.e. carnage:--slaughter.
from a derivative of κόπος; to feel fatigue; by implication, to work hard:--(bestow) labour, toil, be wearied.
from κόπτω; a cut, i.e. (by analogy) toil (as reducing the strength), literally or figuratively; by implication, pains:--labour, + trouble, weariness.
from  (ordure; perhaps akin to κόπτω); manure:--dung(-hill).
a primary verb; to "chop"; specially, to beat the breast in grief:--cut down, lament, mourn, (be-)wail. Compare the base of τομώτερος.
perhaps from κορέννυμι; a crow (from its voracity):--raven.
neuter of a presumed derivative of  (a maiden); a (little) girl:--damsel, maid.

of Hebrew and Chaldee origin respectively (קׇרְבָּן); a votive offering and the offering; a consecrated present (to the Temple fund); by extension (the latter term) the Treasury itself, i.e. the room where the contribution boxes stood:--Corban, treasury.
of Hebrew origin (קֹרַח); Core (i.e. Korach), an Israelite:--Core.
a primary verb; to cram, i.e. glut or sate:--eat enough, full.
from Κόρινθος; a Corinthian, i.e. inhabitant of Corinth:--Corinthian.
of uncertain derivation; Corinthus, a city of Greece:--Corinth.
of Latin origin; Cornelius, a Roman:--Cornelius.
of Hebrew origin (כֹּר); a cor, i.e. a specific measure:--measure.
from κόσμος; to put in proper order, i.e. decorate (literally or figuratively); specially, to snuff (a wick):--adorn, garnish, trim.
from κόσμος (in its secondary sense); terrene ("cosmic"), literally (mundane) or figuratively (corrupt):--worldly.
from κόσμος (in its primary sense); orderly, i.e. decorous:--of good behaviour, modest.
from κόσμος and κρατέω; a world-ruler, an epithet of Satan:--ruler.

probably from the base of κομίζω; orderly arrangement, i.e. decoration; by implication, the world (in a wide or narrow sense, including its inhabitants, literally or figuratively (morally)):--adorning, world.
of Latin origin (fourth); Quartus, a Christian:--Quartus.
of Chaldee origin (קוּם); cumi (i.e. rise!):--cumi.
of Latin origin; "custody", i.e. a Roman sentry:--watch.
from  (light in weight); to unload:--lighten.
of uncertain derivation; a (small) basket:--basket.
probably of foreign origin; a mattress:--bed.
a primary verb; properly, to "croak" (as a raven) or scream, i.e. (genitive case) to call aloud (shriek, exclaim, intreat):--cry (out).
probably from the same as ἁρπάζω; properly, a headache (as a seizure of pain) from drunkenness, i.e. (by implication) a debauch (by analogy, a glut):--surfeiting.
diminutive of a derivative of the base of κέρας; a skull ("cranium"):--Calvary, skull.
of uncertain derivation; a margin, i.e. (specially), a fringe or tassel:--border, hem.
from κράτος; powerful:--mighty.
from κραταιός; to empower, i.e. (passively) increase in vigor:--be strengthened, be (wax) strong.
from κράτος; to use strength, i.e. seize or retain (literally or figuratively):--hold (by, fast), keep, lay hand (hold) on, obtain, retain, take (by).
superlative of a derivative of κράτος; strongest, i.e. (in dignity) very honorable:--most excellent (noble).
perhaps a primary word; vigor ("great") (literally or figuratively):--dominion, might(-ily), power, strength.
from κραυγή; to clamor:--cry out.
from κράζω; an outcry (in notification, tumult or grief):--clamour, cry(-ing).
perhaps a primary word; (butcher's) meat:--flesh.
neuter of an alternate form of κρείττων; (as noun) better, i.e. greater advantage:--better.
comparative of a derivative of κράτος; stronger, i.e. (figuratively) better, i.e. nobler:--best, better.
a prolonged form of a primary verb; to hang:--hang.
from κρεμάννυμι; overhanging, i.e. a precipice:--steep place.
from Κρήτη; a Cretan, i.e. inhabitant of Crete:--Crete, Cretian.
of Latin origin; growing; Cresces (i.e. Crescens), a Christian:--Crescens.
of uncertain derivation; Crete, an island in the Mediterranean:--Crete.
of uncertain derivation; barley:--barley.
from κριθή; consisting of barley:--barley.
from κρίνω; a decision (the function or the effect, for or against ("crime")):--avenge, condemned, condemnation, damnation, + go to law, judgment.
perhaps a prim word; a lily:--lily.

properly, to distinguish, i.e. decide (mentally or judicially); by implication, to try, condemn, punish:--avenge, conclude, condemn, damn, decree, determine, esteem, judge, go to (sue at the) law, ordain, call in question, sentence to, think.
of Latin origin; "crisp"; Crispus, a Corinthian:--Crispus.
neuter of a presumed derivative of κριτής; a rule of judging ("criterion"), i.e. (by implication) a tribunal:--to judge, judgment (seat).
from κρίνω; a judge (genitive case or specially):--judge.
from κριτής; decisive ("critical"), i.e. discriminative:--discerner.
apparently a primary verb; to rap:--knock.
feminine of κρυπτός; a hidden place, i.e. cellar ("crypt"):--secret.
from κρύπτω; concealed, i.e. private:--hid(-den), inward(-ly), secret.
a primary verb; to conceal (properly, by covering):--hide (self), keep secret, secret(-ly).
from κρύσταλλος; to make (i.e. intransitively, resemble) ice ("crystallize"):--be clear as crystal.
from a derivative of  (frost); ice, i.e. (by analogy) rock "crystal":--crystal.
adverb from κρύπτω; privately:--in secret.
a primary verb; to get, i.e. acquire (by any means; own):--obtain, possess, provide, purchase.
from κτάομαι; an acquirement, i.e. estate:--possession.
from κτάομαι; property, i.e. (specially) a domestic animal:--beast.
from κτάομαι; an owner:--possessor.
probably akin to κτάομαι (through the idea of proprietorship of the manufacturer); to fabricate, i.e. found (form originally):--create, Creator, make.
from κτίζω; original formation (properly, the act; by implication, the thing, literally or figuratively):--building, creation, creature, ordinance.
from κτίζω; an original formation (concretely), i.e. product (created thing):--creature.
from κτίζω; a founder, i.e. God (as author of all things):--Creator.
from  (a "cube", i.e. die for playing); gambling, i.e. (figuratively) artifice or fraud:--sleight.
from  (of Latin origin, to steer); pilotage, i.e. (figuratively) directorship (in the church):--government.
from the same as κυβέρνησις; helmsman, i.e. (by implication) captain:--(ship) master.
adverb from the same as κύκλῳ; from the circle, i.e. all around:--(round) about.
from the same as κύκλῳ; to encircle, i.e. surround:--compass (about), come (stand) round about.
as if dative case of  (a ring, "cycle"; akin to κυλιόω); i.e. in a circle (by implication, of ἐν), i.e. (adverbially) all around:--round about.
from κυλιόω; a wallow (the effect of rolling), i.e. filth:--wallowing.
from the base of κῦμα (through the idea of circularity; compare κύκλῳ, εἱλίσσω); to roll about:--wallow.
from the same as κυλιόω; rocking about, i.e. crippled (maimed, in feet or hands):--maimed.
from  (to swell (with young), i.e. bend, curve); a billow (as bursting or toppling):--wave.
from a derivative of the base of κῦμα; a "cymbal" (as hollow):--cymbal.
of foreign origin (compare כַּמֹּן); dill or fennel ("cummin"):--cummin.
neuter of a presumed derivative of κύων; a puppy:--dog.
from Κύπρος; a Cyprian (Cypriot), i.e. inhabitant of Cyprus:--of Cyprus.
of uncertain origin; Cyprus, an island in the Mediterranean:--Cyprus.
probably from the base of κῦμα; to bend forward:--stoop (down).
from Κυρήνη; i.e. Cyrenæan, i.e. inhabitant of Cyrene:--of Cyrene, Cyrenian.
of uncertain derivation; Cyrene, a region of Africa:--Cyrene.
of Latin origin; Cyrenius (i.e. Quirinus), a Roman:--Cyrenius.
feminine of κύριος; Cyria, a Christian woman:--lady.
from κύριος; belonging to the Lord (Jehovah or Jesus):--Lord's.
from κύριος; to rule:--have dominion over, lord, be lord of, exercise lordship over.
from  (supremacy); supreme in authority, i.e. (as noun) controller; by implication, Master (as a respectful title):-- God, Lord, master, Sir.
from κύριος; mastery, i.e. (concretely and collectively) rulers:--dominion, government.
from the same as κύριος; to make authoritative, i.e. ratify:--confirm.
a primary word; a dog ("hound") (literally or figuratively):--dog.
from the base of κολάζω; a limb of the body (as if lopped):--carcase.
from the base of κολάζω; to estop, i.e. prevent (by word or act):--forbid, hinder, keep from, let, not suffer, withstand.
from κεῖμαι; a hamlet (as if laid down):--town, village.
from κώμη and πόλις; an unwalled city:--town.
from κεῖμαι; a carousal (as if letting loose):--revelling, rioting.
apparently a derivative of the base of κέντρον and a derivative of ὀπτάνομαι; a mosquito (from its stinging proboscis):--gnat.
of uncertain origin; Cos, an island in the Mediterranean:--Cos.
of Hebrew origin (compare קֶסֶם); Cosam (i.e. Kosam) an Israelite:--Cosam.
from κόπτω; blunted, i.e. (figuratively) of hearing (deaf) or speech (dumb):--deaf, dumb, speechless.
a prolonged form of a primary verb, which is only used as an alternate in certain tenses; to lot, i.e. determine (by implication, receive) especially by lot:--his lot be, cast lots, obtain.
probably of Hebrew origin (אֶלְעָזָר); Lazarus (i.e. Elazar), the name of two Israelites (one imaginary):--Lazarus.
adverb from λανθάνω; privately:--privily, secretly.
of uncertain derivation; a whirlwind (squall):--storm, tempest.
from adverb  (heelwise); to recalcitrate:--kick.
a prolonged form of an otherwise obsolete verb; to talk, i.e. utter words:--preach, say, speak (after), talk, tell, utter. Compare λέγω.
from λαλέω; talk:--saying, speech.
of Hebrew origin (מָה with prepositional prefix); lama (i.e. why):--lama.

a prolonged form of a primary verb, which is use only as an alternate in certain tenses; to take (in very many applications, literally and figuratively (properly objective or active, to get hold of; whereas δέχομαι is rather subjective or passive, to have offered to one; while αἱρέομαι is more violent, to seize or remove)):--accept, + be amazed, assay, attain, bring, X when I call, catch, come on (X unto), + forget, have, hold, obtain, receive (X after), take (away, up).
of Hebrew origin (לֶמֶךְ); Lamech (i.e. Lemek), a patriarch:--Lamech.
from λάμπω; a "lamp" or flambeau:--lamp, light, torch.
from the same as λαμπάς; radiant; by analogy, limpid; figuratively, magnificent or sumptuous (in appearance):--bright, clear, gay, goodly, gorgeous, white.
from λαμπρός; brilliancy:--brightness.
adverb from λαμπρός; brilliantly, i.e. figuratively, luxuriously:--sumptuously.
a primary verb; to beam, i.e. radiate brilliancy (literally or figuratively):--give light, shine.

a prolonged form of a primary verb, which is used only as an alternate in certain tenses; to lie hid (literally or figuratively); often used adverbially, unwittingly:--be hid, be ignorant of, unawares.
from a compound of  (a stone) and the base of ξηρός (in its original sense of scraping); rock-quarried:--hewn in stone.
apparently a primary word; a people (in general; thus differing from δῆμος, which denotes one's own populace):--people.
from a compound of λαός and δίκη; Laodicia, a place in Asia Minor:--Laodicea.
from Λαοδίκεια; a Laodicean, i.e. inhabitant of Laodicia:--Laodicean.
of uncertain derivation; the throat ("larynx"):--throat.
of uncertain origin; Lasæa, a place in Crete:--Lasea.
a strengthened form of a primary verb, which only occurs in this and another prolonged form as alternate in certain tenses; to crack open (from a fall):--burst asunder.
from the same as the first part of λαξευτός and the base of τομώτερος; to quarry:--hew.
from λατρεύω; ministration of God, i.e. worship:--(divine) service.
from  (a hired menial); to minister (to God), i.e. render religious homage:--serve, do the service, worship(-per).
from  (to dig); a vegetable:--herb.
of uncertain origin; Lebbæus, a Christian:--Lebbæus.
of Latin origin; a "legion", i.e. Roman regiment (figuratively):--legion.

a primary verb; properly, to "lay" forth, i.e. (figuratively) relate (in words (usually of systematic or set discourse; whereas ἔπω and φημί generally refer to an individual expression or speech respectively; while ῥέω is properly to break silence merely, and λαλέω means an extended or random harangue)); by implication, to mean:--ask, bid, boast, call, describe, give out, name, put forth, say(-ing, on), shew, speak, tell, utter.
from λείπω; a remainder:--remnant.
apparently a primary word; smooth, i.e. "level":--smooth.
a primary verb; to leave, i.e. (intransitively or passively) to fail or be absent:--be destitute (wanting), lack.
from λειτουργός; to be a public servant, i.e. (by analogy) to perform religious or charitable functions (worship, obey, relieve):--minister.
from λειτουργέω; public function (as priest ("liturgy") or almsgiver):--ministration(-try), service.
from the same as λειτουργέω; functional publicly ("liturgic"); i.e. beneficient:--ministering.
from a derivative of λαός and ἔργον; a public servant, i.e. a functionary in the Temple or Gospel, or (genitive case) a worshipper (of God) or benefactor (of man):--minister(-ed).
of Latin origin; a "linen" cloth, i.e. apron:--towel.
from  (to peel); a flake:--scale.
from the same as λεπίς; scaliness, i.e. "leprosy":--leprosy.
from the same as λέπρα; scaly, i.e. leprous (a leper):--leper.
neuter of a derivative of the same as λεπίς; something scaled (light), i.e. a small coin:--mite.
of Hebrew origin (לֵוִי); Levi, the name of three Israelites:--Levi. Compare Λευΐς.
a form of Λευΐ; Lewis (i.e. Levi), a Christian:--Levi.
from Λευΐ; a Levite, i.e. descendant of Levi:--Levite.
from Λευΐτης; Levitic, i.e. relating to the Levites:--Levitical.
from λευκός; to whiten:--make white, whiten.
from  ("light"); white:--white.
a primary word; a "lion":--lion.
from λανθάνω; forgetfulness:--+ forget.
apparently a primary word; a trough, i.e. wine-vat:--winepress.
apparently a primary word; twaddle, i.e. an incredible story:--idle tale.
from  (to plunder); a brigand:--robber, thief.
from λαμβάνω; receipt (the act):--receiving.
of uncertain affinity; much (adverbially):--exceeding, great(-ly), sore, very (+ chiefest).
of foreign origin (לְבוֹנָה); the incense-tree, i.e. (by implication) incense itself:--frankincense.
from λίβανος; frankincense, i.e. (by extension) a censer for burning it:--censer.
of Latin origin; a Roman freedman:--Libertine.
probably from λίψ; Libye, a region of Africa:--Libya.
from λίθος; to lapidate:--stone.
from λίθος; stony, i.e. made of stone:--of stone.
from a compound of λίθος and βάλλω; to throw stones, i.e. lapidate:--stone, cast stones.
apparently a primary word; a stone (literally or figuratively):--(mill-, stumbling-)stone.
from λίθος and a derivative of στρώννυμι; stone-strewed, i.e. a tessellated mosaic on which the Roman tribunal was placed:--Pavement.
from , the equivalent of  (a winnowing fan or basket); to winnow, i.e. (by analogy), to triturate:--grind to powder.
apparently a primary word; a harbor:--haven. Compare Καλοὶ Λιμένες.
probably from λιμήν (through the idea of nearness of shore); a pond (large or small):--lake.
probably from λείπω (through the idea of destitution); a scarcity of food:--dearth, famine, hunger.
probably a primary word; flax, i.e. (by implication) "linen":--linen.
perhaps from λίνον; Linus, a Christian:--Linus.
from  (grease); fat, i.e. (figuratively) sumptuous:--dainty.
of Latin origin (libra); a pound in weight:--pound.
probably from  (to pour a "libation"); the south(- west) wind (as bringing rain, i.e. (by extension) the south quarter):--southwest.
from λόγος (in the commercial sense); a contribution:--collection, gathering.
middle voice from λόγος; to take an inventory, i.e. estimate (literally or figuratively):--conclude, (ac-)count (of), + despise, esteem, impute, lay, number, reason, reckon, suppose, think (on).
from λόγος; rational ("logical"):--reasonable, of the word.
neuter of λόγιος; an utterance (of God):--oracle.
from λόγος; fluent, i.e. an orator:--eloquent.
from λογίζομαι; computation, i.e. (figuratively) reasoning (conscience, conceit):--imagination, thought.
from a compound of λόγος and μάχομαι; to be disputatious (on trifles):--strive about words.
from the same as λογομαχέω; disputation about trifles ("logomachy"):--strife of words.

from λέγω; something said (including the thought); by implication, a topic (subject of discourse), also reasoning (the mental faculty) or motive; by extension, a computation; specially, (with the article in John) the Divine Expression (i.e. Christ):--account, cause, communication, X concerning, doctrine, fame, X have to do, intent, matter, mouth, preaching, question, reason, + reckon, remove, say(-ing), shew, X speaker, speech, talk, thing, + none of these things move me, tidings, treatise, utterance, word, work.
perhaps a primary word; a "lance":--spear.
from λοίδορος; to reproach, i.e. vilify:--revile.
from λοίδορος; slander or vituperation:--railing, reproach(-fully).
from  (mischief); abusive, i.e. a blackguard:--railer, reviler.
of uncertain affinity; a plague (literally, the disease, or figuratively, a pest):--pestilence(-t).
masculine plural of a derivative of λείπω; remaining ones:--other, which remain, remnant, residue, rest.
neuter singular of the same as λοιποί; something remaining (adverbially):--besides, finally, furthermore, (from) henceforth, moreover, now, + it remaineth, then.
genitive case singular of the same as λοιποί; remaining time:--from henceforth.
contracted from Latin Lucanus; Lucas, a Christian:--Lucas, Luke.
of Latin origin; illuminative; Lucius, a Christian:--Lucius.
from λούω; a bath, i.e. (figuratively), baptism:--washing.
a primary verb; to bathe (the whole person; whereas νίπτω means to wet a part only, and πλύνω to wash, cleanse garments exclusively):--wash.
of Hebrew origin (לֹד); Lydda (i.e. Lod), a place in Palestine:--Lydda.
properly, feminine of Ludios (of foreign origin) (a Lydian, in Asia Minor); Lydia, a Christian woman:--Lydia.
perhaps remotely from λύκος; Lycaonia, a region of Asia Minor:--Lycaonia.
adverb from a derivative of Λυκαονία; Lycaonistically, i.e. in the language of the Lycaonians:--in the speech of Lycaonia.
probably remotely from λύκος; Lycia, a province of Asia Minor:--Lycia.
perhaps akin to the base of λευκός (from the whitish hair); a wolf:--wolf.
middle voice from a probably derivative of λύω (meaning filth); properly, to soil, i.e. (figuratively) insult (maltreat):--make havock of.
from λύπη; to distress; reflexively or passively, to be sad:--cause grief, grieve, be in heaviness, (be) sorrow(-ful), be (make) sorry.
apparently a primary word; sadness:--grief, grievous, + grudgingly, heaviness, sorrow.
from λύσις and  (trouble); grief-dispelling; Lysanias, a governor of Abilene:--Lysanias.
of uncertain affinity; Lysias, a Roman:--Lysias.
from λύω; a loosening, i.e. (specially), divorce:--to be loosed.
third person singular present indicative active of a derivative of a compound of λύσις and τέλος; impersonally, it answers the purpose, i.e. is advantageous:--it is better.
of uncertain origin; Lystra, a place in Asia Minor:--Lystra.
from λύω; something to loosen with, i.e. a redemption price (figuratively, atonement):--ransom.
from λύτρον; to ransom (literally or figuratively):--redeem.
from λυτρόω; a ransoming (figuratively):--+ redeemed, redemption.
from λυτρόω; a redeemer (figuratively):--deliverer.
from λύχνος; a lamp-stand (literally or figuratively):--candlestick.
from the base of λευκός; a portable lamp or other illuminator (literally or figuratively):--candle, light.
a primary verb; to "loosen" (literally or figuratively):--break (up), destroy, dissolve, (un-)loose, melt, put off. Compare ῥήγνυμι.
of uncertain origin; Lois, a Christian woman:--Lois.
of Hebrew origin (לוֹט); Lot, a patriarch:--Lot.
probably of Hebrew origin; Maath, an Israelite:--Maath.
of Chaldee origin (compare מִגְדָּל); the tower; Magdala (i.e. Migdala), a place in Palestine:--Magdala.
feminine of a derivative of Μαγδαλά; a female Magdalene, i.e. inhabitant of Magdala:--Magdalene.
from μαγεύω; "magic":--sorcery.
from μάγος; to practice magic:--use sorcery.
of foreign origin (רַב־מָג); a Magian, i.e. Oriental scientist; by implication, a magician:--sorcerer, wise man.
of Hebrew origin (מָגוֹג); Magog, a foreign nation, i.e. (figuratively) an Antichristian party:--Magog.
of Hebrew origin (מִדְיָן); Madian (i.e. Midian), a region of Arabia:--Madian.
from μαθητής; intransitively, to become a pupil; transitively, to disciple, i.e. enrol as scholar:--be disciple, instruct, teach.
from μανθάνω; a learner, i.e. pupil:--disciple.
feminine from μαθητής; a female pupil:--disciple.
of Hebrew origin (מְתוּשֶׁלַח); Mathusala (i.e. Methushelach), an antediluvian:--Mathusala.
probably of Hebrew origin; Mainan, an Israelite:--Mainan.
middle voice from a primary  (to long for; through the idea of insensate craving); to rave as a "maniac":--be beside self (mad).
from μακάριος; to beatify, i.e. pronounce (or esteem) fortunate:--call blessed, count happy.
a prolonged form of the poetical  (meaning the same); supremely blest; by extension, fortunate, well off:-- blessed, happy(X -ier).
from μακαρίζω; beatification, i.e. attribution of good fortune:--blessedness.
from Μακεδών; Macedonia, a region of Greece:--Macedonia.
of uncertain derivation; a Macedon (Macedonian), i.e. inhabitant of Macedonia:--of Macedonia, Macedonian.
of Latin origin (macellum); a butcher's stall, meat market or provision-shop:--shambles.
feminine accusative case singular of μακρός (ὁδός being implied); at a distance (literally or figuratively):--(a-)far (off), good (great) way off.
adverb from μακρός; from a distance or afar:--afar off, from far.
from the same as μακροθυμώς; to be long-spirited, i.e. (objectively) forbearing or (subjectively) patient:--bear (suffer) long, be longsuffering, have (long) patience, be patient, patiently endure.
from the same as μακροθυμώς; longanimity, i.e. (objectively) forbearance or (subjectively) fortitude:--longsuffering, patience.
adverb of a compound of μακρός and θυμός; with long (enduring) temper, i.e. leniently:--patiently.
from μῆκος; long (in place (distant) or time (neuter plural)):--far, long.
from μακρός and χρόνος; long-timed, i.e. long-lived:--live long.
from μαλακός; softness, i.e. enervation (debility):--disease.
of uncertain affinity; soft, i.e. fine (clothing); figuratively, a catamite:--effeminate, soft.
of Hebrew origin (מַהֲלַלְאֵל); Maleleel (i.e. Mahalalel), an antediluvian:--Maleleel.
neuter plural of the superlative of an apparently primary adverb  (very); (adverbially) most (in the greatest degree) or particularly:--chiefly, most of all, (e-)specially.
neuter of the comparative of the same as μάλιστα; (adverbially) more (in a greater degree)) or rather:--+ better, X far, (the) more (and more), (so) much (the more), rather.
of Hebrew origin (מֶלֶךְ); Malchus, an Israelite:--Malchus.
of natural origin ("mammy"); a grandmother:--grandmother.
of Chaldee origin (confidence, i.e. wealth, personified); mammonas, i.e. avarice (deified):--mammon.
of uncertain origin; Manaën, a Christian:--Manaen.
of Hebrew origin (מְנַשֶּׁה); Mannasses (i.e. Menashsheh), an Israelite:--Manasses.
prolongation from a primary verb, another form of which, , is used as an alternate in certain tenses; to learn (in any way):--learn, understand.
from μαίνομαι; craziness:--(+ make) X mad.
of Hebrew origin (מָן); manna (i.e. man), an edible gum:--manna.
from a derivative of μαίνομαι (meaning a prophet, as supposed to rave through inspiration); to divine, i.e. utter spells (under pretense of foretelling:--by soothsaying.
of uncertain affinity; to extinguish (as fire), i.e. (figuratively and passively) to pass away:--fade away.
of Chaldee origin (meaning our Lord has come); maranatha, i.e. an exclamation of the approaching divine judgment:--Maran-atha.
from  (a pearl-oyster); a pearl:--pearl.
probably of Chaldee origin (meaning mistress); Martha, a Christian woman:--Martha.
of Hebrew origin (מִרְיָם); Maria or Mariam (i.e. Mirjam), the name of six Christian females:-- Mary.
of Latin origin; Marcus, a Christian:--Marcus, Mark.
from  (to glisten); marble (as sparkling white):--marble.

from μάρτυς; to be a witness, i.e. testify (literally or figuratively):--charge, give (evidence), bear record, have (obtain, of) good (honest) report, be well reported of, testify, give (have) testimony, (be, bear, give, obtain) witness.
from μάρτυς; evidence given (judicially or genitive case):--record, report, testimony, witness.
neuter of a presumed derivative of μάρτυς; something evidential, i.e. (genitive case) evidence given or (specially), the Decalogue (in the sacred Tabernacle):--to be testified, testimony, witness.
middle voice from μάρτυς; to be adduced as a witness, i.e. (figuratively) to obtest (in affirmation or exhortation):--take to record, testify.
of uncertain affinity; a witness (literally (judicially) or figuratively (genitive case)); by analogy, a "martyr":-- martyr, record, witness.
from a primary  (to handle or squeeze); to chew:--gnaw.
from μάστιξ; to flog (literally or figuratively):--scourge.
from μαστός; to whip (literally):--scourge.
probably from the base of μασσάομαι (through the idea of contact); a whip (literally, the Roman flagellum for criminals; figuratively, a disease):--plague, scourging.
from the base of μασσάομαι; a (properly, female) breast (as if kneaded up):--pap.
from ματαιολόγος; random talk, i.e. babble:--vain jangling.
from μάταιος and λέγω; an idle (i.e. senseless or mischievous) talker, i.e. a wrangler:--vain talker.
from the base of μάτην; empty, i.e. (literally) profitless, or (specially), an idol:--vain, vanity.
from μάταιος; inutility; figuratively, transientness; morally, depravity:--vanity.
from μάταιος; to render (passively, become) foolish, i.e. (morally) wicked or (specially), idolatrous:--become vain.

accusative case of a derivative of the base of μασσάομαι (through the idea of tentative manipulation, i.e. unsuccessful search, or else of punishment); folly, i.e. (adverbially) to no purpose:--in vain.
a shorter form of Ματταθίας; Matthæus (i.e. Matthitjah), an Israelite and a Christian:--Matthew.
of Hebrew origin (מַתָּן); Matthan (i.e. Mattan), an Israelite:--Matthan.
probably a shortened form of Ματταθίας; Matthat (i.e. Mattithjah), the name of two Israelites:--Mathat.
apparently a shortened form of Ματταθίας; Matthias (i.e. Mattithjah), an Israelite:--Matthias.
probably a shortened form of Ματταθίας (compare מַתַּתָּה); Mattatha (i.e. Mattithjah), an Israelite:--Mattatha.
of Hebrew origin (מַתִּתְיָה); Mattathias (i.e. Mattithjah), an Israelite and a Christian:--Mattathias.
probably feminine of a presumed derivative of μάχη; a knife, i.e. dirk; figuratively, war, judicial punishment:--sword.
from μάχομαι; a battle, i.e. (figuratively) controversy:--fighting, strive, striving.
middle voice of an apparently primary verb; to war, i.e. (figuratively) to quarrel, dispute:--fight, strive.
a shorter (and probably original) form of ἐμέ; me:--I, me, my.
from a compound of μέγας and  (to boast; akin to αὐξάνω and καυχάομαι); to talk big, i.e. be grandiloquent (arrogant, egotistic):--boast great things.
from μέγας; magnificent, i.e. (neuter, plural as noun) a conspicuous favor, or (subjectively) perfection:--great things, wonderful works.
from μεγαλεῖος; superbness, i.e. glory or splendor:--magnificence, majesty, mighty power.
from μέγας and πρέπω; befitting greatness or magnificence (majestic):--excellent.
from μέγας; to make (or declare) great, i.e. increase or (figuratively) extol:--enlarge, magnify, shew great.
adverb from μέγας; much:--greatly.
from μέγας; greatness, i.e. (figuratively) divinity (often God himself):--majesty.

(including the prolonged forms, feminine , plural , etc.; compare also μέγιστος, μείζων); big (literally or figuratively, in a very wide application):--(+ fear) exceedingly, great(-est), high, large, loud, mighty, + (be) sore (afraid), strong, X to years.
from μέγας; magnitude (figuratively):--greatness.
plural from μέγιστος; grandees:--great men, lords.
superlative of μέγας; greatest or very great:--exceeding great.
from μετά and ἑρμηνεύω; to explain over, i.e. translate:--(by) interpret(-ation).
apparently a primary word; an intoxicant, i.e. (by implication) intoxication:--drunkenness.
from μετά and ἵστημι; to transfer, i.e. carry away, depose or (figuratively) exchange, seduce:--put out, remove, translate, turn away.
from a compound of μετά and ὁδεύω (compare "method"); travelling over, i.e. travesty (trickery):--wile, lie in wait.
from μετά and ὅριον; bounded alongside, i.e. contiguous (neuter plural as noun, frontier):--border.
a prolonged (transitive) form of μεθύω; to intoxicate:--be drunk(-en).
from μεθύω; tipsy, i.e. (as noun) a sot:--drunkard.
from another form of μέθη; to drink to intoxication, i.e. get drunk:--drink well, make (be) drunk(-en).
neuter of μείζων; (adverbially) in greater degree:--the more.
continued comparative of μείζων; still larger (figuratively):--greater.
irregular comparative of μέγας; larger (literally or figuratively, specially, in age):--elder, greater(-est), more.
neuter of μέλας as noun; ink:--ink.
apparently a primary word; black:--black.
of uncertain origin; Meleas, an Israelite:--Meleas.
from a presumed derivative of μέλω; to take care of, i.e. (by implication) revolve in the mind:--imagine, (pre-)meditate.
apparently a primary word; honey:--honey.
from μέλι; relating to honey, i.e. bee (comb):--honeycomb.
of uncertain origin; Melita, an island in the Mediterranean:--Melita.

a strengthened form of μέλω (through the idea of expectation); to intend, i.e. be about to be, do, or suffer something (of persons or things, especially events; in the sense of purpose, duty, necessity, probability, possibility, or hesitation):--about, after that, be (almost), (that which is, things, + which was for) to come, intend, was to (be), mean, mind, be at the point, (be) ready, + return, shall (begin), (which, that) should (after, afterwards, hereafter) tarry, which was for, will, would, be yet.
of uncertain affinity; a limb or part of the body:--member.
of Hebrew origin (מֶלֶךְ with pronominal suffix, my king); Melchi (i.e. Malki), the name of two Israelites:--Melchi.
of Hebrew origin (מַלְכִּי־צֶדֶק); Melchisedek (i.e. Malkitsedek), a patriarch:--Melchisedec.
a primary verb; to be of interest to, i.e. to concern (only third person singular present indicative used impersonally, it matters):--(take) care.
of Latin origin ("membrane"); a (written) sheep-skin:--parchment.
middle voice of an apparently primary verb; to blame:--find fault.
from a presumed derivative of μέμφομαι and  (fate; akin to the base of μέρος); blaming fate, i.e. querulous (discontented):--complainer.

a primary particle; properly, indicative of affirmation or concession (in fact); usually followed by a contrasted clause with δέ (this one, the former, etc.):--even, indeed, so, some, truly, verily. Often compounded with other particles in an intensive or asseverative sense.
from μέν and οὖν and γέ; so then at least:--nay but, yea doubtless (rather, verily).
from μέν and τοί; indeed though, i.e. however:--also, but, howbeit, nevertheless, yet.
a primary verb; to stay (in a given place, state, relation or expectancy):--abide, continue, dwell, endure, be present, remain, stand, tarry (for), X thine own.
from μέρος; to part, i.e. (literally) to apportion, bestow, share, or (figuratively) to disunite, differ:--deal, be difference between, distribute, divide, give participle
from μερίζω (through the idea of distraction); solicitude:--care.
from μέριμνα; to be anxious about:--(be, have) care(-ful), take thought.
feminine of μέρος; a portion, i.e. province, share or (abstractly) participation:--part (X -akers).
from μερίζω; a separation or distribution:--dividing asunder, gift.
from μερίζω; an apportioner (administrator):--divider.

from an obsolete but more primary form of  (to get as a section or allotment); a division or share (literally or figuratively, in a wide application):--behalf, course, coast, craft, particular (+ -ly), part (+ -ly), piece, portion, respect, side, some sort(-what).
from μέσος and ἡμέρα; midday; by implication, the south:--noon, south.
from μεσίτης; to interpose (as arbiter), i.e (by implication) to ratify (as surety):--confirm.
from μέσος; a go-between, i.e. (simply) an internunciator, or (by implication) a reconciler (intercessor):--mediator.
neuter of compound of μέσος and νύξ; midnight (especially as a watch):--midnight.
from μέσος and ποταμός; Mesopotamia (as lying between the Euphrates and the Tigris; compare אֲרַם נַהֲרַיִם), a region of Asia:--Mesopotamia.
from μετά; middle (as an adjective or (neuter) noun):--among, X before them, between, + forth, mid(-day, -night), midst, way.
from μέσος and τοῖχος; a partition (figuratively):--middle wall.
from a presumed compound of μέσος and οὐρανός; mid-sky:--midst of heaven.
from μέσος; to form the middle, i.e. (in point of time), to be half-way over:--be about the midst.
of Hebrew origin (מָשִׁיחַ); the Messias (i.e. Mashiach), or Christ:--Messias.
of uncertain derivation; replete (literally or figuratively):--full.
from μεστός; to replenish, i.e. (by implication) to intoxicate:--fill.

a primary preposition (often used adverbially); properly, denoting accompaniment; "amid" (local or causal); modified variously according to the case (genitive association, or accusative succession) with which it is joined; occupying an intermediate position between ἀπό or ἐκ and εἰς or πρός; less intimate than ἐν and less close than σύν):--after(-ward), X that he again, against, among, X and, + follow, hence, hereafter, in, of, (up-)on, + our, X and setting, since, (un-)to, + together, when, with (+ -out). Often used in composition, in substantially the same relations of participation or proximity, and transfer or sequence.
from μετά and the base of βάσις; to change place:--depart, go, pass, remove.
from μετά and βάλλω; to throw over, i.e. (middle voice figuratively) to turn about in opinion:--change mind.
from μετά and ἁρμόζω; to lead over, i.e. transfer (direct):--turn about.
from μετά and δίδωμι; to give over, i.e. share:--give, impart.
from μετατίθημι; transposition, i.e. transferral (to heaven), disestablishment (of a law):--change, removing, translation.
from μετά and αἴρω; to betake oneself, i.e. remove (locally):--depart.
from μετά and καλέω; to call elsewhere, i.e. summon:--call (for, hither).
from μετά and κινέω; to stir to a place elsewhere, i.e. remove (figuratively):--move away.
from μετά and λαμβάνω; to participate; genitive case, to accept (and use):--eat, have, be partaker, receive, take.
from μεταλαμβάνω; participation:--taking.
from μετά and ἀλλάσσω; to exchange:--change.
from μετά and the middle voice of μέλω; to care afterwards, i.e. regret:--repent (self).
from μετά and μορφόω; to transform (literally or figuratively, "metamorphose"):--change, transfigure, transform.
from μετά and νοιέω; to think differently or afterwards, i.e. reconsider (morally, feel compunction):--repent.
from μετανοέω; (subjectively) compunction (for guilt, including reformation); by implication, reversal (of (another's) decision):--repentance.
from μετά and a form of σύν; betwixt (of place or person); (of time) as adjective, intervening, or (by implication) adjoining:--between, mean while, next.
from μετά and πέμπω; to send from elsewhere, i.e. (middle voice) to summon or invite:--call (send) for.
from μετά and στρέφω; to turn across, i.e. transmute or (figuratively) corrupt:--pervert, turn.
from μετά and a derivative of σχῆμα; to transfigure or disguise; figuratively, to apply (by accommodation):--transfer, transform (self).
from μετά and τίθημι; to transfer, i.e. (literally) transport, (by implication) exchange, (reflexively) change sides, or (figuratively) pervert:--carry over, change, remove, translate, turn.
from μετά and ἔπειτα; thereafter:--afterward.
from μετά and ἔχω; to share or participate; by implication, belong to, eat (or drink):--be partaker, pertain, take part, use.

from a compound of μετά and a collateral form of αἴρω or perhaps rather ἀήρ (compare "meteor"); to raise in mid-air, i.e. (figuratively) suspend (passively, fluctuate or be anxious):--be of doubtful mind.
from a derivative of a compound of μετά and οἶκος; a change of abode, i.e. (specially), expatriation:--X brought, carried(-ying) away (in-)to.
from the same as μετοικεσία; to transfer as a settler or captive, i.e colonize or exile:--carry away, remove into.
from μετέχω; participation, i.e. intercourse:--fellowship.
from μετέχω; participant, i.e. (as noun) a sharer; by implication, an associate:--fellow, partaker, partner.
from μέτρον; to measure (i.e. ascertain in size by a fixed standard); by implication, to admeasure (i.e. allot by rule):--figuratively, to estimate:--measure, mete.
from μετρέω; a measurer, i.e. (specially), a certain standard measure of capacity for liquids:--firkin.
from a compound of the base of μετρίως and πάθος; to be moderate in passion, i.e. gentle (to treat indulgently):--have compassion.
adverb from a derivative of μέτρον; moderately, i.e. slightly:--a little.
an apparently primary word; a measure ("metre"), literally or figuratively; by implication, a limited portion (degree):-- measure.
from μετά and ops (the face); the forehead (as opposite the countenance):--forehead.

from μῆκος; as far as, i.e. up to a certain point (as a preposition, of extent (denoting the terminus, whereas ἄχρι refers especially to the space of time or place intervening) or conjunction):--till, (un-)to, until.

a primary particle of qualified negation (whereas οὐ expresses an absolute denial); (adverb) not, (conjunction) lest; also (as an interrogative implying a negative answer (whereas οὐ expects an affirmative one)) whether:--any but (that), X forbear, + God forbid, + lack, lest, neither, never, no (X wise in), none, nor, (can-)not, nothing, that not, un(-taken), without. Often used in compounds in substantially the same relations. See also ἐὰν μή, ἵνα μή, οὐ μή, μῆκος, μηκύνω, μήν, μὴ οὐκ.
i.e. ἐάν and μή; if not, i.e. unless:--X before, but, except, if, no, (if, + whosoever) not.
i.e. ἵνα and μή; in order (or so) that not:--albeit not, lest, that, no(-t, (-thing)).

i.e. οὐ and μή; a double negative strengthening the denial; not at all:--any more, at all, by any (no) means, neither, never, no (at all), in no case (wise), nor ever, not (at all, in any wise). Compare μὴ οὐκ.
adverb from a compound of μή and  (somebody); by no means:--not so.
from μή and δέ; but not, not even; in a continued negation, nor:--neither, nor (yet), (no) not (once, so much as).
from μή and εἷς; not even one (man, woman, thing):--any (man, thing), no (man), none, not (at all, any man, a whit), nothing, + without delay.
from μηδέ and ποτέ; not even ever:--never.
from μηδέ and -πω; not even yet:--not yet.
of foreign origin (compare מָדַי); a Median, or inhabitant of Media:--Mede.
from μή and ἔτι; no further:--any longer, (not) henceforth, hereafter, no henceforward (longer, more, soon), not any more.
probably akin to μέγας; length (literally or figuratively) length.
from μῆκος; to lengthen, i.e. (middle voice) to enlarge:--grow up.
from  (a sheep); a sheep-skin:--sheepskin.
a stronger form of μέν; a particle of affirmation (only with ἦ); assuredly:--+ surely.
a primary word; a month:--month.
probably from the same base as μασσάομαι and μνάομαι (i.e. , to strive); to disclose (through the idea of mental effort and thus calling to mind), i.e. report, declare, intimate:--shew, tell.
i.e. μή and οὐ; as interrogative and negative, is it not that?:--neither (followed by no), + never, not. Compare οὐ μή.
from μή and ποτέ; not ever; also if (or lest) ever (or perhaps):--if peradventure, lest (at any time, haply), not at all, whether or not.
from μή and -πω; not yet:--not yet.
from μή and -πώς; lest somehow:--lest (by any means, by some means, haply, perhaps).
perhaps a primary word; a thigh:--thigh.
from μή and τέ; not too, i.e. (in continued negation) neither or nor; also, not even:--neither, (n-)or, so as much.
apparently a primary word; a "mother" (literally or figuratively, immediate or remote):--mother.
from μή and the neuter of τὶς; whether at all:--not (the particle usually not expressed, except by the form of the question).
from μήτι and γέ; not at all then, i.e. not to say (the rather still):--how much more.
from μή and τὶς; whether any:--any (sometimes unexpressed except by the simple interrogative form of the sentence).
from μήτηρ; the matrix:--womb.
from μήτηρ and the base of ἅλων; a mother-thresher, i.e. matricide:--murderer of mothers.
from μήτηρ and πόλις; a mother city, i.e. "metropolis":--chiefest city.
irregular feminine of εἷς; one or first:--a (certain), + agree, first, one, X other.
perhaps a primary verb; to sully or taint, i.e. contaminate (ceremonially or morally):--defile.
from μιαίνω ("miasma"); (morally) foulness (properly, the effect):--pollution.
from μιαίνω; (morally) contamination (properly, the act):--uncleanness.
from μίγνυμι; a compound:--mixture.
a primary verb; to mix:--mingle.
masculine or neuter singular of μικρός (as noun); a small space of time or degree:--a (little) (while).
apparently a primary word; small (in size, quantity, number or (figuratively) dignity):--least, less, little, small.
of uncertain origin; Miletus, a city of Asia Minor:--Miletus.
of Latin origin; a thousand paces, i.e. a "mile":--mile.

of uncertain affinity; a thunder storm:--shower.
from ὅμιλος; to be in company with, i.e. (by implication) to converse:--commune, talk.
from ὅμιλος; companionship ("homily"), i.e. (by implication) intercourse:--communication.
from the base of ὁμοῦ and a derivative of the alternate of αἱρέομαι (meaning a crowd); association together, i.e. a multitude:--company.
from ὀπτάνομαι; a sight, i.e. (by implication) the eye:--eye.

a prolonged form of a primary,                         but obsolete , for which                         another prolonged form            is used in certain tenses; to swear, i.e. take (or declare on) oath:--swear.
adverb from a compound of the base of ὁμοῦ and θυμός; unanimously:--with one accord (mind).
from ὅμοιος; to resemble:--agree.
from ὅμοιος and the alternate of πάσχω; similarly affected:--of (subject to) like passions.
from the base of ὁμοῦ; similar (in appearance or character):--like, + manner.
from ὅμοιος; resemblance:--like as, similitude.
from ὅμοιος; to assimilate, i.e. compare; passively, to become similar:--be (make) like, (in the) liken(-ess), resemble.
from ὁμοιόω; a form; abstractly, resemblance:--made like to, likeness, shape, similitude.
adverb from ὅμοιος; similarly:--likewise, so.
from ὁμοιόω; assimilation, i.e. resemblance:--similitude.
from a compound of the base of ὁμοῦ and λόγος; to assent, i.e. covenant, acknowledge:--con- (pro-)fess, confession is made, give thanks, promise.
from the same as ὁμολογέω; acknowledgment:--con- (pro-)fession, professed.
adverb of present passive participle of ὁμολογέω; confessedly:--without controversy.
from the base of ὁμοῦ and τέχνη; a fellow-artificer:--of the same craft.
genitive case of  (the same; akin to ἅμα) as adverb; at the same place or time:--together.
from the base of ὁμοῦ and φρήν; like-minded, i.e. harmonious:--of one mind.
adverb from the base of ὁμοῦ; at the same time, i.e. (conjunctionally) notwithstanding, yet still:--and even, nevertheless, though but.
of uncertain derivation; a dream:--dream.
neuter of a presumed derivative of ὄνος; a little ass:--young ass.
from ὄνειδος; to defame, i.e. rail at, chide, taunt:--cast in teeth, (suffer) reproach, revile, upbraid.
from ὀνειδίζω; contumely:--reproach.
probably akin to the base of ὄνομα; notoriety, i.e. a taunt (disgrace):--reproach.
from ὀνίνημι; profitable; Onesimus, a Christian:--Onesimus.
from a derivative of ὀνίνημι and φόρος; profit-bearer; Onesiphorus, a Christian:--Onespiphorus.
from ὄνος; belonging to a ass, i.e. large (so as to be turned by a ass):--millstone.

a prolonged form of an apparently primary verb (, to slur); for which another prolonged form () is used as an alternate in some tenses (unless indeed it be identical with the base of ὄνομα through the idea of notoriety); to gratify, i.e. (middle voice) to derive pleasure or advantage from:--have joy.
from a presumed derivative of the base of γινώσκω (compare ὀνίνημι); a "name" (literally or figuratively) (authority, character):--called, (+ sur-)name(-d).
from ὄνομα; to name, i.e. assign an appellation; by extension, to utter, mention, profess:--call, name.
apparently a primary word; a donkey:--an ass.
adverb of the oblique cases of ὤν; really:--certainly, clean, indeed, of a truth, verily.
from ὀξύς; vinegar, i.e. sour wine:--vinegar.
probably akin to the base of ἀκμήν ("acid"); keen; by analogy, rapid:--sharp, swift.
probably from ὀπτάνομαι; a hole (as if for light), i.e. cavern; by analogy, a spring (of water):--cave, place.
from  (regard; from ὀπτάνομαι) with enclitic of source; from the rear (as a secure aspect), i.e. at the back (adverb and preposition of place or time):--after, backside, behind.
from the same as ὄπισθεν with enclitic of direction; to the back, i.e. aback (as adverb or preposition of time or place; or as noun):--after, back(-ward), (+ get) behind, + follow.
from ὅπλον; to equip (with weapons (middle voice and figuratively)):--arm self.
probably from a primary  (to be busy about); an implement or utensil or tool (literally or figuratively, especially, offensive for war):--armour, instrument, weapon.

from ὅς and ποῖος; of what kind that, i.e. how (as) great (excellent) (specially, as an indefinite correlative to the definite antecedent τοιοῦτος of quality):--what manner (sort) of, such as whatsoever.
from ὅς and ποτέ; what(-ever) then, i.e. (of time) as soon as:--when.
from ὅς and πού; what(-ever) where, i.e. at whichever spot:--in what place, where(-as, -soever), whither (+ soever).

a (middle voice) prolonged form of the primary (middle voice)        ;    which is used for it in certain                                   tenses; and both as alternate of                                   ὁράω; to gaze (i.e. with wide-open eyes, as at something remarkable; and thus differing from βλέπω, which denotes simply voluntary observation; and from εἴδω, which expresses merely mechanical, passive or casual vision; while θεάομαι, and still more emphatically its intensive θεωρέω, signifies an earnest but more continued inspection; and σκοπέω a watching from a distance):--appear, look, see, shew self.
from a presumed derivative of ὀπτάνομαι; visuality, i.e. (concretely) an apparition:--vision.
from an obsolete verb akin to  (to "steep"); cooked, i.e. roasted:--broiled.
apparently from the base of ὀψέ and ὥρα; properly, even-tide of the (summer) season (dog-days), i.e. (by implication) ripe fruit:--fruit.
from ὅς and πῶς; what(-ever) how, i.e. in the manner that (as adverb or conjunction of coincidence, intentional or actual):--because, how, (so) that, to, when.
from ὁράω; something gazed at, i.e. a spectacle (especially supernatural):--sight, vision.
from ὁράω; the act of gazing, i.e. (externally) an aspect or (internally) an inspired appearance:--sight, vision.
from ὁράω; gazed at, i.e. (by implication) capable of being seen:--visible.

properly, to stare at (compare ὀπτάνομαι), i.e. (by implication) to discern clearly (physically or mentally); by extension, to attend to; by Hebraism, to experience; passively, to appear:--behold, perceive, see, take heed.

from ὀρέγομαι; properly, desire (as a reaching forth or excitement of the mind), i.e. (by analogy), violent passion (ire, or (justifiable) abhorrence); by implication punishment:--anger, indignation, vengeance, wrath.
from ὀργή; to provoke or enrage, i.e. (passively) become exasperated:--be angry (wroth).
from ὀργή; irascible:--soon angry.
from ὀρέγομαι; a stretch of the arms, i.e. a fathom:--fathom.
middle voice of apparently a prolonged form of an obsolete primary (compare ὄρος); to stretch oneself, i.e. reach out after (long for):--covet after, desire.
from ὄρος; mountainous, i.e. (feminine by implication, of χώρα) the Highlands (of Judæa):--hill country.
from ὀρέγομαι; excitement of the mind, i.e. longing after:--lust.
from a compound of ὀρθός and πούς; to be straight-footed, i.e. (figuratively) to go directly forward:--walk uprightly.
probably from the base of ὄρος; right (as rising), i.e. (perpendicularly) erect (figuratively, honest), or (horizontally) level or direct:--straight, upright.
from a compound of ὀρθός and the base of τομώτερος, to make a straight cut, i.e. (figuratively) to dissect (expound) correctly (the divine message):--rightly divide.
from ὄρθρος; to use the dawn, i.e. (by implication) to repair betimes:--come early in the morning.
from ὄρθρος; relating to the dawn, i.e. matutinal (as an epithet of Venus, especially brilliant in the early day):--morning.
from ὄρθρος; in the dawn, i.e. up at day-break:--early.
from the same as ὄρος; dawn (as sun-rise, rising of light); by extension, morn:--early in the morning.
adverb from ὀρθός; in a straight manner, i.e. (figuratively) correctly (also morally):--plain, right(-ly).
from ὅριον; to mark out or bound ("horizon"), i.e. (figuratively) to appoint, decree, specify:--declare, determine, limit, ordain.
neuter of a derivative of an apparently primary  (a bound or limit); a boundary-line, i.e. (by implication) a frontier (region):--border, coast.
from ὅρκος; to put on oath, i.e. make swear; by analogy, to solemnly enjoin:--adjure, charge.
from  (a fence; perhaps akin to ὅριον); a limit, i.e. (sacred) restraint (specially, an oath):--oath.
from a compound of ὅρκος and a derivative of ὀμνύω; asseveration on oath:--oath.
from ὁρμή; to start, spur or urge on, i.e. (reflexively) to dash or plunge:--run (violently), rush.
of uncertain affinity; a violent impulse, i.e. onset:--assault.
from ὁρμή; an attack, i.e. (abstractly) precipitancy:--violence.
neuter of a presumed derivative of ὄρνις; a birdling:--bird, fowl.
probably from a prolonged form of the base of ὄρος; a bird (as rising in the air), i.e. (specially), a hen (or female domestic fowl):--hen.
from a compound of the base of ὅριον and a derivative of τίθημι; a limit-placing, i.e. (concretely) boundary-line:--bound.
probably from an obsolete  (to rise or "rear"; perhaps akin to αἴρω; compare ὄρνις); a mountain (as lifting itself above the plain):--hill, mount(-ain).
apparently a primary verb; to "burrow" in the ground, i.e. dig:--dig.
of uncertain affinity; bereaved ("orphan"), i.e. parentless:--comfortless, fatherless.
middle voice from  (a row or ring); to dance (from the ranklike or regular motion):--dance.

probably a primary word (or perhaps a form of the article ὁ); the relatively (sometimes demonstrative) pronoun, who, which, what, that:--one, (an-, the) other, some, that, what, which, who(-m, -se), etc. See also οὗ.
multiple adverb from ὅς; how (i.e. with ἄν, so) many times as:--as oft(-en) as.

of uncertain affinity; properly, right (by intrinsic or divine character; thus distinguished from 1342, which refers rather to human statutes and relations; from ἱερός, which denotes formal consecration; and from ἅγιος, which relates to purity from defilement), i.e. hallowed (pious, sacred, sure):--holy, mercy, shalt be. 342
from ὅσιος; piety:--holiness.
adverb from ὅσιος; piously:--holily.
from ὄζω; fragrance (literally or figuratively):--odour, savour.

by reduplication from ὅς; as (much, great, long, etc.) as:--all (that), as (long, many, much) (as), how great (many, much), (in-)asmuch as, so many as, that (ever), the more, those things, what (great, -soever), wheresoever, wherewithsoever, which, X while, who(-soever).
from ὅς and περ; who especially:--whomsoever.
of uncertain affinity; a bone:--bone.
from ὅς and τὶς; which some, i.e. any that; also (definite) which same:--X and (they), (such) as, (they) that, in that they, what(-soever), whereas ye, (they) which, who(-soever). Compare ὅτι.
from  ("oyster") (a tile, i.e. terra cotta); earthen-ware, i.e. clayey; by implication, frail:--of earth, earthen.
from a derivative of ὄζω; smell (the sense):--smelling.
of uncertain affinity; the loin (externally), i.e. the hip; internally (by extension) procreative power:--loin.
from ὅτε and ἄν; whenever (implying hypothesis or more or less uncertainty); also causatively (conjunctionally) inasmuch as:--as long (soon) as, that, + till, when(-soever), while.
from ὅς and τέ; at which (thing) too, i.e. when:--after (that), as soon as, that, when, while.
neuter of ὅστις as conjunction; demonstrative, that (sometimes redundant); causative, because:--as concerning that, as though, because (that), for (that), how (that), (in) that, though, why.
for the genitive case of ὅστις (as adverb); during which same time, i.e. whilst:--whiles.

a primary word; the absolute negative (compare μή) adverb; no or not:--+ long, nay, neither, never, no (X man), none, (can-)not, + nothing, + special, un(-worthy), when, + without, + yet but. See also οὐ μή, μῆκος.
genitive case of ὅς as adverb; at which place, i.e. where:--where(-in), whither(-soever).
a primary exclamation of surprise; "ah":--ah.
a primary exclamation of grief; "woe":--alas, woe.
adverb from (the feminine) of οὐδείς; by no means:--not.
from οὐ and δέ; not however, i.e. neither, nor, not even:--neither (indeed), never, no (more, nor, not), nor (yet), (also, even, then) not (even, so much as), + nothing, so much as.

from οὐδέ and εἷς; not even one (man, woman or thing), i.e. none, nobody, nothing:--any (man), aught, man, neither any (thing), never (man), no (man), none (+ of these things), not (any, at all, -thing), nought.
from οὐδέ and ποτέ; not even at any time, i.e. never at all:--neither at any time, never, nothing at any time.
from οὐδέ and -πω; not even yet:--as yet not, never before (yet), (not) yet.
from οὐ and ἔτι; not yet, no longer:--after that (not), (not) any more, henceforth (hereafter) not, no longer (more), not as yet (now), now no more (not), yet (not).
from οὐ and οὖν; is it not therefore that, i.e. (affirmatively) hence or so:--then.
apparently a primary word; (adverbially) certainly, or (conjunctionally) accordingly:--and (so, truly), but, now (then), so (likewise then), then, therefore, verily, wherefore.
from οὐ and -πω; not yet:--hitherto not, (no…) as yet, not yet.
apparently a primary word; a tail:--tail.
from οὐρανός; celestial, i.e. belonging to or coming from the sky:--heavenly.
from οὐρανός and the enclitic of source; from the sky:--from heaven.

perhaps from the same as ὄρος (through the idea of elevation); the sky; by extension, heaven (as the abode of God); by implication, happiness, power, eternity; specially, the Gospel (Christianity):--air, heaven(-ly), sky.
of Latin origin; Urbanus (of the city, "urbane"), a Christian:--Urbanus.
of Hebrew origin (אוּרִיָּה); Urias (i.e. Urijah), a Hittite:--Urias.
apparently a primary word; the ear (physically or mentally):--ear.
from the feminine of ὤν; substance, i.e. property (possessions):--goods, substance.
from οὐ and τέ; not too, i.e. neither or nor; by analogy, not even:--neither, none, nor (yet), (no, yet) not, nothing.

from the article ὁ and αὐτός; the he (she or it), i.e. this or that (often with article repeated):--he (it was that), hereof, it, she, such as, the same, these, they, this (man, same, woman), which, who.

adverb from οὗτος; in this way (referring to what precedes or follows):--after that, after (in) this manner, as, even (so), for all that, like(-wise), no more, on this fashion(-wise), so (in like manner), thus, what.
intensive of οὐ; not indeed:--nay, not.
from ὀφείλω; an ower, i.e. person indebted; figuratively, a delinquent; morally, a transgressor (against God):--debtor, which owed, sinner.
from ὀφείλω; indebtedness, i.e. (concretely) a sum owed; figuratively, obligation, i.e. (conjugal) duty:--debt, due.
from (the alternate of) ὀφείλω; something owed, i.e. (figuratively) a due; morally, a fault:--debt.

probably from the base of ὄφελος (through the idea of accruing); to owe (pecuniarily); figuratively, to be under obligation (ought, must, should); morally, to fail in duty:--behove, be bound, (be) debt(-or), (be) due(-ty), be guilty (indebted), (must) need(-s), ought, owe, should. See also ὄφελον.
first person singular of a past tense of ὀφείλω; I ought (wish), i.e. (interjection) oh that!:--would (to God).
from  (to heap up, i.e. accumulate or benefit); gain:--advantageth, profit.
from ὀφθαλμός and δουλεία; sight-labor, i.e. that needs watching (remissness):--eye-service.
from ὀπτάνομαι; the eye (literally or figuratively); by implication, vision; figuratively, envy (from the jealous side-glance):--eye, sight.
probably from ὀπτάνομαι (through the idea of sharpness of vision); a snake, figuratively, (as a type of sly cunning) an artful malicious person, especially Satan:--serpent.
perhaps from ὀπτάνομαι (through the idea of the shading or proximity to the organ of vision); the eye-"brow" or forehead, i.e. (figuratively) the brink of a precipice:--brow.
from ὄχλος; to mob, i.e. (by implication) to harass:--vex.
from ὄχλος and ποιέω; to make a crowd, i.e. raise a public disturbance:--gather a company.

from a derivative of ἔχω (meaning a vehicle); a throng (as borne along); by implication, the rabble; by extension, a class of people; figuratively, a riot:--company, multitude, number (of people), people, press.
from a remote derivative of ἔχω (meaning to fortify, through the idea of holding safely); a castle (figuratively, argument):--stronghold.
neuter of a presumed derivative of the base of ὀπτός; a relish to other food (as if cooked sauce), i.e. (specially), fish (presumably salted and dried as a condiment):--fish.
from the same as ὀπίσω (through the idea of backwardness); (adverbially) late in the day; by extension, after the close of the day:--(at) even, in the end.
from ὀψέ; later, i.e. vernal (showering):--latter.
from ὀψέ; late; feminine (as noun) afternoon (early eve) or nightfall (later eve):--even(-ing, (-tide)).
from ὀπτάνομαι; properly, sight (the act), i.e. (by implication) the visage, an external show:--appearance, countenance, face.
neuter of a presumed derivative of the same as ὀψάριον; rations for a soldier, i.e. (by extension) his stipend or pay:-- wages.

lemma: ὁ ὢν καί ὁ ἦν καί ὁ ἐρχόμενος
xlit: ho ṑn kaí ho ēn kaí ho erchómenos
pronounce: ho own kahee ho ane kahee ho er-khom'-en-os
description: a phrase combining ὁ with the present participle and imperfect of εἰμί and the present participle of ἔρχομαι by means of καί; the one being and the one that was and the one coming, i.e. the Eternal, as a divine epithet of Christ:--which art (is, was), and (which) wast (is, was), and art (is) to come (shalt be).
from παγίς; to ensnare (figuratively):--entangle.
from πήγνυμι; a trap (as fastened by a noose or notch); figuratively, a trick or statagem (temptation):--snare.
from a presumed derivative of πάθος; something undergone, i.e. hardship or pain; subjectively, an emotion or influence:-- affection, affliction, motion, suffering.
from the same as πάθημα; liable (i.e. doomed) to experience pain:--suffer.
from the alternate of πάσχω; properly, suffering ("pathos"), i.e. (subjectively) a passion (especially concupiscence):-- (inordinate) affection, lust.

from παῖς and a reduplicated form of ἄγω; a boy-leader, i.e. a servant whose office it was to take the children to school; (by implication, (figuratively) a tutor ("pædagogue")):-- instructor, schoolmaster.
neuter of a presumed derivative of παῖς; a little boy:--child, lad.
from παιδεύω; tutorage, i.e. education or training; by implication, disciplinary correction:--chastening, chastisement, instruction, nurture.
from παιδεύω; a trainer, i.e. teacher or (by implication) discipliner:--which corrected, instructor.
from παῖς; to train up a child, i.e. educate, or (by implication), discipline (by punishment):--chasten(-ise), instruct, learn, teach.
adverb (of source) from παιδίον; from infancy:--of a child.
neuter diminutive of παῖς; a childling (of either sex), i.e. (properly), an infant, or (by extension) a half-grown boy or girl; figuratively, an immature Christian:--(little, young) child, damsel.
feminine diminutive of παῖς; a girl, i.e. (specially), a female slave or servant:--bondmaid(-woman), damsel, maid(-en).
from παῖς; to sport (as a boy):--play.

perhaps from παίω; a boy (as often beaten with impunity), or (by analogy), a girl, and (genitive case) a child; specially, a slave or servant (especially a minister to a king; and by eminence to God):--child, maid(-en), (man) servant, son, young man.
a primary verb; to hit (as if by a single blow and less violently than τύπτω); specially, to sting (as a scorpion):--smite, strike.
feminine of an adjective of uncertain derivation; Pacatianian, a section of Phrygia:--Pacatiana.

probably another form for πάλιν (through the idea of retrocession); (adverbially) formerly, or (by relatively) sometime since; (elliptically as adjective) ancient:--any while, a great while ago, (of) old, in time past.
from πάλαι; antique, i.e. not recent, worn out:--old.
from παλαιός; antiquatedness:--oldness.
from παλαιός; to make (passively, become) worn out, or declare obsolete:--decay, make (wax) old.
from  (to vibrate; another form for βάλλω); wrestling:--+ wrestle.
from πάλιν and γένεσις; (spiritual) rebirth (the state or the act), i.e. (figuratively) spiritual renovation; specially, Messianic restoration:--regeneration.

probably from the same as πάλη (through the idea of oscillatory repetition); (adverbially) anew, i.e. (of place) back, (of time) once more, or (conjunctionally) furthermore or on the other hand:--again.
dative case (adverb) of a compound of πᾶς and πλῆθος; in full multitude, i.e. concertedly or simultaneously:--all at once.
from πᾶς and πολύς; full many, i.e. immense:--very great.
from a compound of πᾶς and πυρά; every-tribal, i.e. heterogeneous (χώρα being implied); Pamphylia, a region of Asia Minor:--Pamphylia.
neuter of a presumed compound of πᾶς and a derivative of δέχομαι; all-receptive, i.e. a public lodging-place (caravanserai or khan):--inn.
from the same as πανδοχεῖον; an innkeeper (warden of a caravanserai):--host.
from πᾶς and a derivative of ἀγορά; a mass-meeting, i.e. (figuratively) universal companionship:--general assembly.
adverb from πᾶς and οἶκος; with the whole family:--with all his house.
from a compound of πᾶς and ὅπλον; full armor ("panoply"):--all (whole) armour.
from πανοῦργος; adroitness, i.e. (in a bad sense) trickery or sophistry:--(cunning) craftiness, subtilty.
from πᾶς and ἔργον; all-working, i.e. adroit (shrewd):--crafty.
adverb (of source) from πανταχοῦ; from all directions:--from every quarter.
genitive case (as adverb of place) of a presumed derivative of πᾶς; universally:--in all places, everywhere.
from πᾶς and τέλος; full-ended, i.e. entire (neuter as noun, completion):--+ in (no) wise, uttermost.
adverb (of manner) from πᾶς; wholly:--always.
adverb (of source) from πᾶς; from (i.e. on) all sides:--on every side, round about.
from πᾶς and κράτος; the all-ruling, i.e. God (as absolute and universal sovereign):--Almighty, Omnipotent.
from πᾶς and ὅτε; every when, i.e. at all times:--alway(-s), ever(-more).
adverb from πᾶς; entirely; specially, at all events, (with negative, following) in no event:--by all means, altogether, at all, needs, no doubt, in (no) wise, surely.

a primary preposition; properly, near; i.e. (with genitive case) from beside (literally or figuratively), (with dative case) at (or in) the vicinity of (objectively or subjectively), (with accusative case) to the proximity with (local (especially beyond or opposed to) or causal (on account of):--above, against, among, at, before, by, contrary to, X friend, from, + give (such things as they), + that (she) had, X his, in, more than, nigh unto, (out) of, past, save, side…by, in the sight of, than, (there-)fore, with. In compounds it retains the same variety of application.
from παρά and the base of βάσις; to go contrary to, i.e. violate a command:--(by) transgress(-ion).
from παρά and βάλλω; to throw alongside, i.e. (reflexively) to reach a place, or (figuratively) to liken:--arrive, compare.
from παραβαίνω; violation:--breaking, transgression.
from παραβαίνω; a violator:--breaker, transgress(-or).
from παρά and the middle voice of βιάζω; to force contrary to (nature), i.e. compel (by entreaty):--constrain.
from παραβάλλω; a similitude ("parable"), i.e. (symbolic) fictitious narrative (of common life conveying a moral), apothegm or adage:--comparison, figure, parable, proverb.
from παρά and the middle voice of βουλεύω; to misconsult, i.e. disregard:--not (to) regard(-ing).
from παραγγέλλω; a mandate:--charge, command.
from παρά and the base of ἄγγελος; to transmit a message, i.e. (by implication) to enjoin:--(give in) charge, (give) command(-ment), declare.
from παρά and γίνομαι; to become near, i.e. approach (have arrived); by implication, to appear publicly:--come, go, be present.
from παρά and ἄγω; to lead near, i.e. (reflexively or intransitively) to go along or away:--depart, pass (away, by, forth).
from παρά and δειγματίζω; to show alongside (the public), i.e. expose to infamy:--make a public example, put to an open shame.
of Oriental origin (compare פַּרְדֵּס); a park, i.e. (specially), an Eden (place of future happiness, "paradise"):--paradise.
from παρά and δέχομαι; to accept near, i.e. admit or (by implication) delight in:--receive.
from a compound of παρά and διατρίβω; misemployment, i.e. meddlesomeness:--perverse disputing.
from παρά and δίδωμι; to surrender, i.e yield up, intrust, transmit:--betray, bring forth, cast, commit, deliver (up), give (over, up), hazard, put in prison, recommend.
from παρά and δόξα (in the sense of seeming); contrary to expectation, i.e. extraordinary ("paradox"):--strange.
from παραδίδωμι; transmission, i.e. (concretely) a precept; specially, the Jewish traditionary law:--ordinance, tradition.
from παρά and ζηλόω; to stimulate alongside, i.e. excite to rivalry:--provoke to emulation (jealousy).
from παρά and θάλασσα; along the sea, i.e. maritime (lacustrine):--upon the sea coast.
from παρά and θεωρέω; to overlook or disregard:--neglect.
from παρατίθημι; a deposit, i.e. (figuratively) trust:--committed unto.
from παρά and αἰνέω; to mispraise, i.e. recommend or advise (a different course):--admonish, exhort.
from παρά and the middle voice of αἰτέω; to beg off, i.e. deprecate, decline, shun:--avoid, (make) excuse, intreat, refuse, reject.
from παρά and καθίζω; to sit down near:--sit.
from παρά and καλέω; to call near, i.e. invite, invoke (by imploration, hortation or consolation):--beseech, call for, (be of good) comfort, desire, (give) exhort(-ation), intreat, pray.
from παρά and καλύπτω; to cover alongside, i.e. veil (figuratively):--hide.
from a compound of παρά and κατατίθημι; something put down alongside, i.e. a deposit (sacred trust):--that (thing) which is committed (un-)to (trust).
from παρά and κεῖμαι; to lie near, i.e. be at hand (figuratively, be prompt or easy):--be present.
from παρακαλέω; imploration, hortation, solace:--comfort, consolation, exhortation, intreaty.
from παρακούω; inattention, i.e. (by implication) disobedience:--disobedience.
from παρά and ἀκολουθέω; to follow near, i.e. (figuratively) attend (as a result), trace out, conform to:--attain, follow, fully know, have understanding.
from παρά and ἀκούω; to mishear, i.e. (by implication) to disobey:--neglect to hear.
from παρά and κύπτω; to bend beside, i.e. lean over (so as to peer within):--look (into), stoop down.

from παρά and λαμβάνω; to receive near, i.e. associate with oneself (in any familiar or intimate act or relation); by analogy, to assume an office; figuratively, to learn:--receive, take (unto, with).
from παρά and the middle voice of λέγω (in its original sense); (specially), to lay one's course near, i.e. sail past:--pass, sail by.
from παρά and ἅλς; beside the salt (sea), i.e. maritime:--sea coast.
from a compound of παρά and ἀλλάσσω; transmutation (of phase or orbit), i.e. (figuratively) fickleness:--variableness.
from παρά and λογίζομαι; to misreckon, i.e. delude:--beguile, deceive.
from a derivative of παραλύω; as if dissolved, i.e. "paralytic":--that had (sick of) the palsy.
from παρά and λύω; to loosen beside, i.e. relax (perfect passive participle, paralyzed or enfeebled):--feeble, sick of the (taken with) palsy.
from παρά and μένω; to stay near, i.e. remain (literally, tarry; or figuratively, be permanent, persevere):--abide, continue.
from παρά and the middle voice of a derivative of μῦθος; to relate near, i.e. (by implication) encourage, console:--comfort.
from παραμυθέομαι; consolation (properly, abstract):--comfort.
neuter of παραμυθία; consolation (properly, concretely):--comfort.
from a compound of παρά and νόμος; to be opposed to law, i.e. to transgress:--contrary to law.
from the same as παρανομέω; transgression:--iniquity.
from παρά and πικραίνω; to embitter alongside, i.e. (figuratively) to exasperate:--provoke.
from παραπικραίνω; irritation:--provocation.
from παρά and πίπτω; to fall aside, i.e. (figuratively) to apostatize:--fall away.
from παρά and πλέω; to sail near:--sail by.
neuter of a compound of παρά and the base of πλησίον (as adverb); close by, i.e. (figuratively) almost:--nigh unto.
adverb from the same as παραπλήσιον; in a manner near by, i.e. (figuratively) similarly:--likewise.
from παρά and πορεύομαι; to travel near:--go, pass (by).
from παραπίπτω; a side-slip (lapse or deviation), i.e. (unintentional) error or (wilful) transgression:--fall, fault, offence, sin, trespass.
from παρά and the alternate of ῥέω; to flow by, i.e. (figuratively) carelessly pass (miss):--let slip.
from παρά and the base of σημαίνω; side-marked, i.e. labelled (with a badge (figure-head) of a ship):--sign.
from παρά and a derivative of σκεῦος; to furnish aside, i.e. get ready:--prepare self, be (make) ready.
as if from παρασκευάζω; readiness:--preparation.
from παρά and teino (to stretch); to extend along, i.e. prolong (in point of time):--continue.
from παρά and τηρέω; to inspect alongside, i.e. note insidiously or scrupulously:--observe, watch.
from παρατηρέω; inspection, i.e. ocular evidence:--obervation.
from παρά and τίθημι; to place alongside, i.e. present (food, truth); by implication, to deposit (as a trust or for protection):--allege, commend, commit (the keeping of), put forth, set before.
from παρά and τυγχάνω; to chance near, i.e. fall in with:--meet with.
from παρά and a derivative of αὐτός; at the very instant, i.e. momentary:--but for a moment.
from παρά and φέρω (including its alternate forms); to bear along or aside, i.e. carry off (literally or figuratively); by implication, to avert:--remove, take away.
from παρά and φρονέω; to misthink, i.e. be insane (silly):--as a fool.
from παραφρονέω; insanity, i.e. foolhardiness:--madness.
from παρά and χειμάζω; to winter near, i.e. stay with over the rainy season:--winter.
from παραχειμάζω; a wintering over:--winter in.
from παρά and χρῆμα (in its original sense); at the thing itself, i.e. instantly:--forthwith, immediately, presently, straightway, soon.
feminine of  (a panther); a leopard:--leopard.
from παρά and εἰμί (including its various forms); to be near, i.e. at hand; neuter present participle (singular) time being, or (plural) property:--come, X have, be here, + lack, (be here) present.
from παρά and εἰσάγω; to lead in aside, i.e. introduce surreptitiously:--privily bring in.
from παρεισάγω; smuggled in:--unawares brought in.
from παρά and a compound of εἰς and δύνω; to settle in alongside, i.e. lodge stealthily:--creep in unawares.
from παρά and εἰσέρχομαι; to come in alongside, i.e. supervene additionally or steathily:--come in privily, enter.
from παρά and εἰσφέρω; to bear in alongside, i.e. introduce simultaneously:--give.
from παρά and ἐκτός; near outside, i.e. besides:--except, saving, without.
from a compound of παρά and ἐμβάλλω; a throwing in beside (juxtaposition), i.e. (specially), battle-array, encampment or barracks (tower Antonia):--army, camp, castle.
from παρά and ἐνοχλέω; to harass further, i.e. annoy:--trouble.
from παρά and the base of ἐπιδημέω; an alien alongside, i.e. a resident foreigner:--pilgrim, stranger.

from παρά and ἔρχομαι; to come near or aside, i.e. to approach (arrive), go by (or away), (figuratively) perish or neglect, (causative) avert:--come (forth), go, pass (away, by, over), past, transgress.
from κτήτωρ; praetermission, i.e. toleration:--remission.
from παρά and ἔχω; to hold near, i.e. present, afford, exhibit, furnish occasion:--bring, do, give, keep, minister, offer, shew, + trouble.
from a compound of παρά and a derivative of ἀγορά (meaning to harangue an assembly); an address alongside, i.e. (specially), consolation:--comfort.
from παρθένος; maidenhood:--virginity.
of unknown origin; a maiden; by implication, an unmarried daughter:--virgin.
probably of foreign origin; a Parthian, i.e. inhabitant of Parthia:--Parthian.
from παρά and hiemi (to send); to let by, i.e. relax:--hang down.

from παρά and ἵστημι; to stand beside, i.e. (transitively) to exhibit, proffer, (specially), recommend, (figuratively) substantiate; or (intransitively) to be at hand (or ready), aid:--assist, bring before, command, commend, give presently, present, prove, provide, shew, stand (before, by, here, up, with), yield.
probably by contraction for  (a derivative of a compound of παρά and μένω); constant; Parmenas, a Christian:--Parmenas.
from παρά and ὁδός; a by-road, i.e. (actively) a route:--way.
from παρά and οἰκέω; to dwell near, i.e. reside as a foreigner:--sojourn in, be a stranger.
from πάροικος; foreign residence:--sojourning, X as strangers.
from παρά and οἶκος; having a home near, i.e. (as noun) a by-dweller (alien resident):--foreigner, sojourn, stranger.

from a compound of παρά and perhaps a derivative of οἴομαι; apparently a state alongside of supposition, i.e. (concretely) an adage; specially, an enigmatical or fictitious illustration:--parable, proverb.
from παρά and οἶνος; staying near wine, i.e. tippling (a toper):--given to wine.
from παρά and  (to depart); to escape along, i.e. be gone:--past.
from παρόμοιος; to resemble:--be like unto.
from παρά and ὅμοιος; alike nearly, i.e. similar:--like.
from παρά and a derivative of ὀξύς; to sharpen alongside, i.e. (figuratively) to exasperate:--easily provoke, stir.
from παροξύνω ("paroxysm"); incitement (to good), or dispute (in anger):--contention, provoke unto.
from παρά and ὀργίζω; to anger alongside, i.e. enrage:--anger, provoke to wrath.
from παροργίζω; rage:--wrath.
from παρά and  (to spur); to urge along, i.e. stimulate (to hostility):--stir up.

from the present participle of πάρειμι; a being near, i.e. advent (often, return; specially, of Christ to punish Jerusalem, or finally the wicked); (by implication) physically, aspect:--coming, presence.
from παρά and the base of ὀψάριον; a side-dish (the receptacle):--platter.

from πᾶς and a derivative of ῥέω; all out-spokenness, i.e. frankness, bluntness, publicity; by implication, assurance:--bold (X -ly, -ness, -ness of speech), confidence, X freely, X openly, X plainly(-ness).
middle voice from παῤῥησία; to be frank in utterance, or confident in spirit and demeanor:--be (wax) bold, (preach, speak) boldly.

including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole:--all (manner of, means), alway(-s), any (one), X daily, + ever, every (one, way), as many as, + no(-thing), X thoroughly, whatsoever, whole, whosoever.
of Chaldee origin (compare פֶּסַח); the Passover (the meal, the day, the festival or the special sacrifices connected with it):--Easter, Passover.
apparently a primary verb; to experience a sensation or impression (usually painful):--feel, passion, suffer, vex.
probably of foreign origin; Patara, a place in Asia Minor:--Patara.
probably prolongation from παίω; to knock (gently or with a weapon or fatally):--smite, strike. Compare τύπτω.
from a derivative probably of παίω (meaning a "path"); to trample (literally or figuratively):--tread (down, under foot).
apparently a primary word; a "father" (literally or figuratively, near or more remote):--father, parent.
of uncertain derivation; Patmus, an islet in the Mediterranean:--Patmos.
from πατήρ and the same as the latter part of μητραλῴας; a parricide:--murderer of fathers.
as if feminine of a derivative of πατήρ; paternal descent, i.e. (concretely) a group of families or a whole race (nation):--family, kindred, lineage.
from πατριά and ἄρχω; a progenitor ("patriarch"):--patriarch.
from πατήρ; paternal, i.e. ancestral:--of fathers.
from παράσημος; a father-land, i.e. native town; (figuratively) heavenly home:--(own) country.
perhaps a contraction for  (a compound of πατήρ and βίος); father's life; Patrobas, a Christian:--Patrobas.
from πατήρ and a derivative of παραδίδωμι (in the sense of handing over or down); traditionary:--received by tradition from fathers.
from πατήρ; paternal, i.e. hereditary:--of fathers.
of Latin origin; (little; but remotely from a derivative of παύω, meaning the same); Paulus, the name of a Roman and of an apostle:--Paul, Paulus.
a primary verb ("pause"); to stop (transitively or intransitively), i.e. restrain, quit, desist, come to an end:--cease, leave, refrain.
of uncertain derivation; Paphus, a place in Cyprus:--Paphos.
from a derivative of πήγνυμι (meaning thick); to thicken, i.e. (by implication) to fatten (figuratively, stupefy or render callous):--wax gross.
ultimately from πούς; a shackle for the feet:--fetter.
from a derivative of πούς (meaning the ground); level (as easy for the feet):--plain.
from the same as πεζῇ; to foot a journey, i.e. travel by land:--go afoot.
dative case feminine of a derivative of πούς (as adverb); foot-wise, i.e. by walking:--a- (on) foot.
from a compound of πείθω and ἄρχω; to be persuaded by a ruler, i.e. (genitive case) to submit to authority; by analogy, to conform to advice:--hearken, obey (magistrates).
from πείθω; persuasive:--enticing.

a primary verb; to convince (by argument, true or false); by analogy, to pacify or conciliate (by other fair means); reflexively or passively, to assent (to evidence or authority), to rely (by inward certainty):--agree, assure, believe, have confidence, be (wax) conflent, make friend, obey, persuade, trust, yield.
from the same as πένης (through the idea of pinching toil; "pine"); to famish (absolutely or comparatively); figuratively, to crave:--be an hungered.
from the base of πέραν (through the idea of piercing); a test, i.e. attempt, experience:--assaying, trial.
from πεῖρα; to test (objectively), i.e. endeavor, scrutinize, entice, discipline:--assay, examine, go about, prove, tempt(-er), try.
