from πειράζω; a putting to proof (by experiment (of good), experience (of evil), solicitation, discipline or provocation); by implication, adversity:--temptation, X try.
from πεῖρα; to test (subjectively), i.e. (reflexively) to attempt:--assay.
from a presumed derivative of πείθω; persuadableness, i.e. credulity:--persuasion.
of uncertain affinity; deep or open sea, i.e. the main:--depth, sea.
from a derivative of πλήσσω (meaning an axe); to chop off (the head), i.e. truncate:--behead.
from πέντε; fifth:--fifth.

apparently a primary verb; to dispatch (from the subjective view or point of departure, whereas  (as a stronger form of ) refers rather to the objective point or terminus ad quem, and στέλλω denotes properly, the orderly motion involved), especially on a temporary errand; also to transmit, bestow, or wield:--send, thrust in.
from a primary  (to toil for daily subsistence); starving, i.e. indigent:--poor. Compare πτωχός.
feminine of πενθερός; a wife's mother:--mother in law, wife's mother.
of uncertain affinity; a wife's father:--father in law.
from πένθος; to grieve (the feeling or the act):--mourn, (be-)wail.
strengthened from the alternate of πάσχω; grief:--mourning, sorrow.
prolongation from the base of πένης; necessitous:--poor.
multiplicative adverb from πέντε; five times:--five times.
from πεντάκις and χίλιοι; five times a thousand:--five thousand.
from πέντε and ἑκατόν; five hundred:--five hundred.
a primary number; "five":--five.
from πέντε and καί and δέκατος; five and tenth:--fifteenth.
multiplicative of πέντε; fifty:--fifty.
feminine of the ordinal of πεντήκοντα; fiftieth (ἡμέρα being implied) from Passover, i.e. the festival of "Pentecost":--Pentecost.
from the perfect of the alternate of πάσχω; reliance:--confidence, trust.
from the base of πέραν; an enclitic particle significant of abundance (thoroughness), i.e. emphasis; much, very or ever:--(whom-)soever.
apparently accusative case of an obsolete derivative of  (to "pierce"); through (as adverb or preposition), i.e. across:--beyond, farther (other) side, over.
from the same as πέραν; an extremity:--end, ut-(ter-)most participle
from πύργος; fortified; Pergamus, a place in Asia Minor:--Pergamos.
probably from the same as Πέργαμος; a tower; Perga, a place in Asia Minor:--Perga.

from the base of πέραν; properly, through (all over), i.e. around; figuratively with respect to; used in various applications, of place, cause or time (with the genitive case denoting the subject or occasion or superlative point; with the accusative case the locality, circuit, matter, circumstance or general period):--(there-)about, above, against, at, on behalf of, X and his company, which concern, (as) concerning, for, X how it will go with, ((there-, where-)) of, on, over, pertaining (to), for sake, X (e-)state, (as) touching, (where-)by (in), with. In comparative, it retains substantially the same meaning of circuit (around), excess (beyond), or completeness (through).
from περί and ἄγω; to take around (as a companion); reflexively, to walk around:--compass, go (round) about, lead about.
from περί and αἱρέομαι (including its alternate); to remove all around, i.e. unveil, cast off (anchor); figuratively, to expiate:--take away (up).
from περί and ἀστράπτω; to flash all around, i.e. envelop in light:--shine round (about).
from περί and βάλλω; to throw all around, i.e. invest (with a palisade or with clothing):--array, cast about, clothe(-d me), put on.
from περί and βλέπω; to look all around:--look (round) about (on).
neuter of a presumed derivative of περιβάλλω; something thrown around one, i.e. a mantle, veil:--covering, vesture.
from περί and δέω; to bind around one, i.e. enwrap:--bind about.
from περί and ἐργάζομαι; to work all around, i.e. bustle about (meddle):--be a busybody.
from περί and ἔργον; working all around, i.e. officious (meddlesome, neuter plural magic):--busybody, curious arts.
from περί and ἔρχομαι (including its alternate); to come all around, i.e. stroll, vacillate, veer:--fetch a compass, vagabond, wandering about.
from περί and ἔχω; to hold all around, i.e. include, clasp (figuratively):--+ astonished, contain, after (this manner).
from περί and ζώννυμι; to gird all around, i.e. (middle voice or passive) to fasten on one's belt (literally or figuratively):--gird (about, self).
from περιτίθημι; a putting all around, i.e. decorating oneself with:--wearing.
from περί and ἵστημι; to stand all around, i.e. (near) to be a bystander, or (aloof) to keep away from:--avoid, shun, stand by (round about).
from a compound of περί and καθαίρω; something cleaned off all around, i.e. refuse (figuratively):--filth.
from περί and καλύπτω; to cover all around, i.e. entirely (the face, a surface):--blindfold, cover, overlay.
from περί and κεῖμαι; to lie all around, i.e. inclose, encircle, hamper (literally or figuratively):--be bound (compassed) with, hang about.
feminine of a compound of περί and κεφαλή; encirclement of the head, i.e. a helmet:--helmet.
from περί and κράτος; strong all around, i.e. a master (manager):--+ come by.
from περί and κρύπτω; to conceal all around, i.e. entirely:--hide.
from περί and κυκλόω; to encircle all around, i.e. blockade completely:--compass round.
from περί and λάμπω; to illuminate all around, i.e. invest with a halo:--shine round about.
from περί and λείπω; to leave all around, i.e. (passively) survive:--remain.
from περί and λύπη; grieved all around, i.e. intensely sad:--exceeding (very) sorry(-owful).
from περί and μένω; to stay around, i.e. await:--wait for.
adverb from περί; all around, i.e. (as an adjective) circumjacent:--round about.
from περί and οἰκέω; to reside around, i.e. be a neighbor:--dwell round about.
from περί and οἶκος; housed around, i.e. neighboring (used elliptically as a noun):--neighbour.
from the present participle feminine of a compound of 4012 and εἰμί; being beyond usual, i.e. special (one's own):--peculiar.
from περιέχω; a being held around, i.e. (concretely) a passage (of Scripture, as circumscribed):--place.

from περί and πατέω; to tread all around, i.e. walk at large (especially as proof of ability); figuratively, to live, deport oneself, follow (as a companion or votary):--go, be occupied with, walk (about).
from περί and the base of πέραν; to penetrate entirely, i.e. transfix (figuratively):--pierce through.
from περί and πίπτω; to fall into something that is all around, i.e. light among or upon, be surrounded with:--fall among (into).
middle voice from περί and ποιέω; to make around oneself, i.e. acquire (buy):--purchase.
from περιποιέομαι; acquisition (the act or the thing); by extension, preservation:--obtain(-ing), peculiar, purchased, possession, saving.
from περί and ῥήγνυμι; to tear all around, i.e. completely away:--rend off.
from περί and σπάω; to drag all around, i.e. (figuratively) to distract (with care):--cumber.
from περισσεύω; surplusage, i.e. superabundance:--abundance(-ant, (-ly)), superfluity.
from περισσεύω; a surplus, or superabundance:--abundance, that was left, over and above.

from περισσός; to superabound (in quantity or quality), be in excess, be superfluous; also (transitively) to cause to superabound or excel:--(make, more) abound, (have, have more) abundance (be more) abundant, be the better, enough and to spare, exceed, excel, increase, be left, redound, remain (over and above).

from περί (in the sense of beyond); superabundant (in quantity) or superior (in quality); by implication, excessive; adverbially (with ἐκ) violently; neuter (as noun) preeminence:--exceeding abundantly above, more abundantly, advantage, exceedingly, very highly, beyond measure, more, superfluous, vehement(-ly).
neuter of περισσότερος (as adverb); in a more superabundant way:--more abundantly, a great deal, far more.
comparative of περισσός; more superabundant (in number, degree or character):--more abundant, greater (much) more, overmuch.
adverb from περισσότερος; more superabundantly:--more abundant(-ly), X the more earnest, (more) exceedingly, more frequent, much more, the rather.
adverb from περισσός; superabundantly:--exceedingly, out of measure, the more.
of uncertain derivation; a pigeon:--dove, pigeon.
from περί and the base of τομώτερος; to cut around, i.e. (specially) to circumcise:--circumcise.
from περί and τίθημι; to place around; by implication, to present:--bestow upon, hedge round about, put about (on, upon), set about.
from περιτέμνω; circumcision (the rite, the condition or the people, literally or figuratively):--X circumcised, circumcision.
from περί and the base of τροπή; to turn around, i.e. (mentally) to craze:--+ make mad.
from περί and τρέχω (including its alternate); to run around, i.e. traverse:--run through.
from περί and φέρω; to convey around, i.e. transport hither and thither:--bear (carry) about.
from περί and φρονέω; to think beyond, i.e. depreciate (contemn):--despise.
from περί and χώρα; around the region, i.e. circumjacent (as noun, with γῆ implied vicinity):--country (round) about, region (that lieth) round about.
from a comparative of περί and  (to rub); something brushed all around, i.e. off-scrapings (figuratively, scum):--offscouring.
middle voice from  (braggart; perhaps by reduplication of the base of πέραν); to boast:--vaunt itself.
adverb from πέρας; the by-gone, i.e. (as noun) last year:--+ a year ago.
neuter of a derivative of πέτομαι; a flying animal, i.e. bird:--bird, fowl.
middle voice of a primary verb; to fly:--fly(-ing).
feminine of the same as Πέτρος; a (mass of) rock (literally or figuratively):--rock.
apparently a primary word; a (piece of) rock (larger than λίθος); as a name, Petrus, an apostle:--Peter, rock. Compare Κηφᾶς.
from πέτρα and εἶδος; rock-like, i.e. rocky:--stony.
from πήγνυμι; rue (from its thick or fleshy leaves):--rue.

probably from πήγνυμι (through the idea of gushing plumply); a fount (literally or figuratively), i.e. source or supply (of water, blood, enjoyment) (not necessarily the original spring):--fountain, well.
a prolonged form of a primary verb (which in its simpler form occurs only as an alternate in certain tenses); to fix ("peg"), i.e. (specially) to set up (a tent):--pitch.
neuter of a (presumed) derivative of  (the blade of an oar; from the same as πέδη); a "pedal", i.e. helm:--rudder.
a quantitative form (the feminine) of the base of πού; how much (as an indefinite), i.e. in size or (figuratively) dignity:--how great (large).
perhaps a primary word; clay:--clay.
of uncertain affinity; a wallet or leather pouch for food:--scrip.
of uncertain affinity; the fore-arm, i.e. (as a measure) a cubit:--cubit.
probably another form of βιάζω; to squeeze, i.e. seize (gently by the hand (press), or officially (arrest), or in hunting (capture)):--apprehend, catch, lay hand on, take. Compare πιέζω.
another form for πιάζω; to pack:--press down.
from a compound of a derivative of πείθω and λόγος; persuasive language:--enticing words.
from πικρός; to embitter (literally or figuratively):--be (make) bitter.
from πικρός; acridity (especially poison), literally or figuratively:--bitterness.
perhaps from πήγνυμι (through the idea of piercing); sharp (pungent), i.e. acrid (literally or figuratively):--bitter.
adverb from πικρός; bitterly, i.e. (figuratively) violently:--bitterly.
of Latin origin; close-pressed, i.e. firm; Pilatus, a Roman:--Pilate.

a reduplicated and prolonged form of a primary  ; which occurs only as an alternate in certain tenses); to fire, i.e. burn (figuratively and passively, become inflamed with fever):--be (X should have) swollen.
diminutive of πίναξ; a tablet (for writing on):--writing table.
apparently a form of πλάξ; a plate:--charger, platter.
a prolonged form of        ;  which (together with another form)        ; occurs only as an alternate in certain tenses;  to imbibe (literally or figuratively):--drink.
from  (fat; perhaps akin to the alternate of πίνω through the idea of repletion); plumpness, i.e. (by implication) richness (oiliness):--fatness.
contracted from  (to traverse; from the base of πέραν); to traffic (by travelling), i.e. dispose of as merchandise or into slavery (literally or figuratively):--sell.
probably akin to πέτομαι through the idea of alighting; to fall (literally or figuratively):--fail, fall (down), light on.
probably of foreign origin; Pisidia, a region of Asia Minor:--Pisidia.

from πίστις; to have faith (in, upon, or with respect to, a person or thing), i.e. credit; by implication, to entrust (especially one's spiritual well-being to Christ):--believe(-r), commit (to trust), put in trust with.
from πίστις; trustworthy, i.e. genuine (unadulterated):--spike-(nard).

from πείθω; persuasion, i.e. credence; moral conviction (of religious truth, or the truthfulness of God or a religious teacher), especially reliance upon Christ for salvation; abstractly, constancy in such profession; by extension, the system of religious (Gospel) truth itself:--assurance, belief, believe, faith, fidelity.
from πείθω; objectively, trustworthy; subjectively, trustful:--believe(-ing, -r), faithful(-ly), sure, true.
from πιστός; to assure:--assure of.
from πλάνη; to (properly, cause to) roam (from safety, truth, or virtue):--go astray, deceive, err, seduce, wander, be out of the way.
feminine of πλάνος (as abstractly); objectively, fraudulence; subjectively, a straying from orthodoxy or piety:--deceit, to deceive, delusion, error.
from πλάνος; a rover ("planet"), i.e. (figuratively) an erratic teacher:--wandering.
of uncertain affinity; roving (as a tramp), i.e. (by implication) an impostor or misleader; --deceiver, seducing.
from πλάσσω; a moulding-board, i.e. flat surface ("plate", or tablet, literally or figuratively):--table.
from πλάσσω; something moulded:--thing formed.
a primary verb; to mould, i.e. shape or fabricate:--form.
from πλάσσω; moulded, i.e. (by implication) artificial or (figuratively) fictitious (false):--feigned.
feminine of πλατύς; a wide "plat" or "place", i.e. open square:--street.
from πλατύς; width:--breadth.
from πλατύς; to widen (literally or figuratively):--make broad, enlarge.
from πλάσσω; spread out "flat" ("plot"), i.e. broad:--wide.
from πλέκω; a plait (of hair):--broidered hair.
irregular superlative of πολύς; the largest number or very large:--very great, most.

comparative of πολύς; more in quantity, number, or quality; also (in plural) the major portion:--X above, + exceed, more  excellent, further, (very) great(-er), long(-er), (very) many, greater (more) part, + yet but.
a primary word; to twine or braid:--plait.
from πλείων; to do, make or be more, i.e. increase (transitively or intransitively); by extension, to superabound:--abound, abundant, make to increase, have over.
from πλεονέκτης; to be covetous, i.e. (by implication) to over-reach:--get an advantage, defraud, make a gain.
from πλείων and ἔχω; holding (desiring) more, i.e. eager for gain (avaricious, hence a defrauder):--covetous.
from πλεονέκτης; avarice, i.e. (by implication) fraudulency, extortion:--covetous(-ness) practices, greediness.
of uncertain affinity; a rib, i.e. (by extension) side:--side.
probably a form of πλύνω (through the idea of plunging through the water); to pass in a vessel:--sail. See also πλήθω.
from πλήσσω; a stroke; by implication, a wound; figuratively, a calamity:--plague, stripe, wound(-ed).
from πλήθω; a fulness, i.e. a large number, throng, populace:--bundle, company, multitude.
from another form of πλῆθος; to increase (transitively or intransitively):--abound, multiply.

a prolonged form of a primary            (which appears only as an alternate in                          certain tenses and in the reduplicated form                          pimplemi); to "fill" (literally or figuratively (imbue, influence, supply)); specially, to fulfil (time):--accomplish, full (…come), furnish.
from πλήσσω; a smiter, i.e. pugnacious (quarrelsome):--striker.
prolonged from πλήθω; flood-tide, i.e. (by analogy) a freshet:--flood.
from πλείων; moreover (besides), i.e. albeit, save that, rather, yet:--but (rather), except, nevertheless, notwithstanding, save, than.
from πλήθω; replete, or covered over; by analogy, complete:--full.
from πλήρης and φορέω; to carry out fully (in evidence), i.e. completely assure (or convince), entirely accomplish:--most surely believe, fully know (persuade), make full proof of.
from πληροφορέω; entire confidence:--(full) assurance.

from πλήρης; to make replete, i.e. (literally) to cram (a net), level up (a hollow), or (figuratively) to furnish (or imbue, diffuse, influence), satisfy, execute (an office), finish (a period or task), verify (or coincide with a prediction), etc.:--accomplish, X after, (be) complete, end, expire, fill (up), fulfil, (be, make) full (come), fully preach, perfect, supply.

from πληρόω; repletion or completion, i.e. (subjectively) what fills (as contents, supplement, copiousness, multitude), or (objectively) what is filled (as container, performance, period):--which is put in to fill up, piece that filled up, fulfilling, full, fulness.
neuter of a derivative of  (near); (adverbially) close by; as noun, a neighbor, i.e. fellow (as man, countryman, Christian or friend):--near, neighbour.
from a presumed derivative of πλήθω; a filling up, i.e. (figuratively) gratification:--satisfying.
apparently another form of πλάσσω (through the idea of flattening out); to pound, i.e. (figuratively) to inflict with (calamity):--smite. Compare τύπτω.
neuter of a presumed derivative of πλοῖον; a boat:--boat, little (small) ship.
from πλέω; a sailer, i.e. vessel:--ship(-ing).
from πλέω; a sail, i.e. navigation:--course, sailing, voyage.
from πλοῦτος; wealthy; figuratively, abounding with:--rich.
adverb from πλούσιος; copiously:--abundantly, richly.
from πλουτίζω; to be (or become) wealthy (literally or figuratively):--be increased with goods, (be made, wax) rich.
from πλοῦτος; to make wealthy (figuratively):--en- (make) rich.
from the base of πλήθω; wealth (as fulness), i.e. (literally) money, possessions, or (figuratively) abundance, richness, (specially), valuable bestowment:--riches.
a prolonged form of an obsolete  (to "flow"); to "plunge", i.e. launder clothing:--wash. Compare λούω, νίπτω.

from πνέω; a current of air, i.e. breath (blast) or a breeze; by analogy or figuratively, a spirit, i.e. (human) the rational soul, (by implication) vital principle, mental disposition, etc., or (superhuman) an angel, demon, or (divine) God, Christ's spirit, the Holy Spirit:--ghost, life, spirit(-ual, -ually), mind. Compare ψυχή.
from πνεῦμα; non-carnal, i.e. (humanly) ethereal (as opposed to gross), or (dæmoniacally) a spirit (concretely), or (divinely) supernatural, regenerate, religious:--spiritual. Compare ψυχικός.
adverb from πνευματικός; non-physically, i.e. divinely, figuratively:--spiritually.
a primary word; to breathe hard, i.e. breeze:--blow. Compare ψύχω.
strengthened from πνέω; to wheeze, i.e. (causative, by implication) to throttle or strangle (drown):--choke, take by the throat.
from πνίγω; throttled, i.e. (neuter concretely) an animal choked to death (not bled):--strangled.
from πνέω; respiration, a breeze:--breath, wind.
from πούς and another element of uncertain affinity; a dress (ἐσθής implied) reaching the ankles:--garment down to the foot.
from the base of πόσις with enclitic adverb of origin; from which (as interrogative) or what (as relative) place, state, source or cause:--whence.

apparently a prolonged form of an obsolete primary; to make or do (in a very wide application, more or less direct):--abide, + agree, appoint, X avenge, + band together, be, bear, + bewray, bring (forth), cast out, cause, commit, + content, continue, deal, + without any delay, (would) do(-ing), execute, exercise, fulfil, gain, give, have, hold, X journeying, keep, + lay wait, + lighten the ship, make, X mean, + none of these things move me, observe, ordain, perform, provide, + have purged, purpose, put, + raising up, X secure, shew, X shoot out, spend, take, tarry, + transgress the law, work, yield. Compare πράσσω.
from ποιέω; a product, i.e. fabric (literally or figuratively):--thing that is made, workmanship.
from ποιέω; action, i.e. performance (of the law):--deed.
from ποιέω; a performer; specially, a "poet"; --doer, poet.
of uncertain derivation; motley, i.e. various in character:--divers, manifold.
from ποιμήν; to tend as a shepherd of (figuratively, superviser):--feed (cattle), rule.
of uncertain affinity; a shepherd (literally or figuratively):--shepherd, pastor.
contraction from ποιμαίνω; a flock (literally or figuratively):--flock, fold.
neuter of a presumed derivative of ποίμνη; a flock, i.e. (figuratively) group (of believers):--flock.
from the base of ποῦ and οἷος; individualizing interrogative (of character) what sort of, or (of number) which one:--what (manner of), which.
from πόλεμος; to be (engaged) in warfare, i.e. to battle (literally or figuratively):--fight, (make) war.
from  (to bustle); warfare (literally or figuratively; a single encounter or a series):--battle, fight, war.
probably from the same as πόλεμος, or perhaps from πολύς; a town (properly, with walls, of greater or less size):--city.
from πόλις and ἄρχω; a town-officer, i.e. magistrate:--ruler of the city.
from πολίτης ("polity"); citizenship; concretely, a community:--commonwealth, freedom.
from πολιτεύομαι; a community, i.e. (abstractly) citizenship (figuratively):--conversation.
middle voice of a derivative of πολίτης; to behave as a citizen (figuratively):--let conversation be, live.
from πόλις; a townsman:--citizen.
multiplicative adverb from πολύς; many times, i.e. frequently:--oft(-en, -entimes, -times).
from πολύς and probably a derivative of πλέκω; manifold, i.e. (neuter as noun) very much more:--manifold more.
from a compound of πολύς and λόγος; loquacity, i.e. prolixity:--much speaking.
adverb from a compound of πολύς and μέρος; in many portions, i.e. variously as to time and agency (piecemeal):--at sundry times.
from πολύς and ποικίλος; much variegated, i.e. multifarious:--manifold.

including the forms from the alternate ; (singular) much (in any respect) or (plural) many; neuter (singular) as adverbial, largely; neuter (plural) as adverb or noun often, mostly, largely:--abundant, + altogether, common, + far (passed, spent), (+ be of a) great (age, deal, -ly, while), long, many, much, oft(-en (-times)), plenteous, sore, straitly. Compare πλεῖστος, πλείων.
from πολύς and σπλάγχνον (figuratively); extremely compassionate:--very pitiful.
from πολύς and τέλος; extremely expensive:--costly, very precious, of great price.
from πολύς and τιμή; extremely valuable:--very costly, of great price.
adverb from a compound of πολύς and τρόπος; in many ways, i.e. variously as to method or form:--in divers manners.
from the alternate of πίνω; a beverage:--drink.
from πονηρός; depravity, i.e. (specially), malice; plural (concretely) plots, sins:--iniquity, wickedness.

from a derivative of πόνος; hurtful, i.e. evil (properly, in effect or influence, and thus differing from κακός, which refers rather to essential character, as well as from σαπρός, which indicates degeneracy from original virtue); figuratively, calamitous; also (passively) ill, i.e. diseased; but especially (morally) culpable, i.e. derelict, vicious, facinorous; neuter (singular) mischief, malice, or (plural) guilt; masculine (singular) the devil, or (plural) sinners:--bad, evil, grievous, harm, lewd, malicious, wicked(-ness). See also πονηρότερος.
comparative of πονηρός; more evil:--more wicked.
from the base of πένης; toil, i.e. (by implication) anguish:--pain.
from Πόντος; a Pontican, i.e. native of Pontus:--born in Pontus.
of Latin origin; apparently bridged; Pontius, a Roman:--Pontius.
of Latin origin; a sea; Pontus, a region of Asia Minor:--Pontus.
of Latin origin; apparently "popular"; Poplius (i.e. Publius), a Roman:--Publius.
from πορεύομαι; travel (by land); figuratively (plural) proceedings, i.e. career:--journey(-ing), ways.

middle voice from a derivative of the same as πεῖρα; to traverse, i.e. travel (literally or figuratively; especially to remove (figuratively, die), live, etc.); --depart, go (away, forth, one's way, up), (make a, take a) journey, walk.
prolongation from  (to sack); to ravage (figuratively):--destroy, waste.
from a derivative of  (a way, i.e. means); furnishing (procuring), i.e. (by implication) money-getting (acquisition):--gain.
of Latin origin; apparently swinish; Porcius, a Roman:--Porcius.
from πορνεύω; harlotry (including adultery and incest); figuratively, idolatry:--fornication.
from πόρνη; to act the harlot, i.e. (literally) indulge unlawful lust (of either sex), or (figuratively) practise idolatry:--commit (fornication).
feminine of πόρνος; a strumpet; figuratively, an idolater:--harlot, whore.
from  (to sell; akin to the base of πιπράσκω); a (male) prostitute (as venal), i.e. (by analogy) a debauchee (libertine):--fornicator, whoremonger.
adverb from πρό; forwards, i.e. at a distance:--far, a great way off. See also πόῤῥωθεν.
from πόῤῥω with adverbial enclitic of source; from far, or (by implication) at a distance, i.e. distantly:--afar off.
adverb comparative of πόῤῥω; further, i.e. a greater distance:--farther.
of Latin origin; the "purple" mussel, i.e. (by implication) the red-blue color itself, and finally a garment dyed with it:--purple.
from πορφύρα; purpureal, i.e. bluish red:--purple.
feminine of a compound of πορφύρα and πωλέω; a female trader in purple cloth:--seller of purple.
multiplicative from πόσος; how many times:--how oft(-en).
from the alternate of πίνω; a drinking (the act), i.e. (concretely) a draught:--drink.
from an absolute  (who, what) and ὅς; interrogative pronoun (of amount) how much (large, long or (plural) many):--how great (long, many), what.
probably from a derivative of the alternate of πίνω (compare πότος); a current, brook or freshet (as drinkable), i.e. running water:--flood, river, stream, water.
from ποταμός and a derivative of φορέω; river-borne, i.e. overwhelmed by a stream:--carried away of the flood.
apparently from πότε and the base of ποῦ; interrogatively, whatever, i.e. of what possible sort:--what (manner of).
from the base of πού and τέ; indefinite adverb, at some time, ever:--afore-(any, some-)time(-s), at length (the last), (+ n- )ever, in the old time, in time past, once, when.
from the base of ποῦ and τέ; interrogative adverb, at what time:--+ how long, when.
neuter of a comparative of the base of ποῦ; interrogative as adverb, which (of two), i.e. is it this or that:--whether.
neuter of a derivative of the alternate of πίνω; a drinking-vessel; by extension, the contents thereof, i.e. a cupful (draught); figuratively, a lot or fate:--cup.
from a derivative of the alternate of πίνω; to furnish drink, irrigate:--give (make) to drink, feed, water.
of Latin origin; little wells, i.e. mineral springs; Potioli (i.e. Puteoli), a place in Italy:--Puteoli.
from the alternate of πίνω; a drinking-bout or carousal:--banqueting.
genitive case of an indefinite pronoun  (some) otherwise obsolete (compare πόσος); as adverb of place, somewhere, i.e. nearly:--about, a certain place.

genitive case of an interrogative pronoun  (what) otherwise obsolete (perhaps the same as πού used with the rising slide of inquiry); as adverb of place; at (by implication, to) what locality:--where, whither.
of Latin origin; modest; Pudes (i.e. Pudens), a Christian:--Pudens.
a primary word; a "foot" (figuratively or literally):--foot(-stool).
from πράσσω; a deed; by implication, an affair; by extension, an object (material):--business, matter, thing, work.
from πραγματεύομαι; a transaction, i.e. negotiation:--affair.
from πρᾶγμα; to busy oneself with, i.e. to trade:--occupy.
of Latin origin; the prætorium or governor's courtroom (sometimes including the whole edifice and camp):--(common, judgment) hall (of judgment), palace, prætorium.
from a derivative of πράσσω; a practiser, i.e. (specially), an official collector:--officer.
from πράσσω; practice, i.e. (concretely) an act; by extension, a function:--deed, office, work.
a form of πραΰς, used in certain parts; gentle, i.e. humble:--meek.
from πρᾷος; gentleness, by implication, humility:--meekness.
perhaps from  (a leek, and so an onion-patch); a garden plot, i.e. (by implication, of regular beds) a row (repeated in plural by Hebraism, to indicate an arrangement):--in ranks.

a primary verb; to "practise", i.e. perform repeatedly or habitually (thus differing from ποιέω, which properly refers to a single act); by implication, to execute, accomplish, etc.; specially, to collect (dues), fare (personally):--commit, deeds, do, exact, keep, require, use arts.
apparently a primary word; mild, i.e. (by implication) humble:--meek. See also πρᾷος.
from πραΰς; mildness, i.e. (by implication) humility:--meekness.

apparently a primary verb; to tower up (be conspicuous), i.e. (by implication) to be suitable or proper (third person singular present indicative, often used impersonally, it is fit or right):--become, comely.
from πρεσβεύω; seniority (eldership), i.e. (by implication) an embassy (concretely, ambassadors):--ambassage, message.
from the base of πρεσβύτερος; to be a senior, i.e. (by implication) act as a representative (figuratively, preacher):--be an ambassador.
neuter of a presumed derivative of πρεσβύτερος; the order of elders, i.e. (specially), Israelite Sanhedrin or Christian "presbytery":--(estate of) elder(-s), presbytery.
comparative of  (elderly); older; as noun, a senior; specially, an Israelite Sanhedrist (also figuratively, member of the celestial council) or Christian "presbyter":-- elder(-est), old.
from the same as πρεσβύτερος; an old man:--aged (man), old man.
feminine of πρεσβύτης; an old woman:--aged woman.
from πρό; leaning (falling) forward ("prone"), i.e. head foremost:--headlong.
a strengthened form of a primary prio (to saw); to saw in two:--saw asunder.
adverb from πρό; prior, sooner:--before (that), ere.
of Latin origin; feminine of Priscus, ancient; Priska, a Christian woman:--Prisca. See also Πρίσκιλλα.
diminutive of Πρίσκα; Priscilla (i.e. little Prisca), a Christian woman:--Priscilla.
a primary preposition; "fore", i.e. in front of, prior (figuratively, superior) to:--above, ago, before, or ever. In the comparative, it retains the same significations.
from πρό and ἄγω; to lead forward (magisterially); intransitively, to precede (in place or time (participle, previous)):--bring (forth, out), go before.
from πρό and αἱρέομαι; to choose for oneself before another thing (prefer), i.e. (by implication) to propose (intend):--purpose.
from πρό and a derivative of αἰτία; to accuse already, i.e. previously charge:--prove before.
from πρό and ἀκούω; to hear already,i.e. anticipate:--hear before.
from πρό and ἁμαρτάνω; to sin previously (to conversion):--sin already, heretofore sin.
neuter of a presumed compound of πρό and αὐλή; a forecourt, i.e. vestibule (alley-way):--porch.
from πρό and the base of βάσις; to walk forward, i.e. advance (literally, or in years):--+ be of a great age, go farther (on), be well stricken.
from πρό and βάλλω; to throw forward, i.e. push to the front, germinate:--put forward, shoot forth.
from πρόβατον; relating to sheep, i.e. (a gate) through which they were led into Jerusalem:--sheep (market).
probably neuter of a presumed derivative of προβαίνω; something that walks forward (a quadruped), i.e. (specially), a sheep (literally or figuratively):--sheep(-fold).
from πρό and a reduplicated form of βιάζω; to force forward, i.e. bring to the front, instigate:--draw, before instruct.
from πρό and βλέπω; to look out beforehand, i.e. furnish in advance:--provide.
from πρό and γίνομαι; to be already, i.e. have previousy transpired:--be past.
from πρό and γινώσκω; to know beforehand, i.e. foresee:--foreknow (ordain), know (before).
from προγινώσκω; forethought:--foreknowledge.
from προγίνομαι; an ancestor, (grand-)parent:--forefather, parent.
from πρό and γράφω; to write previously; figuratively, to announce, prescribe:--before ordain, evidently set forth, write (afore, aforetime).
from πρό and δῆλος; plain before all men, i.e. obvious:--evident, manifest (open) beforehand.
from πρό and δίδωμι; to give before the other party has given:--first give.
from προδίδωμι (in the sense of giving forward into another's (the enemy's) hands); a surrender:--betrayer, traitor.
from the alternate of προτρέχω; a runner ahead, i.e. scout (figuratively, precursor):--forerunner.
from πρό and εἴδω; foresee:--foresee, saw before.
from πρό and ἐλπίζω; to hope in advance of other confirmation:--first trust.
from πρό and ἔπω; to say already, to predict:--forewarn, say (speak, tell) before. Compare προερέω.
from πρό and ἐνάρχομαι; to commence already:--begin (before).
middle voice from πρό and ἐπαγγέλλω; to promise of old:--promise before.
from πρό and ἐρέω; used as alternate of προέπω; to say already, predict:--foretell, say (speak, tell) before.
from πρό and ἔρχομαι (including its alternate); to go onward, precede (in place or time):--go before (farther, forward), outgo, pass on.
from πρό and ἑτοιμάζω; to fit up in advance (literally or figuratively):--ordain before, prepare afore.
middle voice from πρό and εὐαγγελίζω; to announce glad news in advance:--preach before the gospel.
middle voice from πρό and ἔχω; to hold oneself before others, i.e. (figuratively) to excel:--be better.
from πρό and ἡγέομαι; to lead the way for others, i.e. show deference:--prefer.
from προτίθεμαι; a setting forth, i.e. (figuratively) proposal (intention); specially, the show-bread (in the Temple) as exposed before God:--purpose, shew(-bread).
from πρό and a derivative of τίθημι; fixed beforehand, i.e. (feminine with ἡμέρα implied) a designated day:--time appointed.
from πρόθυμος; predisposition, i.e. alacrity:--forwardness of mind, readiness (of mind), ready (willing) mind.
from πρό and θυμός; forward in spirit, i.e. predisposed; neuter (as noun) alacrity:--ready, willing.
adverb from πρόθυμος; with alacrity:--willingly.
from πρό and ἵστημι; to stand before, i.e. (in rank) to preside, or (by implication) to practise:--maintain, be over, rule.
middle voice from πρό and καλέω; to call forth to oneself (challenge), i.e. (by implication) to irritate:--provoke.
from πρό and καταγγέλλω; to anounce beforehand, i.e. predict, promise:--foretell, have notice, (shew) before.
from πρό and καταρτίζω; to prepare in advance:--make up beforehand.
from πρό and κεῖμαι; to lie before the view, i.e. (figuratively) to be present (to the mind), to stand forth (as an example or reward):--be first, set before (forth).
from πρό and κηρύσσω; to herald (i.e. proclaim) in advance:--before (first) preach.
from προκόπτω; progress, i.e. advancement (subjectively or objectively):--furtherance, profit.

from πρό and κόπτω; to drive forward (as if by beating), i.e. (figuratively and intransitively) to advance (in amount, to grow; in time, to be well along):--increase, proceed, profit, be far spent, wax.
from a compound of πρό and κρίνω; a prejudgment (prejudice), i.e. prepossession:--prefer one before another.
from πρό and κυρόω; to ratify previously:--confirm before.
from πρό and λαμβάνω; to take in advance, i.e. (literally) eat before others have an opportunity; (figuratively) to anticipate, surprise:--come aforehand, overtake, take before.
from πρό and λέγω; to say beforehand, i.e. predict, forewarn:--foretell, tell before.
from πρό and μαρτύρομαι; to be a witness in advance i.e. predict:--testify beforehand.
from πρό and μελετάω; to premeditate:--meditate before.
from πρό and μεριμνάω; to care (anxiously) in advance:--take thought beforehand.
from πρό and νοιέω; to consider in advance, i.e. look out for beforehand (actively, by way of maintenance for others; middle voice by way of circumspection for oneself):--provide (for).
from προνοέω; forethought, i.e. provident care or supply:--providence, provision.
from πρό and ὁράω; to behold in advance, i.e. (actively) to notice (another) previously, or (middle voice) to keep in (one's own) view:--foresee, see before.
from πρό and ὁρίζω; to limit in advance, i.e. (figuratively) predetermine:--determine before, ordain, predestinate.
from πρό and πάσχω; to undergo hardship previously:--suffer before.
from πρό and πέμπω; to send forward, i.e. escort or aid in travel:--accompany, bring (forward) on journey (way), conduct forth.
from a compound of πρό and πίπτω; falling forward, i.e. headlong (figuratively, precipitate):--heady, rash(-ly).
from πρό and πορεύομαι; to precede (as guide or herald):--go before.

a strengthened form of πρό; a preposition of direction; forward to, i.e. toward (with the genitive case, the side of, i.e. pertaining to; with the dative case, by the side of, i.e. near to; usually with the accusative case, the place, time, occasion, or respect, which is the destination of the relation, i.e. whither or for which it is predicated):--about, according to , against, among, at, because of, before, between, (where-)by, for, X at thy house, in, for intent, nigh unto, of, which pertain to, that, to (the end that), X together, to (you) -ward, unto, with(-in). In the comparative case, it denotes essentially the same applications, namely, motion towards, accession to, or nearness at.
from πρό and σάββατον; a fore-sabbath, i.e. the Sabbath-eve:--day before the sabbath. Compare παρασκευή.
from πρός and a derivative of ἀγορά (mean to harangue); to address, i.e. salute by name:--call.
from πρός and ἄγω; to lead towards, i.e. (transitively) to conduct near (summon, present), or (intransitively) to approach:--bring, draw near.
from προσάγω (compare ἀγωγή); admission:--access.
from πρός and αἰτέω; to ask repeatedly (importune), i.e. solicit:--beg.
from πρός and ἀναβαίνω; to ascend farther, i.e. be promoted (take an upper (more honorable) seat):--go up.
from πρός and ἀναλίσκω; to expend further:--spend.
from πρός and ἀναπληρόω; to fill up further, i.e. furnish fully:--supply.
from πρός and ἀνατίθεμαι; to lay up in addition, i.e. (middle voice and figuratively) to impart or (by implication) to consult:--in conference add, confer.
from πρός and ἀπειλέω; to menace additionally:--i.e. threaten further.
from πρός and δαπανάω; to expend additionally:--spend more.
from πρός and δέομαι; to require additionally, i.e. want further:--need.
from πρός and δέχομαι; to admit (to intercourse, hospitality, credence, or (figuratively) endurance); by implication, to await (with confidence or patience):--accept, allow, look (wait) for, take.
from πρός and dokeuo (to watch); to anticipate (in thought, hope or fear); by implication, to await:--(be in) expect(-ation), look (for), when looked, tarry, wait for.
from προσδοκάω; apprehension (of evil); by implication, infliction anticipated:--expectation, looking after.
from πρός and ἐάω; to permit further progress:--suffer.
from πρός and ἐγγίζω; to approach near:--come nigh.
from a compound of πρός and the base of ἑδραῖος; to sit near, i.e. attend as a servant:--wait at.
from πρός and ἐργάζομαι; to work additionally, i.e. (by implication) acquire besides:--gain.

from πρός and ἔρχομαι (including its alternate); to approach, i.e. (literally) come near, visit, or (figuratively) worship, assent to:--(as soon as he) come (unto), come thereunto, consent, draw near, go (near, to, unto).
from προσεύχομαι; prayer (worship); by implication, an oratory (chapel):--X pray earnestly, prayer.
from πρός and εὔχομαι; to pray to God, i.e. supplicate, worship:--pray (X earnestly, for), make prayer.

from πρός and ἔχω; (figuratively) to hold the mind (3563 implied) towards, i.e. pay attention to, be cautious about, apply oneself to, adhere to:--(give) attend(-ance, -ance at, -ance to, unto), beware, be given to, give (take) heed (to unto); have regard.
from πρός and a derivative of ἧλος; to peg to, i.e. spike fast:--nail to.
from the alternate of προσέρχομαι; an arriver from a foreign region, i.e. (specially), an acceder (convert) to Judaism ("proselyte"):--proselyte.
from πρός and καιρός; for the occasion only, i.e. temporary:--dur-(eth) for awhile, endure for a time, for a season, temporal.
middle voice from πρός and καλέω; to call toward oneself, i.e. summon, invite:--call (for, to, unto).

from πρός and καρτερέω; to be earnest towards, i.e. (to a thing) to persevere, be constantly diligent, or (in a place) to attend assiduously all the exercises, or (to a person) to adhere closely to (as a servitor):--attend (give self) continually (upon), continue (in, instant in, with), wait on (continually).
from προσκαρτερέω; persistancy:--perseverance.
neuter of a presumed compound of πρός and κεφαλή; something for the head, i.e. a cushion:--pillow.
from πρός and κληρόω; to give a common lot to, i.e. (figuratively) to associate with:--consort with.
from a compound of πρός and κλίνω; a leaning towards, i.e. (figuratively) proclivity (favoritism):--partiality.
from πρός and κολλάω; to glue to, i.e. (figuratively) to adhere:--cleave, join (self).
from προσκόπτω; a stub, i.e. (figuratively) occasion of apostasy:--offence, stumbling(-block, (-stone)).
from προσκόπτω; a stumbling, i.e. (figuratively and concretely) occasion of sin:--offence.
from πρός and κόπτω; to strike at, i.e. surge against (as water); specially, to stub on, i.e. trip up (literally or figuratively):--beat upon, dash, stumble (at).
from πρός and κυλιόω; to roll towards, i.e. block against:--roll (to).

from πρός and a probable derivative of κύων (meaning to kiss, like a dog licking his master's hand); to fawn or crouch to, i.e. (literally or figuratively) prostrate oneself in homage (do reverence to, adore):--worship.
from προσκυνέω; an adorer:--worshipper.
from πρός and λαλέω; to talk to, i.e. converse with:--speak to (with).
from πρός and λαμβάνω; to take to oneself, i.e. use (food), lead (aside), admit (to friendship or hospitality):--receive, take (unto).
from προσλαμβάνω; admission:--receiving.
from πρός and μένω; to stay further, i.e. remain in a place, with a person; figuratively, to adhere to, persevere in:--abide still, be with, cleave unto, continue in (with).
from πρός and a derivative of the same as ὁρμή (meaning to tie (anchor) or lull); to moor to, i.e. (by implication) land at:--draw to the shore.
from πρός and ὀφείλω; to be indebted additionally:--over besides.
from πρός and a form of  (to be vexed with something irksome); to feel indignant at:--be grieved at.
from πρός and the same as πεινάω; hungering further, i.e. intensely hungry:--very hungry.
from πρός and πήγνυμι; to fasten to, i.e. (specially), to impale (on a cross):--crucify.
from πρός and πίπτω; to fall towards, i.e. (gently) prostrate oneself (in supplication or homage), or (violently) to rush upon (in storm):--beat upon, fall (down) at (before).
middle voice from πρός and ποιέω; to do forward for oneself, i.e. pretend (as if about to do a thing):--make as though.
from πρός and πορεύομαι; to journey towards, i.e. approach (not the same as προπορεύομαι):--go before.
from πρός and ῥήγνυμι; to tear towards, i.e. burst upon (as a tempest or flood):--beat vehemently against (upon).
from πρός and τάσσω; to arrange towards, i.e. (figuratively) enjoin:--bid, command.
feminine of a derivative of προΐστημι; a patroness, i.e. assistant:--succourer.
from πρός and τίθημι; to place additionally, i.e. lay beside, annex, repeat:--add, again, give more, increase, lay unto, proceed further, speak to any more.
from πρός and τρέχω (including its alternate); to run towards, i.e. hasten to meet or join:--run (thither to, to).
neuter of a presumed derivative of a compound of πρός and φάγω; something eaten in addition to bread, i.e. a relish (specially, fish; compare ὀψάριον):--meat.
from πρό and a derivative of σφάζω; previously (recently) slain (fresh), i.e. (figuratively) lately made:--new.
adverb from πρόσφατος; recently:--lately.
from πρός and φέρω (including its alternate); to bear towards, i.e. lead to, tender (especially to God), treat:--bring (to, unto), deal with, do, offer (unto, up), present unto, put to.
from a presumed compound of πρός and φιλέω; friendly towards, i.e. acceptable:--lovely.
from προσφέρω; presentation; concretely, an oblation (bloodless) or sacrifice:--offering (up).
from πρός and φωνέω; to sound towards, i.e. address, exclaim, summon:--call unto, speak (un-)to.
from a comparative of πρός and  (to pour); a shedding forth, i.e. affusion:--sprinkling.
from πρός and  (to touch); to impinge, i.e. lay a finger on (in order to relieve):--touch.
from προσωπολήπτης; to favor an individual, i.e. show partiality:--have respect to persons.
from πρόσωπον and λαμβάνω; an accepter of a face (individual), i.e. (specially), one exhibiting partiality:--respecter of persons.
from προσωπολήπτης; partiality, i.e. favoritism:--respect of persons.

from πρός and  (the visage, from ὀπτάνομαι); the front (as being towards view), i.e. the countenance, aspect, appearance, surface; by implication, presence, person:--(outward) appearance, X before, countenance, face, fashion, (men's) person, presence.
from πρό and τάσσω; to pre-arrange, i.e. prescribe:--before appoint.
from πρό and  (to stretch); to protend, i.e. tie prostrate (for scourging):--bind.
neuter of πρότερος as adverb (with or without the article); previously:--before, (at the) first, former.
comparative of πρό; prior or previous:--former.
middle voice from πρό and τίθημι; to place before, i.e. (for oneself) to exhibit; (to oneself) to propose (determine):--purpose, set forth.
middle voice from πρό and the base of τροπή; to turn forward for oneself, i.e. encourage:--exhort.
from πρό and τρέχω (including its alternate); to run forward, i.e. outstrip, precede:--outrun, run before.
from πρό and ὑπάρχω; to exist before, i.e. (adverbially) to be or do something previously:--+ be before(-time).
from a compound of πρό and φαίνω; an outward showing, i.e. pretext:--cloke, colour, pretence, show.
from πρό and φέρω; to bear forward, i.e. produce:--bring forth.
from προφήτης ("prophecy"); prediction (scriptural or other):--prophecy, prophesying.
from προφήτης; to foretell events, divine, speak under inspiration, exercise the prophetic office:--prophesy.
from a compound of πρό and φημί; a foreteller ("prophet"); by analogy, an inspired speaker; by extension, a poet:--prophet.
from προφήτης; pertaining to a foreteller ("prophetic"):--of prophecy, of the prophets.
feminine of προφήτης; a female foreteller or an inspired woman:--prophetess.
from πρό and φθάνω; to get an earlier start of, i.e. anticipate:--prevent.
middle voice from πρό and a derivative of χείρ; to handle for oneself in advance, i.e. (figuratively) to purpose:--choose, make.
from πρό and χειροτονέω; to elect in advance:--choose before.
from πρό and χορός; before the dance; Prochorus, a Christian:--Prochorus.
feminine of  (hindmost); the stern of a ship:--hinder part, stern.
adverb from πρό; at dawn; by implication, the day-break watch:--early (in the morning), (in the) morning.
feminine of a derivative of πρωΐ as noun; day-dawn:--early, morning.
from πρωΐ; dawning, i.e. (by analogy) autumnal (showering, the first of the rainy season):--early.
from πρωΐ; pertaining to the dawn, i.e. matutinal:--morning.
feminine of a presumed derivative of πρό as noun; the prow, i.e. forward part of a vessel:--forepart(-ship).
from πρῶτος; to be first (in rank or influence):--have the preeminence.
from πρῶτος and καθέδρα; a sitting first (in the front row), i.e. preeminence in council:--chief (highest, uppermost) seat.
from πρῶτος and κλισία; a reclining first (in the place of honor) at the dinner-bed, i.e. preeminence at meals:--chief (highest, uppermost) room.
neuter of πρῶτος as adverb (with or without ὁ); firstly (in time, place, order, or importance):--before, at the beginning, chiefly (at, at the) first (of all).
contracted superlative of πρό; foremost (in time, place, order or importance):--before, beginning, best, chief(-est), first (of all), former.
from πρῶτος and ἵστημι; one standing first in the ranks, i.e. a captain (champion):--ringleader.
from πρωτότοκος; primogeniture (as a privilege):--birthright.
from πρῶτος and the alternate of τίκτω; first-born (usually as noun, literally or figuratively):--firstbegotten(-born).
a form of πίπτω; to trip, i.e. (figuratively) to err, sin, fail (of salvation):--fall, offend, stumble.
of uncertain derivation; the heel (figuratively):--heel.
neuter of a presumed derivative of πτέρυξ; a winglet, i.e. (figuratively) extremity (top corner):--pinnacle.
from a derivative of πέτομαι (meaning a feather); a wing:--wing.
contraction for πετεινόν; a bird:--bird.
probably akin to the alternate of πίπτω (through the idea of causing to fall) or to πέτομαι (through that of causing to fly away); to scare:--frighten.
from πτοέω; alarm:--amazement.
from  (Ptolemy, after whom it was named); Ptolemais, a place in Palestine:--Ptolemais.
from πτύω; a winnowing-fork (as scattering like spittle):--fan.
from a presumed derivative of πτύω (and thus akin to πτοέω); to frighten:--terrify.
from πτύω; saliva:--spittle.
probably akin to  (to spread; and thus apparently allied to πέτομαι through the idea of expansion, and to 4429 through that of flattening; compare πατέω); to fold, i.e. furl a scroll:--close.
a primary verb (compare πτύσσω); to spit:--spit.
from the alternate of πίπτω; a ruin, i.e. (specially), lifeless body (corpse, carrion):--dead body, carcase, corpse.
from the alternate of πίπτω; a crash, i.e. downfall (literally or figuratively):--fall.
from πτωχεύω; beggary, i.e. indigence (literally or figuratively):--poverty.
from πτωχός; to be a beggar, i.e. (by implication) to become indigent (figuratively):--become poor.

from  (to crouch); akin to πτοέω and the alternate of πίπτω); a beggar (as cringing), i.e. pauper (strictly denoting absolute or public mendicancy, although also used in a qualified or relative sense; whereas πένης properly means only straitened circumstances in private), literally (often as noun) or figuratively (distressed):--beggar(-ly), poor.
from a primary  (the fist as a weapon); the clenched hand, i.e. (only in dative case as adverb) with the fist (hard scrubbing):--oft.
from  (the name of the region where Delphi, the seat of the famous oracle, was located); a Python, i.e. (by analogy, with the supposed diviner there) inspiration (soothsaying):-- divination.
from the same as σκηνοποιός; clasped (thick), i.e. (figuratively) frequent; neuter plural (as adverb) frequently:--often(-er).
from a derivative of the same as πυγμή; to box (with the fist), i.e. contend (as a boxer) at the games (figuratively):--fight.
apparently a primary word; a gate, i.e. the leaf or wing of a folding entrance (literally or figuratively):--gate.
from πύλη; a gate-way, door-way of a building or city; by implication, a portal or vestibule:--gate, porch.

middle voice prolonged from a primary  (which occurs only as an alternate in certain tenses); to question, i.e. ascertain by inquiry (as a matter of information merely; and thus differing from ἐρωτάω, which properly means a request as a favor; and from αἰτέω, which is strictly a demand for something due; as well as from ζητέω, which implies a search for something hidden; and from δέομαι, which involves the idea of urgent need); by implication, to learn (by casual intelligence):--ask, demand, enquire, understand.
a primary word; "fire" (literally or figuratively, specially, lightning):--fiery, fire.
from πῦρ; a fire (concretely):--fire.
apparently a primary word ("burgh"); a tower or castle:--tower.
from πυρά; to be on fire, i.e. (specially), to have a fever:--be sick of a fever.
from πυρέσσω; inflamed, i.e. (by implication) feverish (as noun, fever):--fever.
from πυρά; fiery, i.e. (by implication) flaming:--of fire.
from πῦρ; to kindle, i.e. (passively) to be ignited, glow (literally), be refined (by implication), or (figuratively) to be inflamed (with anger, grief, lust):--burn, fiery, be on fire, try.
from πυῤῥός; to redden (intransitively):--be red.
from πῦρ; fire-like, i.e. (specially), flame- colored:--red.
from πυρόω; ignition, i.e. (specially), smelting (figuratively, conflagration, calamity as a test):--burning, trial.
another form of the base of -πώς; an enclitic particle of indefiniteness; yet, even; used only in the comparative. See μηδέπω, μήπω, οὐδέπω, οὔπω, πώποτε.
probably ultimately from  (to be busy, to trade); to barter (as a pedlar), i.e. to sell:--sell, whatever is sold.
apparently a primary word; a "foal" or "filly", i.e. (specially), a young ass:--colt.
from -πω and ποτέ; at any time, i.e. (with negative particle) at no time:--at any time, + never (…to any man), + yet, never man.
apparently from  (a kind of stone); to petrify, i.e. (figuratively) to indurate (render stupid or callous):-- blind, harden.
from πωρόω; stupidity or callousness:--blindness, hardness.
adverb from the base of πού; an enclitic particle of indefiniteness of manner; somehow or anyhow; used only in composition:--haply, by any (some) means, perhaps. See εἴ πως, μήπως. Compare πῶς.

adverb from the base of ποῦ; an interrogative particle of manner; in what way? (sometimes the question is indirect, how?); also as exclamation, how much!:--how, after (by) what manner (means), that. (Occasionally unexpressed in English).
of Hebrew origin (רָחָב); Raab (i.e. Rachab), a Canaanitess:--Rahab. See also Ῥαχάβ.
of Hebrew origin (רַב with pronominal suffix); my master, i.e Rabbi, as an official title of honor:--Master, Rabbi.
of Chaldee origin; corresponding to ῥαββί:--Lord, Rabboni.
from ῥάβδος; to strike with a stick, i.e. bastinado:--beat (with rods).
from the base of ῥαπίζω; a stick or wand (as a cudgel, a cane or a baton of royalty):--rod, sceptre, staff.
from ῥάβδος and ἔχω; a rod- (the Latin fasces) holder, i.e. a Roman lictor (constable or executioner):--serjeant.
of Hebrew origin (רְעוּ); Ragau (i.e. Reu), a patriarch:--Ragau.
from a comparative of  (easy, i.e. reckless) and ἔργον; easy-going behavior, i.e. (by extension) a crime:--lewdness.
from the same as ῥᾳδιούργημα; recklessness, i.e. (by extension) malignity:--mischief.
of Chaldee origin (compare רֵיק); O empty one, i.e. thou worthless (as a term of utter vilification):--Raca.
from ῥήγνυμι; a "rag," i.e. piece of cloth:--cloth.
of Hebrew origin (רָמָה); Rama (i.e. Ramah), a place in Palestine:--Rama.
from a derivative of  (to sprinkle); to render besprinkled, i.e. asperse (ceremonially or figuratively):-- sprinkle.
from ῥαντίζω; aspersion (ceremonially or figuratively):--sprinkling.
from a derivative of a primary  (to let fall, "rap"); to slap:--smite (with the palm of the hand). Compare τύπτω.
from ῥαπίζω; a slap:--(+ strike with the) palm of the hand, smite with the hand.
from a primary  (to sew; perhaps rather akin to the base of ῥαπίζω through the idea of puncturing); a needle:-- needle.
from the same as Ῥαάβ; Rachab, a Canaanitess:--Rachab.
of Hebrew origin (רָחֵל); Rachel, the wife of Jacob:--Rachel.
of Hebrew origin (רִבְקָה); Rebecca (i.e. Ribkah), the wife of Isaac:--Rebecca.
of Latin origin; a rheda, i.e. four-wheeled carriage (wagon for riding):--chariot.
by incorrect transliteration for a word of Hebrew origin (כִּיּוּן); Remphan (i.e. Kijun), an Egyptian idol:--Remphan.
a primary verb; for some tenses of which a prolonged form         is used to flow ("run"; as water):--flow.
ἔπωperhaps akin (or identical) with ῥέω (through the idea of pouring forth); to utter, i.e. speak or say:--command, make, say, speak (of). Compare λέγω.
of Latin origin; Rhegium, a place in Italy:--Rhegium.
from ῥήγνυμι; something torn, i.e. a fragment (by implication and abstractly, a fall):--ruin.

both prolonged forms of  (which appears only in certain forms, and is itself probably a strengthened form of agnumi (see in κατάγνυμι)); to "break," "wreck" or "crack", i.e. (especially) to sunder (by separation of the parts; κατάγνυμι being its intensive (with the preposition in composition), and θραύω a shattering to minute fragments; but not a reduction to the constituent particles, like λύω) or disrupt, lacerate; by implication, to convulse (with spasms); figuratively, to give vent to joyful emotions:--break (forth), burst, rend, tear.

from ῥέω; an utterance (individually, collectively or specially),; by implication, a matter or topic (especially of narration, command or dispute); with a negative naught whatever:--+ evil, + nothing, saying, word.
probably of Hebrew origin (apparently for רְפָיָה); Resa (i.e. Rephajah), an Israelite:--Rhesa.
from ῥέω; a speaker, i.e. (by implication) a forensic advocate:--orator.
adverb from a derivative of ῥέω; out-spokenly, i.e. distinctly:--expressly.
apparently a primary word; a "root" (literally or figuratively):--root.
from ῥίζα; to root (figuratively, become stable):--root.
from ῥίπτω; a jerk (of the eye, i.e. (by analogy) an instant):--twinkling.
from a derivative of ῥίπτω (meaning a fan or bellows); to breeze up, i.e. (by analogy) to agitate (into waves):--toss.
from a derivative of ῥίπτω; to toss up:--cast off.

a primary verb (perhaps rather akin to the base of ῥαπίζω, through the idea of sudden motion); to fling (properly, with a quick toss, thus differing from βάλλω, which denotes a deliberate hurl; and from  (see in ἐκτείνω), which indicates an extended projection); by qualification, to deposit (as if a load); by extension, to disperse:--cast (down, out), scatter abroad, throw.
of Hebrew origin (רְחַבְעָם); Roboam (i.e. Rechobam), an Israelite:--Roboam.
probably for rhode (a rose); Rode, a servant girl:--Rhoda.
probably from  (a rose); Rhodus, an island of the Mediterranean:--Rhodes.
adverb from a derivative of  (a whir); whizzingly, i.e. with a crash:--with a great noise.
probably of foreign origin; a sabre, i.e. a long and broad cutlass (any weapon of the kind, literally or figuratively):--sword.
of Hebrew origin (רְאוּבֵן); Ruben (i.e. Reuben), an Israelite:--Reuben.
of Hebrew origin (רוּת); Ruth, a Moabitess:--Ruth.
of Latin origin; red; Rufus, a Christian:--Rufus.
prolongation from ῥύομαι in its original sense; an alley or avenue (as crowded):--lane, street.
middle voice of an obsolete verb, akin to ῥέω (through the idea of a current; compare ῥύσις); to rush or draw (for oneself), i.e. rescue:--deliver(-er).
from ῥυπαρός; dirtiness (morally):--turpitude.
from ῥύπος; dirty, i.e. (relatively) cheap or shabby; morally, wicked:--vile.
of uncertain affinity; dirt, i.e. (morally) depravity:--filth.
from ῥύπος; to soil, i.e. (intransitively) to become dirty (morally):--be filthy.
from ῥύομαι in the sense of its congener ῥέω; a flux (of blood):--issue.
from ῥύομαι; a fold (as drawing together), i.e. a wrinkle (especially on the face):--wrinkle.
from Ῥωμαῖος; Romaic, i.e. Latin:--Latin.
from Ῥώμη; Romæan, i.e. Roman (as noun):--Roman, of Rome.
adverb from a presumed derivative of Ῥώμη; Romaistically, i.e. in the Latin language:--Latin.
from the base of ῥώννυμι; strength; Roma, the capital of Italy:--Rome.
prolongation from  (to dart; probably akin to ῥύομαι); to strengthen, i.e. (impersonal passive) have health (as a parting exclamation, good-bye):--farewell.
of Chaldee or (שְׁבַק with pronominal suffix); thou hast left me; sabachthani (i.e. shebakthani), a cry of distress:--sabachthani.
of Hebrew origin (צָבָא in feminine plural); armies; sabaoth (i.e. tsebaoth), a military epithet of God:--sabaoth.
from a derivative of σάββατον; a "sabbatism", i.e. (figuratively) the repose of Christianity (as a type of heaven):--rest.

of Hebrew origin (שַׁבָּת); the Sabbath (i.e. Shabbath), or day of weekly repose from secular avocations (also the observance or institution itself); by extension, a se'nnight, i.e. the interval between two Sabbaths; likewise the plural in all the above applications:--sabbath (day), week.
from a derivative of  (to equip) meaning furniture, especially a pack-saddle (which in the East is merely a bag of netted rope); a "seine" for fishing:--net.
probably from Σαδώκ; a Sadducæan (i.e. Tsadokian), or follower of a certain heretical Israelite:--Sadducee.
of Hebrew origin (צָדוֹק); Sadoc (i.e. Tsadok), an Israelite:--Sadoc.
akin to σείω; to wag (as a dog its tail fawningly), i.e. (generally) to shake (figuratively, disturb):--move.
of Hebrew origin (שַׂק); "sack"-cloth, i.e. mohair (the material or garments made of it, worn as a sign of grief):-- sackcloth.
of Hebrew origin (שֶׁלַח); Sala (i.e. Shelach), a patriarch :--Sala.
of Hebrew origin (שְׁאַלְתִּיאֵל); Salathiel (i.e. Shealtiel), an Israelite:--Salathiel.
probably from σάλος (from the surge on the shore); Salamis, a place in Cyprus:--Salamis.
probably from the same as σαλεύω; Salim, a place in Palestine:--Salim.
from σάλος; to waver, i.e. agitate, rock, topple or (by implication) destroy; figuratively, to disturb, incite:--move, shake (together), which can(-not) be shaken, stir up.
of Hebrew origin (שָׁלֵם); Salem (i.e. Shalem), a place in Palestine:--Salem.
of Hebrew origin (שַׂלְמוֹן); Salmon, an Israelite:--Salmon.
perhaps of similar origin to Σαλαμίς; Salmone, a place in Crete:--Salmone.
probably from the base of σαίνω; a vibration, i.e. (specially), billow:--wave.
perhaps from σάλος (through the idea of quavering or reverberation); a trumpet:--trump(-et).
from σάλπιγξ; to trumpet, i.e. sound a blast (literally or figuratively):--(which are yet to) sound (a trumpet).
from σαλπίζω; a trumpeter:--trumpeter.
probably of Hebrew origin (feminine from שָׁלוֹם); Salome (i.e. Shelomah), an Israelitess:--Salome.
of Hebrew origin (שֹׁמְרוֹן); Samaria (i.e. Shomeron), a city and region of Palestine:--Samaria.
from Σαμάρεια; a Samarite, i.e. inhabitant of Samaria:--Samaritan.
feminine of Σαμαρείτης; a Samaritess, i.e. woman of Samaria:--of Samaria.
from Σάμος and  (Thrace); Samo-thrace (Samos of Thrace), an island in the Mediterranean:--Samothracia.
of uncertain affinity; Samus, an island of the Mediterranean:--Samos.
of Hebrew origin (שְׁמוּאֵל); Samuel (i.e. Shemuel), an Israelite:--Samuel.
of Hebrew origin (שִׁמְשׁוֹן); Sampson (i.e. Shimshon), an Israelite:--Samson.
neuter of a derivative of  (a "sandal"; of uncertain origin); a slipper or sole-pad:--sandal.
of uncertain affinity; a plank:--board.
of Hebrew origin (שָׁאוּל); Saul (i.e. Shaul), the Jewish name of Paul:--Saul. Compare Σαῦλος.
from σήπω; rotten, i.e. worthless (literally or morally):--bad, corrupt. Compare πονηρός.
feminine of σάπφειρος; Sapphire, an Israelitess:--Sapphira.
of Hebrew origin (סַפִּיר); a "sapphire" or lapis-lazuli gem:--sapphire.
apparently of Hebrew origin (שָׂרַג); a basket (as interwoven or wicker-work:--basket.
plural of uncertain derivation; Sardis, a place in Asia Minor:--Sardis.
from the same as σάρδιος; sardine (λίθος being implied), i.e. a gem, so called:--sardine.
properly, an adjective from an uncertain base; sardian (3037 being implied), i.e. (as noun) the gem so called:--sardius.
from the base of σάρδιος and  (the nail of a finger; hence the "onyx" stone); a "sardonyx", i.e. the gem so called:-- sardonyx.
of Hebrew origin (צָרְפַת); Sarepta (i.e. Tsarephath), a place in Palestine:--Sarepta.
from σάρξ; pertaining to flesh, i.e. (by extension) bodily, temporal, or (by implication) animal, unregenerate:--carnal, fleshly.
from σάρξ; similar to flesh, i.e. (by analogy) soft:--fleshly.

probably from the base of σαρόω; flesh (as stripped of the skin), i.e. (strictly) the meat of an animal (as food), or (by extension) the body (as opposed to the soul (or spirit), or as the symbol of what is external, or as the means of kindred), or (by implication) human nature (with its frailties (physically or morally) and passions), or (specially), a human being (as such):--carnal(-ly, + -ly minded), flesh(-ly).
of Hebrew origin (שְׂרוּג); Saruch (i.e. Serug), a patriarch:--Saruch.
from a derivative of  (to brush off; akin to σύρω); meaning a broom; to sweep:--sweep.
of Hebrew origin (שָׂרָה); Sarra (i.e. Sarah), the wife of Abraham:--Sara, Sarah.
of Hebrew origin (שָׁרוֹן); Saron (i.e. Sharon), a district of Palestine:--Saron.
of Hebrew origin (שָׂטָן); Satan, i.e. the devil:--Satan. Compare Σατανᾶς.
of Chaldee origin corresponding to מַעְבָּד (with the definite affix); the accuser, i.e. the devil:--Satan.
of Hebrew origin (סְאָה); a certain measure for things dry:--measure.
of Hebrew origin, the same as Σαούλ; Saulus (i.e. Shaul), the Jewish name of Paul:--Saul.
a prolonged form of an apparently primary verb; to extinguish (literally or figuratively):--go out, quench.
accusative case singular of σύ; thee:--thee, thou, X thy house.

genitive case from σέ and αὐτός,                             also dative case of the same,        ,  and accusative case        , likewise contracted        ,        ,     and        ,    respectively; of (with, to) thyself:--thee, thine own self, (thou) thy(-self).
middle voice from a derivative of σέβομαι; to venerate, i.e. adore:--worship.
from σεβάζομαι; something adored, i.e. an object of worship (god, altar, etc):--devotion, that is worshipped.
from σεβάζομαι; venerable (august), i.e. (as noun) a title of the Roman Emperor, or (as adjective) imperial:--Augustus(-').
middle voice of an apparently primary verb; to revere, i.e. adore:--devout, religious, worship.
probably from σύρω through its congener  (to fasten; akin to αἱρέομαι); a chain (as binding or drawing):--chain.
from σείω; a commotion, i.e. (of the air) a gale, (of the ground) an earthquake:--earthquake, tempest.

apparently a primary verb; to rock (vibrate, properly, sideways or to and fro), i.e. (generally) to agitate (in any direction; cause to tremble); figuratively, to throw into a tremor (of fear or concern):--move, quake, shake.
of Latin origin; "second"; Secundus, a Christian:--Secundus.
from  (Seleucus, a Syrian king); Seleuceia, a place in Syria:--Seleucia.
from  (brilliancy; probably akin to the alternate of αἱρέομαι, through the idea of attractiveness); the moon:--moon.
middle voice or passive from a presumed derivative of σελήνη; to be moon-struck, i.e. crazy:--be a lunatic.
of Hebrew origin (שִׁמְעִי); Semei (i.e. Shimi), an Israelite:--Semei.
probably of foreign origin; fine wheaten flour:--fine flour.
from σέβομαι; venerable, i.e. honorable:--grave, honest.
from σεμνός; venerableness, i.e. probity:--gravity, honesty.
of Latin origin; Sergius, a Roman:--Sergius.
of Hebrew origin (שֵׁת); Seth (i.e. Sheth), a patriarch:--Seth.
of Hebrew origin (שֵׁם); Sem (i.e. Shem), a patriarch:-- Sem.
from  (a mark; of uncertain derivation); to indicate:--signify.
neuter of a presumed derivative of the base of σημαίνω; an indication, especially ceremonially or supernaturally:--miracle, sign, token, wonder.
from σημεῖον; to distinguish, i.e. mark (for avoidance):--note.

neuter (as adverb) of a presumed compound of the article ὁ  (t changed to s) and ἡμέρα; on the (i.e. this) day (or night current or just passed); generally, now (i.e. at present, hitherto):--this (to-)day.
apparently a primary verb; to putrefy, i.e. (figuratively) perish:--be corrupted.
from  (an Indian tribe from whom silk was procured; hence the name of the silk-worm); Seric, i.e. silken (neuter as noun, a silky fabric):--silk.
apparently of Hebrew origin (סָס); a moth:--moth.
from σής and a derivative of βιβρώσκω; moth-eaten:--motheaten.
from  (bodily vigor; probably akin to the base of ἵστημι); to strengthen, i.e. (figuratively) confirm (in spiritual knowledge and power):--strengthen.
of uncertain derivation; the jaw-bone, i.e. (by implication) the cheek or side of the face:--cheek.
from σιγή; to keep silent (transitively or intransitively):--keep close (secret, silence), hold peace.
apparently from  (to hiss, i.e. hist or hush); silence:--silence. Compare σιωπάω.
from σίδηρος; made of iron:--(of) iron.
of uncertain derivation; iron:--iron.
of Hebrew origin (צִידוֹן); Sidon (i.e. Tsidon), a place in Palestine:--Sidon.
from Σιδών; a Sidonian, i.e. inhabitant of Sidon:--of Sidon.
of Latin origin; a dagger-man or assassin; a freebooter (Jewish fanatic outlawed by the Romans):--murderer. Compare φονεύς.
of Hebrew origin (שֵׁכָר); an intoxicant, i.e. intensely fermented liquor:--strong drink.
contraction for Σιλουανός; Silas, a Christian:--Silas.
of Latin origin; "silvan"; Silvanus, a Christian:--Silvanus. Compare Σίλας.
of Hebrew origin (שִׁלֹחַ); Siloam (i.e. Shiloach), a pool of Jerusalem:--Siloam.
of Latin origin; a semicinctium or half-girding, i.e. narrow covering (apron):--apron.
of Hebrew origin (שִׁמְעוֹן); Simon (i.e. Shimon), the name of nine Israelites:--Simon. Compare Συμεών.
of Hebrew origin (סִינַי); Sina (i.e. Sinai), a mountain in Arabia:--Sina.
perhaps from  (to hurt, i.e. sting); mustard (the plant):--mustard.
of uncertain (perhaps foreign) origin; byssos, i.e. bleached linen (the cloth or a garment of it):--(fine) linen (cloth).
from  (a sieve); to riddle (figuratively):--sift.
from a derivative of σῖτος; grain-fed, i.e. fattened:--fatted.
from a derivative of σῖτος; grained, i.e. fatted:--fatling.
from σῖτος and μέτρον; a grain-measure, i.e. (by implication) ration (allowance of food):--portion of meat.
of uncertain derivation; grain, especially wheat:--corn, wheat.
of Hebrew origin (צִיּוֹן); Sion (i.e. Tsijon), a hill of Jerusalem; figuratively, the Church (militant or triumphant):--Sion.

from  (silence, i.e. a hush; properly, muteness, i.e. involuntary stillness, or inability to speak; and thus differing from σιγή, which is rather a voluntary refusal or indisposition to speak, although the terms are often used synonymously); to be dumb (but not deaf also, like 2974 properly); figuratively, to be calm (as quiet water):--dumb, (hold) peace.
from σκάνδαλον; to entrap, i.e. trip up (figuratively, stumble (transitively) or entice to sin, apostasy or displeasure):--(make to) offend.

("scandal"); probably from a derivative of κάμπτω; a  trap-stick (bent sapling), i.e. snare (figuratively, cause of displeasure or sin):--occasion to fall (of stumbling), offence, thing that offends, stumblingblock.
apparently a primary verb; to dig:--dig.
apparently from  (to parch; through the idea of leanness); the leg (as lank):--leg.
from a derivative of  (a covering; perhaps akin to the base of σκοπός through the idea of noticeableness); clothing:--raiment.
apparently of Latin origin; left-handed; Scevas (i.e. Scævus), an Israelite:--Sceva.
from σκεῦος; furniture, i.e. spare tackle:--tackling.
of uncertain affinity; a vessel, implement, equipment or apparatus (literally or figuratively [specially, a wife as contributing to the usefulness of the husband]):--goods, sail, stuff, vessel.
apparently akin to σκεῦος and σκιά; a tent or cloth hut (literally or figuratively):--habitation, tabernacle.
from σκῆνος and πήγνυμι; the Festival of Tabernacles (so called from the custom of erecting booths for temporary homes):--tabernacles.
from σκηνή and ποιέω; a manufacturer of tents:--tent-maker.
from σκηνή; a hut or temporary residence, i.e. (figuratively) the human body (as the abode of the spirit):--tabernacle.
from σκῆνος; to tent or encamp, i.e. (figuratively) to occupy (as a mansion) or (specially), to reside (as God did in the Tabernacle of old, a symbol of protection and communion):-- dwell.
from σκηνόω; an encampment, i.e. (figuratively) the Temple (as God's residence), the body (as a tenement for the soul):-- tabernacle.
apparently a primary word; "shade" or a shadow (literally or figuratively (darkness of error or an adumbration)):-- shadow.
akin to  (to skip); to jump, i.e. sympathetically move (as the quickening of a fetus):--leap (for joy).
feminine of a compound of σκληρός and καρδία; hard-heartedness, i.e. (specially), destitution of (spiritual) perception:--hardness of heart.
from the base of σκέλος; dry, i.e. hard or tough (figuratively, harsh, severe):--fierce, hard.
from σκληρός; callousness, i.e. (figuratively) stubbornness:--hardness.
from σκληρός and τράχηλος; hardnaped, i.e. (figuratively) obstinate:--stiffnecked.
from σκληρός; to indurate, i.e. (figuratively) render stubborn:--harden.
from the base of σκέλος; warped, i.e. winding; figuratively, perverse:--crooked, froward, untoward.
perhaps from the base of σκέλος and ὀπτάνομαι; withered at the front, i.e. a point or prickle (figuratively, a bodily annoyance or disability):--thorn.
from σκοπός; to take aim at (spy), i.e. (figuratively) regard:--consider, take heed, look at (on), mark. Compare ὀπτάνομαι.
from  (to peer about ("skeptic"); perhaps akin to σκάπτω through the idea of concealment; compare σκέπασμα); a watch (sentry or scout), i.e. (by implication) a goal:--mark.
apparently from the same as σκορπίος (through the idea of penetrating); to dissipate, i.e. (figuratively) put to flight, waste, be liberal:--disperse abroad, scatter (abroad).
probably from an obsolete  (perhaps strengthened from the base of σκοπός and meaning to pierce); a "scorpion" (from its sting):--scorpion.
from σκότος; opaque, i.e. (figuratively) benighted:--dark, full of darkness.
from σκότος; dimness, obscurity (literally or figuratively):--dark(-ness).
from σκότος; to obscure (literally or figuratively):--darken.
from the base of σκιά; shadiness, i.e. obscurity (literally or figuratively):--darkness.
from σκότος; to obscure or blind (literally or figuratively):--be full of darkness.
neuter of a presumed derivative of εἰς and κύων and βάλλω; what is thrown to the dogs, i.e. refuse (ordure):--dung.
probably of foreign origin; a Scythene or Scythian, i.e. (by implication) a savage:--Scythian.
from  (sullen) and a derivative of ὀπτάνομαι; angry-visaged, i.e. gloomy or affecting a mournful appearance:--of a sad countenance.
apparently a primary verb; to flay, i.e. (figuratively) to harass:--trouble(self).
neuter from σκύλλω; something stripped (as a hide), i.e. booty:--spoil.
from σκώληξ and a derivative of βιβρώσκω; worm-eaten, i.e. diseased with maggots:--eaten of worms.
of uncertain derivation; a grub, maggot or earth-worm:--worm.
from σμάραγδος; consisting of emerald:--emerald.
of uncertain derivation; the emerald or green gem so called:--emerald.
apparently strengthened for μύρον; myrrh:--myrrh.
the same as σμύρνα; Smyrna, a place in Asia Minor:--Smyrna.
from Σμύρνα; a Smyrnæan:--in Smyrna.
from Σμύρνα; to tincture with myrrh, i.e. embitter (as a narcotic):--mingle with myrrh.
plural of Hebrew origin (סְדֹם); Sodoma (i.e. Sedom), a place in Palestine:--Sodom.
dative case of σύ; to thee:--thee, thine own, thou, thy.
of Hebrew origin (שְׁלֹמֹה); Solomon (i.e. Shelomoh), the son of David:--Solomon.
probably akin to the base of σωρεύω; a funereal receptacle (urn, coffin), i.e. (by analogy) a bier:--bier.
from σύ; thine:--thine (own), thy (friend).
genitive case of σύ; of thee, thy:--X home, thee, thine (own), thou, thy.
of Latin origin; a sudarium (sweat-cloth), i.e. towel (for wiping the perspiration from the face, or binding the face of a corpse):--handkerchief, napkin.
of Hebrew origin (שׁוּשַׁן feminine); lily; Susannah (i.e. Shoshannah), an Israelitess:--Susanna.
from σοφός; wisdom (higher or lower, worldly or spiritual):--wisdom.
from σοφός; to render wise; in a sinister acceptation, to form "sophisms", i.e. continue plausible error:--cunningly devised, make wise.
akin to  (clear); wise (in a most general application):--wise. Compare φρόνιμος.
probably of foreign origin; Spania, a region of Europe:--Spain.
prolongation from  (to grasp; apparently strengthened from σπάω through the idea of spasmodic contraction); to mangle, i.e. convluse with epilepsy:--rend, tear.
from  (a strip; from a derivative of the base of σπαράσσω meaning to strap or wrap with strips); to swathe (an infant after the Oriental custom):--wrap in swaddling clothes.
from  (luxury); to be voluptuous:--live in pleasure, be wanton.
a primary verb; to draw:--draw (out).

of immediate Latin origin, but ultimately a derivative of αἱρέομαι in the sense of its cognate εἱλίσσω; a coil (spira, "spire"), i.e. (figuratively) a mass of men (a Roman military cohort; also (by analogy) a squad of Levitical janitors):--band.
probably strengthened from σπάω (through the idea of extending); to scatter, i.e. sow (literally or figuratively):--sow(- er), receive seed.
of Latin origin; a speculator, i.e. military scout (spy or (by extension) life-guardsman):--executioner.
apparently a primary verb; to pour out as a libation, i.e. (figuratively) to devote (one's life or blood, as a sacrifice) ("spend"):--(be ready to) be offered.
from σπείρω; something sown, i.e. seed (including the male "sperm"); by implication, offspring; specially, a remnant (figuratively, as if kept over for planting):--issue, seed.
from σπέρμα and λέγω; a seed-picker (as the crow), i.e. (figuratively) a sponger, loafer (specially, a gossip or trifler in talk):--babbler.
probably strengthened from πούς; to "speed" ("study"), i.e. urge on (diligently or earnestly); by implication, to await eagerly:--(make, with) haste unto.
neuter of a presumed derivative of  (a grotto); a cavern; by implication, a hiding-place or resort:--cave, den.
of uncertain derivation; a ledge or reef of rock in the sea:--spot (by confusion with σπίλος).
from σπίλος; to stain or soil (literally or figuratively):--defile, spot.
of uncertain derivation; a stain or blemish, i.e. (figuratively) defect, disgrace:--spot.
middle voice from σπλάγχνον; to have the bowels yearn, i.e. (figuratively) feel sympathy, to pity:--have (be moved with) compassion.
probably strengthened from  (the "spleen"); an intestine (plural); figuratively, pity or sympathy:--bowels, inward affection, + tender mercy.
perhaps of foreign origin; a "sponge":--spunge.
of uncertain derivation; ashes:--ashes.
from σπείρω; a sowing, i.e. (by implication) parentage:--seed.
from σπόρος; sown, i.e. (neuter plural) a planted field:--corn(-field).
from σπείρω; a scattering (of seed), i.e. (concretely) seed (as sown):--seed (X sown).
from σπουδή; to use speed, i.e. to make effort, be prompt or earnest:--do (give) diligence, be diligent (forward), endeavour, labour, study.
from σπουδή; prompt, energetic, earnest:--diligent.
neuter of σπουδαιότερος as adverb; more earnestly than others), i.e. very promptly:--very diligently.
comparative of σπουδαῖος; more prompt, more earnest:--more diligent (forward).
adverb from σπουδαιότερος; more speedily, i.e. sooner than otherwise:--more carefully.
adverb from σπουδαῖος; earnestly, promptly:--diligently, instantly.
from σπεύδω; "speed", i.e. (by implication) despatch, eagerness, earnestness:--business, (earnest) care(-fulness), diligence, forwardness, haste.
from σπείρω (as woven); a hamper or lunch-receptacle:--basket.
from the base of ἵστημι (as fixed); a stade or certain measure of distance; by implication, a stadium or race-course:--furlong, race.
from the base of ἵστημι (as stationary); a jar or earthen tank:--pot.

from the base of ἵστημι; a standing (properly, the act), i.e. (by analogy) position (existence); by implication, a popular uprising; figuratively, controversy:--dissension, insurrection, X standing, uproar.
from the base of καύχησις; a stander (standard of value), i.e. (specially), a stater or certain coin:--piece of money.

from the base of ἵστημι; a stake or post (as set upright), i.e. (specially), a pole or cross (as an instrument of capital punishment); figuratively, exposure to death, i.e. self-denial; by implication, the atonement of Christ:--cross.
from σταυρός; to impale on the cross; figuratively, to extinguish (subdue) passion or selfishness:--crucify.
probably from the base of στέφανος; a cluster of grapes (as if intertwined):--grapes.
from the base of ἵστημι; a head of grain (as standing out from the stalk):--ear (of corn).
the same as στάχυς; Stachys, a Christian:--Stachys.
strengthened from a primary  (a "thatch" or "deck" of a building); a roof:--roof.
from στέγη; to roof over, i.e. (figuratively) to cover with silence (endure patiently):--(for-)bear, suffer.
